A GOOD LOAF

Good bread, that is, bread made without chemical ‘improvers’ which make it fluffy, pappy, bland,- is one of my favourite things. I confess to being a ‘Breadie’ who can bore for Britain consulting with fellow cultists.

I make my own sourdough loaf. A boast: my ‘starter’ is over 30 years old.. But, I also make a loaf or two which don’t require such forethought as sourdough, which make take 15-18 hours before the end product is ready, even though it requires very little kneading.

So, here is a quicker bread which also needs very little effort and can be contemplated, assembled, finished in less than a long morning or an afternoon.. It also requires not very much yeast and uses ordinary beer as a raising agent and flavour enhancer, The sugars and additional yeasts in the beer contribute to the taste and speed. For this recipe, I use very ordinary pale ale or light sort of beer- any kind will do.

I use mostly white flour, with only a quarter of the weight in whole meal, as I personally find too much brown flour in a loaf produces a stodgy, heavy loaf. But, that is my own personal preference; I leave the proportion of white to brown flour to you.

Ingredients: 6g dried yeast; 110ml warm water; 600g flour; 300ml beer; 12g (1 ½ tsp)salt.

Method: In a large bowl stir together 70g of the flour, the yeast and the warm water. Cover this mixture and leave it in a warmish spot for ½ hour. Then add the beer. Remaining flour and salt into the starter, incorporating it all by kneading briefly until it’s amalgamated. Cover the bowl and leave it to rise for 2 hours until it’s doubled in size. Then, with floury hands shape it into a loaf and place it on a floured baking sheet. Cover this very loosely and leave it to rise for ½ hours, while you heat your oven (220’C or 425’F). Slash a few slits in the middle of the loaf with a very sharp knife3 or razorblade, then bake for 30-35 minutes till golden. You can place a tray of warm water in the bottom of the oven to add a bit of steam, to encourage rising.

When done, cool on a rack.

-Carla Phillips

A MIDSUMMER SPREAD

A popular sort of meal, which can be expanded or contracted, depending upon how many you have to feed – this is centred on several simply cooked ingredients, cooled and then served with a bowlful of sauce, which can be used sparingly or lavishly, depending upon the individual preference of each diner.

I know that I gave this sauce recipe in The Quay earlier on, and I am giving it again. It is easy to make, using available ingredients; it will store well in a fridge and requires no cooking at all.

Serve this sauce with cold cooked asparagus, new potatoes, basely cooked broad beans, peas, samphire, hard-boiled eggs, crab, prawns, and cold chicken…

The quickly assembled sauce contains mayonnaise (homemade or bought), Thai-style sweet chilli sauce and White Miso- also now available in supermarkets, whole (health) food chops and delis. Use only White Miso in this sauce- Brown Miso, another great ingredient, is very very different.

The Sauce: 120g Mayonnaise; 40g White Miso; 30g Sweet Chilli Sauce; 20g Olive Oil.

Method: Weigh these into a bowl. With a fork, blend them together – then serve!

-Carla Phillips

A MUSSELS TREAT

We have some of the plumpest mussels I have ever had to deal with – the local shellfish men have a lot to be proud of. Here is a simple recipe which can be served, first, hot, but when cold – say. the next day – are either good served on salad leaves or even better as a filling for a sandwich.

To clean them, (say, a litre of mussels for two servings), rinse them well in cold running water. Then, remove the threads tangling round their shells as well as any barnacles stuck to their shell. This can be done with a small sharp knife and is very important, as the barnacles may contain dead matter. Then rinse them well in a couple of changes of water, tapping them to discover any mussels which are open after rough treatment. Discard these. Now, cut up a few blades of celery, half an onion, some parsley stalks, and place them, with a bay leaf or two, and some peppercorns, in a large saucepan. Add a teacup of either cider, perry, white wine or vermouth, and bring this to the boil. Then, throw in the mussels, Cover the pot, and cook for a couple of minutes. Uncover the pot, stir them round, then recover the pot and cook for another two or three minutes. They should all be open. Remove the pot from the fire, and strain the mussels into a large bowl, but reserving the cooking juices. (I strain them into a colander), then strain the juices directly into a small saucepan. Reduce these juices until you have just about two tablespoons of the mixture, which should be shiny and somewhat gloopy. Shell the mussels and place them directly into this mixture, tossing them quickly. Spoon them into a bowl.

Make a sharpish vinaigrette using the juice of a lemon, a crushed clove of garlic, a finely chopped shallot, some chopped parsley and a tablespoon of Dijon mustard. Gradually add a teacup of vegetable oil to this. Spoon some of this vinaigrette over the cooked (and coated) mussels. You can serve this as is, or as a salad. But, it’s magic as a sandwich in sliced brown bread or a soft bap.

A SUPER POTATO CAKE

In this difficult time, here is a simple step-by-step recipe for a delicious meal which can be made with ingredients you may well have on hand – with no need to shop for the ingredients. I suggest that you make two of these potato cakes even if there is just one of you – the remaining ‘cake’ will keep well, chilled in the fridge, for up to three days, ready to be cooked just when you need it.

Ingredients: 440g potatoes (approximately a pound)- peeled, and if large, cut into reasonable chunks; 1 bay leaf (optional); salt, pepper, a little grated nutmeg; chopped parsley (from 2-3 stalks); a small amount of chopped onion (approximately a tablespoon; flour – a rounded tablespoon of flour; 1 egg; 50g cheese (I use strong cheddar); breadcrumbs (the ‘Panko’ ones from Howell’s deli are particularly good; a little paprika (to make it look golden; fat: bacon fat, dripping, vegetable oil- nothing fancy.

Method: Place the potato chunks and bay leaf in salted water to cover. Bring to the boil and cook until soft (approximately 20 minutes). Drain them well and place the back in the saucepan for a minute or two until they are quite dry. Then mash them well. Season well with the salt, pepper and nutmeg, then add the chopped parsley and onion. Mix together well, then add in the egg, then the flour. Cut the cheese into slices.

Now, cover a dinner plate with breadcrumbs. Sprinkle these with paprika. Divide this potato ‘dough in half, then halve them again. Mould one of these quarters into a large-ish round cake and place it on the breadcrumbed plate. Depress the centre of it slightly and cover it with half of the cheese. Then cover this up with the other quarter. Gently form it into a neat and circular cake. With a fish slice, turn this cake round so that you have breadcrumbed the bottom. Slide this onto a tray. Now, add a few more breadcrumbs and paprika to the plate and repeat the process with the remaining potato mixture and the cheese. You should end up with two good sized potato cakes, ready to cook.

Fry them in a nice hot pan, to which you’ve added a little oil, dripping or bacon fat, cooking them until they are golden on each side. They can keep in a low oven for a while, or cooked from cold, hours later. With salad, cooked greens, - an easy, trouble free meal.

-Carla Phillips

A USEFUL SAUCE

This is a particularly useful dressing for winter vegetables: cauliflower, broccoli, calabrese, leeks; it is fine spooned over them when they’ve just been steamed it when it is served cold, as leftovers, it makes for a super salad. I make enough to serve several times as it stores well. Basically, it is a ‘Sauce Vierge’, and though originally designed for serving over poached chicken ir pish, it is very nice indeed with vegetables on their own.

Ingredients: 12 pitted black olives; 2 cloves of garlic; 1 peeled shallot; a handful of fresh parsley; 2 teaspoons of capers; 1 small gherkin; 3 anchovies (from a can or jar); 1 smallish chilli, de-seeded and deveined; 2 tablespoons of wine vinegar; 3oo ml of olive oil.

Method: Place everything except the olive oil in a small bowl. Chop or sap it with a blender or stick blender, then dribble and pour in the olive oil. Pour this into a jar to store.If you are serving this hot over freshly cooked vegetables, you can further top it with some toasted breadcrumbs and a chopped hard boiled egg.

-Carla Phillips

AMERICAN ‘ICEBOX’ COOKIES

The name indicates an era before electric refrigeration was common. This recipe came from a book published in the 60s which was an anthology of recipes culled from American collections of booklets put out as fundraisers by (mostly) rural women’s associations…. Included are contributions by the Mrs..Eisenhower and Nixon…..There are some very curious contributions: raspberry jelly (‘Jello’) salad, mashed sweet potatoes with marshmallow- but this biscuit is a terrific find. It calls for a lot of butter ,but then, will make somewhere around 100 cookies. The dough is rolled into long cylinders, then refrigerated, and then can be unwrapped, cut and baked at will. It stores – and freezes well.

Ingredients: 450g butter, at room temperature; 300g caster sugar; 1 egg; 2 tsp milk; 1 tsp vanilla; 500g flour; a pinch of salt.

Method: Cream the butter and sugar until pale and fluffy, then add the egg, vanilla and milk. Finally, stir in the flour and salt. Chill this batter for approximately a half hour ,until it is able to be turned into cylinders. Make into several cylinders ,slightly bigger than 50p pieces (you can make these larger if you wish) directly onto Bakewell paper, which you roll up around the cylinders before refrigerating, at least overnight. Bake on trays lined with more Bakewell or greaseproof paper. You slice the dough as thinly as you can. And, in a moderately hot oven, they should take about 10 minutes to cook. When they are starting to brown around the edges, they are ready, though if you like them slightly more caramelized you can leave them a minute or so longer.

-Carla Phillips

APRICOT UPSIDE DOWN CAKE

This pale tall cake crowned with a shiny fruit top is a spectacular pudding for a large gathering – say 8 yo 12 servings. The careful following of instructions for preparing and lining of the cake tin (20cm or 8”) will insure the neat appearance.

Ingredients: 6-10 apricots, halved and stoned; 70g butter; 200g brown sugar; 2 tblsp rum; 4 eggs; 200g self-raising flour; 1 teaspoon baking powder; 150g caster sugar; pinch of salt; 1 teaspoon vanilla;. For serving whipped cream flavoured with a tablespoon of icing sugar and a tblsp rum.

Method: First of all lightly butter the cake tin. Line the bottom of the tin with a round of Bakewell paper which should be an inch or so larger than the actual circle of the bottom of the tin. Snip the edges all round the paper so that it will fit neatly into the bottom of the tin, in order to keep the fruit topping’s juices from leaking out. Butter it lightly.

Preheat the oven to 170 (gas 3- or 325F). Now, in a frying pan, melt the butter. Remove a tablespoon of this butter and place it in a largish mixing bowl. Add the vanilla to this. Set it aside while you add the brown sugar to the melted butter, heat and stir until the sugar is dissolved. Now add the apricot halves and continue to cook, very briefly, until the fruit is just beginning to soften slightly. Then remove the pan from the heat, add a tablespoon of the rum and pour the lot – buttered, sugared fruit, into the cake tin.

Now, separate the eggs, placing th yolks into the bowl with melted butter and vanilla. Put the whites into a different bowl. Beat these until stiff, then fold in the caster sugar and a pinch of salt. Leaving this aside for a very short while, now beat the egg yolk, butter and vanilla mixture until it is very light. Then fold this into the stiffened egg white mixture and last of all, sift and fold the flour and baking powder into it all. Pour or spoon this over the fruit , place it on a metal tray, then bake the cake in the oven for 35-45 minutes. When done- that is, not wet when prodded with a toothpick- leave to cool for at least ½ hour before turning out. It’s also very good completely cooled. Serve with a dollop of whipped cream flavoured with some icing sugar and the remaining rum.

-Carla Phillips

ASPARAGUS TIMBALE

A quote from the classic American cookbook, ‘The Joy of Cooking’: “The timbale is first cousin to the reliable custard and to the flighty souffle..” Combining the good qualities of both, it is easily assembled, simple to cook, an attractive way of serving leftover food as a light main dish. It’s particularly good with asparagus, which is well in season now.

Timbales are cooked in small souffle dishes or bowls, immersed in either larger ovenproof bowls, saucepans or casserole. \the gap between the two bowls is filled with boiling water and the dish is cooked, bain-marie style, in a medium oven.

Ingredients (for two) : A couple of handfuls of asparagus, stems peeled, then steamed or cooked upright in boiling water until just firm – then rinsed in cold water to prevent further cooking;2-3 eggs; 150ml (a teacup and a half) of whole milk, or milk with a little stock or cream mixed in, gently heated; 1-2 teaspoons of grated onion; a dash of paprika; salt and pepper; a tablespoon of chopped parsley; a little grated nutmeg.

Method: use a well buttered bowl. Line the sides with the asparagus, cut into segments which will ringfence the actual custard. Mix the milk with the stock and/or cream. Beat the eggs and add the seasonings, then the heated milk. Pour this gently onto the asparagus-lined bowl, then place the bowl in the larger container. Fill the gap between with boiling water and cook for 20-30 minutes, until it is set. An inserted knife into the middle will come out clean and uncoated.Then, reverse onto a serving dish.

If you want to push the boat out a bit, you can serve it with a little hollandaise sauce. But this isn’t strictly necessary.

-Carla Phillips

AUBERGINE SESAME SALAD WITH SPRING ONIONS

A recipe from a Waitrose magazine approximately 25 years ago…..

Ingredients:

3 aubergines

4 tbsp toasted sesame oil

4 tbsp soy sauce

1 ½ tbsp vinegar (cider)

3 tbsp honey

3 tbsp sesame seeds

150g fine noodles (Chinese)

1 tsp finely chopped ginger

2cloves of garlic, minced

225g baby leaf spinach

1 red pepper, very finely sliced

1 bunch spring onions, sliced – including green parts

250g bean sprouts

2 handfuls of coriander leaves, chopped

1-2 tsp sriracha or other chilli sauce

Method:

Preheat the oven to hot. Prick each aubergine all over with a sharp knife or fork, then bake for 30 minutes, or until very soft. Then remove and leave them to cool.

Meanwhile, mix the oil, soy sauce, vinegar, honey. Toast the sesame seeds in either the oven or a dry pan till golden and add to this mixture. Divide the mixture in half. Add the cooked noodles to one of these halves of dressing.

Mix the garlic and ginger into the other half of the dressing. Peel the aubergines and tear the flesh into long strips. Mix into the bowl with the remaining garlicky dressing. Drop the spinach into a pot of boiling water, return it to the boil, then drain the spinach and cool it under cold water. Squeeze it dry then mix it into the aubergines, along with the finely sliced red pepper, the spring onions and the bean sprouts. Finally add the noodle mixture, season with a little black pepper and the chilli sauce. Mix in the chopped coriander, and serve.

-|Carla Phillips

BEETROOT DIP

My neighbour served it first. She’d enjoyed it when served up by her sister-in-law in Leicester. When sampled, I was enthusiastic. It’s attractive, a rich pink colour, and the taste a heady mixture of sweetness, earthiness and heat. Accompanying toast, crackers, pita bread, it is genuinely ‘more-ish’ and it keeps well, at least a week in my fridge. So, what’s to lose? It’s not expensive- so well worth a go.

Ingredients: 2 large or 3 medium sized raw beetroots; coarse salt; 2-3 tablespoons of olive oil; 1-2 cloves or garlic, peeled; Greek yogurt; horseradish sauce (from a jar).

Method: Slice off the woody top and ‘tail’ of the beetroot, and clean them sell. Don’t peel them but you may need to use an abrasive scrubbing cloth. Roll the beetroot in about a tablespoonful of the olive oil and sprinkle them with the coarse salt. Now wrap them well in aluminium foil and bake them in a hot oven for 40-60 minutes – until they’re tender when probed with a sharp knife. Allow them to cool. They will have absorbed almost all of the oil. When cool, cut them up and add the garlic, a couple of dollops of Greek yogurt and a couple of teaspoonsful of the horseradish sauce. Either blend these with a stick blender or whizz them in a food processor until smooth, gradually dribbling in the rest of the olive oil. Taste and adjust the seasoning to your own preference. Chill, and serve in a shallow bowl accompanied by toast, crackers or pita bread.

-Carla Phillips

BLACKBERRY VINEGAR

September is the great month for gathering blackberries. Great on their own or combined with apples in pies and preserves, they also make a fine dry aperitif type wine. But for me, they are useful when used to make blackberry vinegar. This delicious combination of sweet and sour which has myriad undertones which make it the finest fruit vinegar around.Made with our local Whin Hill cider vinegar, it’s a winning combo.

You must leave the berries to soak in the vinegar for at least a month, ideally 6 weeks or longer. But once made and decanted into attractive bottles it’s a great present as well as a welcome addition to your larder. So, for each kilo of berries you will need a litre and a half of the vinegar. Leave the berries to soak in covered bucket , large bowl or big jar.

When you’re ready, strain off the vinegar. Leave the draining berries for long enough for them to yield as much liquid as possible. Then measure your liquid. For every litre use half the weight in sugar (any sort). Thus for a litre of vinegar, use 500 grams of sugar. Place the vinegar in a saucepan and immerse the sugar. Gradually bring it to the boil. Make sure the sugar is dissolved. Allow it to boil a minute or two, then remove from the heat. Pour this liquid into well washed narrow necked bottles (I use a measuring jug with a good spout for this),

This condiment is wonderful with game, liver and salads which include leftover savoury items. It can transform leftover gravy into a piquant sauce. Try it and see!

MERRY BERRY PARTY

Strawberries and raspberries are some of summer’s simplest joys. Widely grown locally, they are wonderful served simply, perhaps with some sugar and cream. But, you can vary this presentation slightly. They are fine served with brown sugar. Crème fraiche or Greek yogurt thinned with a little whipped cream are nice. I’ve tried them with sprinklings of black pepper or balsamic vinegar, as suggested by cheffy friends but these haven’t been particularly appealing.

My favourite party variation of strawberries or raspberries with cream is to whip a couple of dessertspoons of caster sugar into a potful of riccotta cheese. Make sure that you pour off the slight amount of liquid on top of the cheese. Then, I whip 150-200dl of double cream and fold this into the cheese.

If this cream is left (covered with a little clingfilm) in the fridge for a couple of hours it will solidify slightly so that you can form it into a mound or cones, then stud it with the fruit- raspberries or halved strawberries. Very glam indeed.

Served with some sort of fancy biscuit- shortbread or brandy snap, say, this can be a star of any seasonal celebration. And, if it’s between adults only, you can always fold a little brandy into the ricotta-cream combo.

-Carla Phillips

BONNE FEMME

At the end of the week, traditionally, a good French housewife would be left with very few single ingredients: a leek, one potato, an onion, a carrot, a blade or two of celery, and, perhaps, a small turnip. With all these she would assemble that classic soup- Bonne Femme- a great soup made by a good housewife .Here’s my version.

Ingredients: One of each- leek, onion, carrot, potato, turnip, and a blade or two of celery. If you wish, you can add a clove of garlic to this, but it’s not mandatory. 30G butter; a few sprigs of thyme; parsley stalks; 1 litre of vegetable stock. For serving – a little milk or cream.

Method: Clean and slice the leek, chop the onion; slice the celery and peel and chop up the carrot, potato and turnip. Heat up a large saucepan, melt the butter and then add the onion and carrot, frying them gently for a few minutes, Then add the potato, leek, turnip and celery. Add the herbs, stir them together, lower the heat and cover the pan. Leave them to cook for ten minutes, stirring occasionally. Finally, add the stock and cook for another 15 minutes until the vegetables are soft.

Remove the pot from the heat, allow to stand a couple of minutes, then blitz it very well with either a stick blender, regular blender or a food processor. Then you can either declare it finished, or if you like it lusciously smooth, you can strain it through a sieve before reheating it gently and then adding milk or cream. Either way, it is mighty good!

-Carla Phillips

SIMPLE BUT SUMPTUOUS

This is one of the nicest meat dishes I know of. First prepared for me, many years ago by Tom Faire, I think its origins are Italian. Its main ingredient is brisket of beef and its other ingredient - onions. Nothing more, and all depends on the quality of the meat – easy to succeed in this part of the world where there are individual, dedicated butchers who are all careful about the sources of their ingredients.

Nothing more is needed, other than a sprig or two of thyme (or dried thyme if the fresh stuff is not obtainable), and a tablespoon or so of olive oil. However, you do need lots of real time for this, even though no great effort is required.

You need whole brisket, and about a kilo of it, at least. This will provide for several meals –more later, about these- and you need a kilo of onions as well. First of all, slices the onions finely. Heat up a heavy bottomed saucepan, and then toss all the onions in it. Stir them well, as they start to steam, and when they are just starting to change colour, add the olive oil and thyme, and reduce the heat. Stir them occasionally as they cook gently, until they are a caramel shade. Season them with salt and pepper, then remove the onions from the pan and turn up the heat once again.

Now, brown the brisket thoroughly on all sides. Once this is done, remove the meat, add the onions, place the meat on top, then either cover the saucepan, reducing the heat underneath to the minimum possible, or place the covered saucepan in a very slow oven, or transfer the contents into an ovenproof casserole before placing it in a very slow oven. If you have a slow cooker, this is a time to use it.

Don’t add any liquid. And, take your time before looking at it; this recipe takes at least four to five hours to cook. I usually remove it from the heat, allowing it to cool completely. Then. I skim off most of the fat which has risen to the top before reheating it for about a half hour.It’s superb served with Yorkshire pudding and roasties. The onion gravy works a treat. Sliced thinly, it should be a faint pink colour in the middle.

Next day, the cold remains of the meat, thinly sliced, make perfect sandwiches. Then, there is a perfect cottage pie, using some of the gravy. And finally, if there is any of the sauce left, add some red wine to it, and a little water. Heat these up, place some croutons or dried bread on it, grate some gruyere cheese over the lot, and grill it briefly. Voila! Onion soup, French style!

-Carla Phillips

USING THE BEANS

As I write this, the weather is still reasonable, lettuce and salad ingredients still abundant, as well as green beans – runner or French- so that the salad I am suggesting is a suitable lunch, starter or accompaniment dish. I have also added sliced tomatoes or a small sliced avocado to this. It tastes and looks fresh, seasonable.

The dressing, once made, is a laster. It is delicious with hard boiled eggs and cold cooked (NOT overcooked) broccoli.

Ingredients: For the salad, lettuce, cold cooked green beans, with optional extras: sliced ripe tomatoes, avocado, etc; half a shallot chopped with a small handful of dill or fennel or tarragon.

For the dressing: 1 tablespoon of Dijon mustard; 1 clove of garlic; ½ teacup of boiling water; juice of half a lemon; 3-4 tablespoons of olive oil; a little vinegar (wine or cider).

Method: Prepare the salad ingredients, topping them with the green beans, then the chopped shallot and herb. To make the dressing, mix the mustard and garlic in a smallish bowl using a stick blender (Or use a processor or ordinary blender). Gradually trickle in the hot water. Then add the lemon juice. Now trickle in the olive oil, and last of all add vinegar to taste.

-Carla Phillips

BROAD BEANS

The best broad beans are those you’ve picked early. While they’re still quite small. These are a ‘good feed’ raw, just podded, wih an accompaniment of a a few shavings or slivers of Peccorino, Parmesan or mature cheddar cheese. Good for a snack, or even an informal preliminary to a meal. This one was introduced to me by my Italian daughter-in-law.

In fact, if the broad beans are immature enough, you can treat them as if they were regular green beans, that is, cooking them briefly, draining them and serving with just a little butter.

My favourite way of cooking fresh, youngish broad beans is to pod them and throw them into fiercely boiling unsalted water for only three or four minutes. Then drain them, add salt and pepper and a tablespoon of cream or crème fraiche. Delicious!

Once the broad beans are large with tough skins, it’s worth skinning them once cooked. I know this is a bit tedious, but when the skins are discarded, the inner beans are very fine indeed – nice by themselves, but a gorgeous addition to an ordinary tossed salad. Here is a nice vinagrette for this sort of summer salad.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar; 1 clove of garlic; 1 small shallot; a handful of parsley; salt and pepper; 4-6 tablespoons of olive oil.

Method: Make this if you can with either a blender or stick blender. Mix together the vinegar with the garlic, shallot, parsley. Blend these well. Then trickle in the olive oil, and last of all season to taste. When this is well blended it can be decanted into either a squeezy bottle or a well rinsed out plastic ketchup bottle, to be squeezed out onto the salad. It stores well at room temperatures.

-Carla Phillips

BROCCOLI QUICKIE

One of the quickest delicious meals, carrying no particular burden of using a lot of kitchen apparatus-

Here is a current, favourite pasta dish. Only using two pans, with pasta and some sort of greens—broccoli, broccoli rabe, sprouting broccoli,calabrese- are my choices, here is a good dish for one or two people.

Per serving, I use around 70-80 grams of pasta, preferring tagliatelle or some sort of noodle (papardelle would serve, as well). As for the greens, I use about a handful or so, per person , about a generous normal serving. I cut the broccoli, etc, into smallish, bite size pieces, and if any bit of it is tough, I will peel it. This only takes seconds. For the sauce, I use a couple of tablespoons of cream (about 50-60ml), and 40-50 grams of grated parmesan cheese.

So, here goes: first boil your salted water. Then, throw in the pasta. In a separate saucepan, gently heat up the cream. Three minutes before the pasta is done, add the greens into the boiling water, and stir briefly with a fork. While that is finishing cooking, add the cheese to the cream, stirring until the cheese is dissolved and the sauce is unctuous. Season to taste. When the pasta is cooked, drain it rapidly and add the pasta-broccoli mixture to the creamy sauce. Mix well, season, and if you want a perfect but rich little addition to make it all a bit glossier, add a small ‘nut’ of butter/

-Carla Phillips

CHEAP!

First of all – a ‘cheap’ recipe has no meaning at all, unless it’s going to be consumed. So make sure it’s diner-friendly. Second, have more than one use at one meal in mind for your ingredients. It’s a good idea to think of some vegetables- seasonable, sustainable, as the basis for your meal, with the protein as a welcome ‘add-on’, which provides taste as well as nourishment. Another tip: spend what you can on a store of ingredients which can enhance anything – anchovies, gherkins, dried chillies, olives, as well as cheese- cheddar, parmesan…These are all often cheapest at market stalls.

Anyway, here are a few recipes, in season now, using either broccoli, sprouting broccoli or calabrese, which help make a satisfactory and simple meal.

Broccoli and pasta with a savoury sauce: Ingredients: for each 100g serving of pasta, a handful of broccoli, calabrese, etc per person. These should be cut into small, bite sized bits with any hard stems peeled. This way there should be lots. BUTTERNUT SQUASH SOUP WITH MISO AND COCONUT

from food52

Ingredients

3 tblsp olive oil

900 ml water

70g white miso

1 large onion, diced

1 2-3cm ginger, peeled and gratedf

2and1/2 tsp cumin

1/2tsp cayenne

1and ½ kg butternut squash, peeled and cut into smallish cubes

coconut milk – either ½ cup of canned, or 45g coconut milk powder dissolved in ½ cup of water

1 tsp salt

Method

F|irst make the miso stock. Dissolve the miso in about ½ cup of water. Bring the rest of the water to a simmer and dissolve the cold miso-water mixture into it. Bring it to a simmer, but don’t let it boil.

Now, heat a large-ish heavy soup pot. Add the olive oil and onions, and cook them till theiy are translucent. Then stir in the ginger, cumin and cayenne, and stir them briefly, before adding a ladleful of the miso stock. Then add the cubed squash and salt, mixing and combining everything, and finally pour in the rest of the stock. Simmer this for about 20 minutes, until it is completely tender. Turn off the heat and puree the soup in a processor or with a hand blender- or you can strain it.

Return the pureed soup back to the pot and stir in the coconut milk. Taste, and adjust the seasoning if you like.

BUTTERSCOTCH BROWNIES

I have given out this recipe countless times, because these easy little cakes, a true ‘Tray Bake’ are easy and delicious. Also, given that this is Fair Trade time, the ingredients, at least some of them, are appropriate.

Made in a single saucepan, it doesn’t require much equipment, other than a Swiss roll tin (33x23) which has either been greased and floured or lined with silicon paper.

Ingredients: 120g butter; 200g dark muscovado sugar; 120g light raw cane sugar; 2 eggs; 230g self raising flour mixed with 1 tsp salt; 2 tsp vanilla extract; 80g chopped nuts or 100g dark chocolate, crushed.

Method: Preheat oven to medium. Melt the butter, then stir in the sugars until dissolved and just starting to bubble. Remove the pan from the heat and leve it for a minute or two. Then beat in the egs, the vanilla and add the flour. Last of all add either the nuts or the chopped chocolate. Pour this mixture into the tin and bake for 15-25 minutes, that is, until it has browned and is starting to crust around the edges. Slice into squares or bars, which you can store in an air-tight container,

-Carla Phillips

BUTTERSCOTCH PIE

While there are some butterscotch desserts that are more sumptuous: custards, sauces, creams… this particular recipe is a crowd pleaser,

Ingredients: either a digestive biscuit crust or one made of ground walnuts, a little sugar and melted butter. Use a largish pie tin.

For the filling: 500 ml whole milk; 120 ml double cream; 3 level tablespoons of cornflour; 120g butter; 90g light brown sugar; 120g dark brown sugar; 1 level teaspoon salt; 1 teaspoon vanilla extract.

Method: First prepare and cook the crust. Next, mix the milk and cream together. Set aside a teacup of it, but heat the rest. Set aside a couple of teaspoons of the butter, but combine the rest, together with the sugars and salt in another saucepan and cook these together until they sizzle. Then stir in a couple of tablespoons of hot water to dissolve the mixture completely.

Now, combine the set aside cold milk-cream mixture with the cornflour, and stir this into the rest of the heated milk and cream. Stir this into the brown sugar and butter mixture. Continue to cook this, stirring continuously until the mixture has thickened and just started to bubble. The colour should darken slightly. Remove the pan from the fire, add the remaining butter and the vanilla. This will stop the filling from cooking any more. Pour the mixture into the prepared crus, and leave it to cool. Top with whipped cream (I sometimes stir a little rum into this) – or just serve with a little crème fraiche.

-Carla Phillips

CARAMEL BUTTERSCOTCH CAKE

Rich, sweet – though not as sickeningly sweet as many other versions of this recipe, I like to bake it in two square 20 x 20cm pans, then cut in half, for two layered loaf-shaped cakes, but a couple of round pans will certainly suffice.

Ingredients- for the cake: 200g butter; 50g light brown sugar; 50g dark brown sugar; 50g caster sugar; 3 eggs; 250g self raising flour, sifted with 1 tsp baking powder; 1 tsp salt; 1 tsp vanilla extract; 100g Greek yogurt.

Ingredients-for the icing: 125g light brown sugar; 125g dark brown sugar; 160ml cream (single or double); 50g butter; 1 tsp salt; 1 tsp vanilla extract

Method: Cream the butter and sugars until light and fluffy. Add in the eggs, one by one.Then add the vanilla. Alternatively, add dollops of the flour and the yogurt. Spread into two plans lined with Bakewell paper, and bake at medium (350’) heat for 20 minutes, until they are golden brown on top. Leave to cool in their pans, and they’ll be easier to tip out for assembling.

|For the icing- slowly warm together the sugars, salt and cream in a saucepan. When dissolved, up the heat and with out stirring, bring to a soft boil stage (238’). Remove from the heat, add the butter, vanilla, then stir well, before beating it with a fork until it is a spreadable consistency, then ice the cakes. Leave to stand until thoroughly cool before cutting.

-Carla Phillips

CARAMELIZED ONIONS

I recently read that Spanish cooks buy caramelized onions in tins and jars. What a good idea for a convenience food, I thought, and resolved to try making my own and see how it kept.

Well, this is a really handy little item.. Cut up and sliced very thinly, cooked slowly in olive oil, occasionally stirred, seasoned with a little salt and pepper and a thyme branch or two until they are a comfortably beige mixture – these are then ready for anything. Chilled in a wide mouthed jar, these have been real little time savers.

How have I used my first batch? First as a tartlet filling, topped with grated cheese, one egg and a little cream. Secondly, as the topping for an omelette. Third, briefly reheated till just starting to sizzle, in a sausage sandwich. My first batch, made from three medium onions, fitted into a large, well-packed yogurt carton This lasted three weeks.. I can see that they will save time making soup or sauces.

-Carla Phillips

CAULIFLOWER TONNATO

I found this recipe in a very old newspaper cutting which dislodged itself from another ancient clipping filed away in an album. It dates from the late 70s and is originally American- measurements in ‘cups’ and specifying a ‘can’ of tuna. Terrifically tasty, originating from an Italian classic sauce traditionally served with veal, it makes a perfect starter when served in small portions on some lettuce leaves and is a grand lunchtime salad, Please don’t be put off by the notion of this combination, even the most rabid fish rejector may enjoy this.

Ingredients: 1 large cauliflower cut into florets; a normal sized tin or tuna steak orchunks in oil, drained; 1 small chopped onion, chopped;2 hard boiled eggs; 2 tblsp capers; 2 tblsp chopped parsley; 1 clove of garlic; 3-4 tblsp of wine vinegar; salt and pepper to taste; 150 ml olive oil; optional -4 anchovy fillets.

Method: Blanch the cauliflower florets in boiling water for 3 minutes, Drain them and refresh the under cold water. Set them aside in either a shallow bowl or wide but not to deep serving dish.

Using a food processor or stick blender, zap the tuna together with the eggs, onion, garlic, capers, parsley and vinegar (and the anchovies, if using them(. Slowly add the olive oil to the mix. You should have a thick, smooth sauce. Taste and season it. Pour the sauce over the cauli and refrigerate until needed. Serve over lettuce, garnished with more chopped parsley. There may seem to be too much sauce at the start, but it is surprising how much is absorbed.

-Carla Phillips

CHICKEN MARY TEMPEST

An extraordinarily old-fashioned recipe, the name alone should tell you this; who was Marie Tempest?

Answer, a singer and actress, famous from the turn of the last century into the early 1930’s. This recipe dates from the time when grand chefs named sumptuous dishes after celebrities. Think Peach Melba or Omelette Arnold Bennett.

Anyway, the silky richness of this dish was particularly popular with diners in our restaurant; mostly because of the egg yolk addition rather than the cream and cheese which were more modest in amounts. The ingredients are simple enough but there are several stages to the dish, none difficult or requiring too much fiddling about, and indeed, it can be made well in advance.

Ingredients (for 4 people): 2 Large cooked chicken breasts; 250g small button mushrooms; ½ litre of milk; 250g chopped onions; 70g flour; 4 egg yolks; 100g butter; 1 tablespoon double cream; 50g grated gruyere or parmesan (or a mixture);2 teaspoons of sherry; salt; pepper; cayenne; nutmeg; paprika; a little more grated cheese for topping.

Method: Heat the chopped onion gradually in the milk. Bring it just to a simmer, then turn off the heat and let it steep until the liquid is cool. Meanwhile, remove the skin and bones from the chicken and chop it into smallish chunks.

Chop the mushrooms very, very finely. Without using any fat, cook them in a frying pan, stirring, until all their moisture has evaporated. This will take from 7 to 10 minutes.

Now make the first part of the sauce. Strain the milk, discarding the onions. Make a cream sauce with this liquid, half the butter and all the flour. Stir until it’s thickened, just starting to bubble, then season with the sherry, salt and pepper.

Now, whisk the egg yolks. Divide into two bowls. Add some of the cream sauce to one of these bowls, then stir this back into the whole sauce. Add a dash of cayenne and some grated nutmeg, and finally, the cream.

Add a third of this sauce to the chopped mushrooms and mix well.

As to the remaining sauces, add the rest of the egg yolks, most of the remaining butter and the grated cheese.

Now, to assemble. Coat the chicken chunks with the mushroom mixture and place these in a buttered gratin dish. Coat the whole with the remaining cheese sauce, then cover with the little bit of grated cheese, some paprika and the few dots of the remaining butter.

Bake this in a very hot oven for 12-15 minutes, then serve it with very plain but colourful vegetables: greens, carrots, etc. Very more-ish!

-Carla Phillips

CHICKEN SOUP, OLD STYLE – ‘JEWISH PENICILLIN’

This simple and easily made soup is served with fluffy dumplings (‘knaidlach’), which I have included in this recipe.

Ingredients: for the soup: 1 or 2 raw chicken carcasses (available and inexpensive at the butchers); extra chicken wings or chicken feet, if available; 2 onions; 2 carrots; 3 sticks of celery; parsley stalks; a handful of dill; optional- a small turnip

Method: roast the chicken and bits briefly – 10 minutes in a hot oven; then combine them in a large saucepan with the onion. Add 2 litres of water to them, then on top of the stove, bring it to the boil. Simmer for an hour and a half, then add 2 teaspoons of salt, the vegetables, and cook for an hour longer. Then, strain the soup.

For the dumplings: 75g of pulverised matzos (matzo meal); 2 eggs, separated; salt and pepper.

Method: Beat the egg whites until stiff, then fold in the lightly beaten yolks, then the matzo meal and salt. Cover the bowl and chill for a half hour. Then bring a pan of water to the boil. Form the dumpling batter into smallish balls and drop them into the boiling water. Simmer them for 20 minutes. If you cook them in the actual soup they will soak up so much liquid that you won’t have enough soup to go round.

Just before you need to serve the soup, bring both pots to the boil, then slide the dumplings into the hot soup. Garnish with a little chopped parsley.

-Carla Phillips

CHINESE BOXING

A one-person show, if good, can be incredibly powerful. ‘Chinese Boxing’ written and acted by Mark Kitto, is a re-enactment of the Boxer Uprising, at the start of the last century: a historic event when all the Western embassies (plus the Japanese) were held under siege for 55 days until they were relieved by the arrival of troops led by the British. Starting as a lecture and lantern slide show set at least a century ago, this took place on Friday evening at Wells Maltings. The author, a longtime Norfolk resident who lives locally has been touring the country with this performance.

It was entrancing. Diplomats (British and Chinese), soldiers, Chinese courtiers, sounds from the Dowager \Empress. The distant and not so distant sounds of gunfire – all brilliantly evoked. Greed, revenge, snobbery, prejudice, plus the knowledge of Chinese history and customs, all revealed in this portrayal of a momentous historical event which inevitably echoes today. We ignore history at our peril.

Narration, acting, sounds and strikingly attractive set and costumes were all faultless. It seems amazing to be so fired up by this evocation of a historically remote event, but clear repercussions have trickled down to the present. This production is travelling all over the place. If possible, don’t miss it!

-Carla Phillips

CHOCOLATE ORANGE CAKE

When my children were very small, I made this cake. It was bigger and sweeter. Through the years drinking chocolate was replaced by cocoa powder, the sugar content lessened’ a little marmalade was added; it became smaller, more delicious.

Ingredients for the body of the cake: 1 small orange- separated into its zest and juice; the zest and juice of ½ of a lemon; 100g of softened butter; 80g caster sugar; 2 eggs; 100g self raising flour sifted with 20g cocoa powder, 1 tsp baking powder and a good pinch of salt; the juice of the orange and half lemon.

For the filling and icing of the cake: a few teaspoons of marmalade; a small orange, separated into juice and zest; the zest and juice of the remaining lemon half; 30g cocoa powder; 40g butter; 150g icing sugar,

A 7 inch (17 ½) baking tin, lined with paper and a medium hot oven.

Method: Beat the softened butter with the fruit zests and sugar until the mixture is light and creamy, Add the eggs and beat until smooth. Gradually mix in the dry ingredients, then the juices. Pour the batter into the cake tin, then bake for 35 minutes. If it looks as though it is starting to brown on its top too early, place a baking sheet in the tin top until the time is up. Then the cake should just be starting to pull away from the sides of the tin. Allow it to cool for 5 minutes before turning it onto a rack, till cool.

When the cake is completely cool, cut through the middler, in order to have two layers. Spread these two halves with a very thin coating of marmalade. Then make the filling and icing by heating the juices and zests of the orange and half lemon with the cutter and cocoa powder, stirring well until they are dissolved. Add in all the icing sugar and stir well until smooth, Then remove it all from the heat, keeping on stirring until it thickens into a spreadable paste. Place some of this paste onto one of the layers, spreading it rapidly and cover with the remaining half. \finish by icing the top and sides of the whole cake. If it is a little too thick, use a spatula dipped into a little water. It should be shiny, smooth and glossy.

CHOCOLATE GLAZED HAZELNUT MOUSSE CAKE

This is almost impossibly rich and has to be served in small, sliver like slices. When I make it for a lot of people I will use a nine inch spring-form baking tin, and double the recipe, but if it’s for 8-10 people make it in an eight inch spring form tin.

Shortbread base- Ingredients: 25g hazelnuts, toasted, skins rubbed off; 3 tablespoons sugar; 75g flour; 50g butter; 15g cocoa; pinch of salt

Method: Pulse the nuts in a processor with the sugar until the nuts are finely chopped. Add the rest of the ingredients and pulse until a dough forms. Press this into a 20cm (8 inch) springform pan. Prick it with a knife or fork all over, then bake for 20 minutes at 180’c.

Mousse- Make this while the base is cooling.-Ingredients: 1 teaspoon gelatine; 2 tablespoons of cold water; 150g chocolate hazelnut spread (Nutella); 120g Mascarpone: 350ml cream (double or whipping); 50g sugar; 75g cocoa

Method: Sprinkle the gelatine into the water and warm in a bowl immersed over hot water, leaving it to soften, then melted. Then beat in the chocolate hazelnut spread until combined. Remove from the heat. Whisk it into the Mascarpone in a large bowl. In another largish bowl, combine and beat together the cream, cocoa powder and sugar until the cream forms soft peaks. Whisk a third of this into the chocolate hazelnut mixture, then fold in the rest. Spoon this over the crust (still in its tin) and chill for at least 3 hours.

The Ganache Topping- Ingredients- 100ml cream; 100g chocolate, chopped

Method: Bring the cream to a simmer in a heavy saucepan. Remove from the heat and then add the chocolate. Leave it to stand for a minute, the whisk until it’s completely smooth. Transfer this to a small bowl, stirring occasionally until it is slightly thickened. Run a warm thin knife around the inside of the springform pan, then remove the side. Slide the cake off of the bottom and transfer to a serving dish. Pour the ganache onto the top of the cake, then spread slightly, allowing the excess to drip down the sides.

-Carla Phillips

KNOCKOUT CHOCOLATE BROWNIES

Previously, I wasn’t a fan of chocolate brownies. Butterscotch brownies filled the bill as far as I was concerned. But a recent trip to New York City to visit my eldest daughter has changed my mind completely. She served the following recipe up, and like everyone else present, I couldn’t wait to get the recipe. As you will see, when you examine the ingredients, they are massively rich in chocolate. Please use decent chocolate, with at least 60% cocoa butter content! But, they are really easy and quick to make, and even though the original recipe called for massive slices, smaller and daintier slices seem fine to me.

Ingredients: 230g dark chocolate, 140g of it chopped or hammered into small chunks or shards; 125g butter; 250g sugar; 1 tsp vanilla essence; 90g plain flour; 2 eggs, at room temperature; a pinch of salt if you use unsalted butter. Use a 20cm (8inch) square baking tin or dish, lined with Bakewell paper.

Method: Melt the butter and 90g of the chocolate together- either in a microwave or a bowl set well above simmering water, Stir to blend, then remove from the heat. Mix together, in a separate bowl, the eggs, sugar and flour. Then blend them with the butter-chocolate mixture, stir in the vanilla essence, and last of all, the remaining chocolate chunks. Put this into the baking tin or dish, and bake it in a moderately hot oven (180C or 350F) for 10-12 minutes – an inserted toothpick should come out clean. Transfer the baking tin to a rack and leave to cool before slicing.

-Carla Phillips

FAIR TRADE TREAT

It’s Fairtrade Month again, and this is an indulgent recipe using fine ingredients sourced from the Third World. Safe in the knowledge that the real producers of these good cooking and eating materials are actually receiving a fair return for their labour, we can enjoy this heavenly tart which doesn’t require very much work.

Lots of Fairtrade ingredients are directed towards that well known British characteristic, the Sweet Tooth. This recipe is very rich indeed, and perfect for special occasions; I suggest serving it in little wedges rather than hearty slices. Unless, of course, you are entertaining a Chocohalic….

CHOCOLATE HAZELNUT TART

Ingredients: for the base- either an ordinary baked blind pastry shell (for a 23cm (9inch) tin or a biscuit base using approximately 150gm of crushed digestive biscuits or chocolate biscuits and 100 gm of melted butter. These should be mixed, pressed into the tin, then baked in a low oven for 10 minutes. In any case, the crust for this tart must be cool.

Ingredients for the filling: 120gm of hazelnuts, toasted, then chopped or crushed finely; 300 gm of dark chocolate; 150 gm of chocolate-nut spread ; 220ml double cream; a pinch of salt.

Method: Simplicity itself. Break the chocolate into finish pieces. Bring the cream to the boil, then add the chocolate pieces, and remove the cream from the fire. Whisk until it is smooth. Then, add the chocolate spread, then the chopped nuts and a pinch of salt. Mix it together, then pour onto the crust and cool the pie until set.

As I said before, the Fairtrade ingredients are particularly fine in this recipe, especially the chocolate spread.

-Carla Phillips

CHOCOLATE MOUSSE

Fairtrade Chocolate Mousse

A gloomy time of year, with only the lengthening of daylight and the sudden, sweet appearance of snowdrops to improve prospects.

So a sweet treat is in order. As it’s Fairtrade Month, with its products widely available through the Methodists and Friends, the WI, the Farmers’ Markets etc., their chocolate tastes absolutely wonderful as well as being a genuinely politically correct product – not the result of human exploitation, and decidedly better tasting than many more established brands.

So, here we have the simplest recipe for Chocolate Mousse. It will feed three or four and is easily achieved by anyone,

Ingredients

100g dark (Fairtrade) good quality chocolate

25 g unsalted butter

40g caster sugar

3 eggs, whites separated from yolks

Method

Melt the chocolate by placing it in a bowl with the butter and sugar over (not immersed in) simmering water. When these are melted and blended, stir in the egg yolks. Remove from the heat.

Now whip the egg whites until they form stiff peaks. Fold the chocolate mixture into the egg whites then chill this mixture for at least half an hour. Serve with cream.

You can vary this by adding biscuits or sponge fingers, which have been soaked in sherry, rum or brandy. Or you can put the mixture into a Swiss-roll tin, which has been lined with buttered paper, and bake it for ten minutes. It will swell up then collapse, but it can be covered with whipped cream and rolled up, becoming Chocolate Roulade.

Cheer up, everyone! Spring is coming!

pCHOPPED CHICKEN LIVERS, GRANNY-STYLE

My grandmother was not an ambitious cook. An immigrant, a working woman,,she only made the few dishes she was familiar with. The most tasty was her chopped liver s[read, which was for parties, some sort of family gathering. Served on little slices of rye bread, with nice sour dill pickles, it was always a treat. It is one dish I could probably make in my sleep (from having observed it made, many times). Made of very few ingredients, its rich texture and fine taste make it an eternal delight.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons of either chicken, duck or goose fat; 1 medium onion thinly sliced; 1 package (225g) chicken livers, drained (don’t use anychicken hearts if they are included); 2-3 hard boiled eggs; 1 generous handful of parsley; salt; pepper; a branch or two of fresh thyme: optional: 1 teaspoon of soy sauce; 2 teaspoons of sweet sherry, marsala or port.

Method: In a well heated frying pan, dissolve the fat with the thyme branch and the onion. Add a little salt and pepper, and fry until the onions are just starting to soften. Then, up the heat a little and fry the chicken livers until they are browned and cooked,but still slightly pink. Now, place these in a food processor, with the parsley and hard boiled eggs. Blitz, taste, then add any seasoning needed. Spoon it into a bowl, cover it well and chill it, at least overnight.

My grandmother, not having a food processor, had a curved chopper and a gently curving bowl- reminiscent of the Italian ‘mezzaluna’ which she used to chop the whole thing together when cooked, but the modern processor gives much the same effect.

-Carla Phillips

CHRISTMAS HAM

A really terrific recipe- not just for Christmas!

Ingredients: 1 large boneless ham – 2kg at least

3tbsp black treacle or molasses

pinch of mace or small blade of cinnamon

1 tsp whole allspice

1-2 bay leaves

1 tbsp black peppercorns

zest of ½ an orange

1 tsp cloves

juice of the orange half

For the glaze:

Handful of cloves

5 tbsp dark brown sugar

1 and ½ tbsp of mustard powder

grated zest of the other ½ orange

20 ml ginger wine

Method: Put the ham into a large stockpot and cover with cold water. Add the molasses, spices bay leaves and the zest of the orange, and the peppercorns. Bring it slowly to a simmer, skimming off any scum. Simmer gently for about an hour and a half. Using a meat thermometer, check the internal temperature. It should reach 68c.

Heat the oven to 220c-- very hot. Lift the ham out of the liquid and allow it to cool slightly, then carefully cut off the skin, leaving as much fat as possible. Score this in a diamond pattern, then stud the centres with the cloves, Put the ham into a foil lined roasting tin.

Mix the glaze ingredients into a thick paste and brush this all over the fat. Place this into the hot oven for about 25 minutes, basting it a couple of times, You can sprinkle a bit more sugar over it. The glaze should be caramelized and bubbling.

Allow it to cool completely before chilling. Leave to cool for several hours, - indeed, overnight- before serving.

‘CLASSIC IMPOSSIBLE’

On the weekly family 'Zoom’, my daughter mentioned successfully making the chocolate version of ‘Impossible Pie’, and I was intrigued by the name. Consulting ‘the net’ I realized that this was the name of a sort of pudding baked in a glass baking dish – and also found this recipe, the true ‘Classic Impossible’, which I tried out. The original ‘classic’ was gynormous, and slightly too sweet, and given in American cup measures.So, here is my modified recipe, which I halved, and this will serve 2 or 3 portions. It’s a sort of custard pie, and is ridiculously economical and easy to make, It’s best made in a flattish glass container, like a pie dish or one of those old Pyrex baking dishes which seem to be in many un-’decluttered’ kitchens.

Ingredients: 1 glass baking dish, well buttered with about 10g of butter. 2 eggs; 90g sugar; 35g dessicated coconut; 35g flour; 240ml whole milk; 1 tsp vanilla extract; a little grated nutmeg.

Method: In a jug or bowl, combine the eggs, milk, sugar, coconut, flour and vanilla. Blitz with a stick blender then pour into the buttered dish. Sprinkle the nutmeg over it. Bake in a moderate oven for 35-40 minutes, until just set and beginning to pull away from the edge. Nice served with a little cream.

-Carla Phillips

CORNBREAD AND SPOONBREAD

Two recipes I’m often asked for. I suppose that everyone expects a ‘Yank’ like me to know all about cornbread, and everyone who has sampled its posh cousin, spoonbread wants that recipe.

They both use maize meal, that quintessential New World ingredient, universally adopted and familiar in African, Eastern European, Spanish and Italian cuisine. Of course, I’m talking about ‘Polenta’ which is the same as cornmeal as far as I can tell. It’s widely available, commonly found at delicatessens, health food stalls and shops (in Wells at Nobby’s).

For cornbread: Ingredients: 90g self raising flour; 100g polenta; 60g sugar; salt; 1 egg; 2 tablespoons of either oil, melted butter or dripping; 150ml milk.

Method: First, oil a 20cm x 20xm pan and place it in a hot (220c,gas7) oven. Then combine the dry ingredients. Mix the egg, fat and milk together and stir this into the dry ingredients rapidly. Pour into the tin, and cook for 25-30 minutes. Halfway through the cooking you can add little bits and bobs, of sweetcorn, or chopped peppers, or ham and bits of bacon. Cornbread is fine served with spicy food: chilli beans, spiced tomatoes, etc...

Spoonbread, which is really a souffle made with maize meal but no flour is extremely nice with spicy foods, bitterish greens and game casseroles.

Ingredients: 100g polenta; 500ml milk; 80g butter; 1 heaping tablespoon of sugar; good pinch of salt; 3 eggs, separated. Use a casserole or souffle dish, 15-18cm wide. Oil or butter this before use.

Method: Heat the milk, then stir in the polenta, salt and sugar. Stir the mixture until it’s thick then stir in the butter. Cool this slightly, then stir in the egg yolks. Preheat the oven to medium hot (gas6). Whip the egg whites until stiff, then fold them into the mixture. Pour into the casserole and bake it for 30-40 minutes, until it’s risen and browned. Serve immediately.

-Carla Phillips

COURGETTE CREPES

This started out as a recipe by Patricia Wells in ‘Bistro’- probably long out of print. She was a NY Times reporter in Paris who collected recipes from ordinary good French restaurants in the 70s. I changed the recipe to suit my tastes and needs, using spring onion instead of garlic, adding cheese at the end to make a ‘main’, rather than a ‘side’, It looks good on the plate and is easy to prepare.

Ingredients (for two): 2 small courgettes; 2 spring onions; 2 eggs; 2 tblsp cream; 2 tblsp plain flour; 2 tblsp grated cheese (I used a mixture of parmesan and cheddar); 1 tblsp oil; 1 tblsp butter.

Method: Coarsely grate the courgettes, Salt them and place them in a colander, weighing them down and leave 10-15 minutes. Mince the spring onions. Then gather the grated courgettes into a cloth or J-cloth and squeeze them to rid them of excess fluid. Then combine them with the minced spring onions in a bowl. Mix with the eggs, cream and flour. Season them well.

Heat a large heavy bottomed frying pan. Add the oil, then the butter and when the butter has completely melted, and it is all starting to sizzle, spoon in the mixture, spreading them out- say, two crepes per serving. When they are browned on the bottom, flip them over. Now spoon the grated cheese over them, baste them lightly with the oil and butter, and cover them. When the cheese has melted, they are ready to serve.

COURGETTES > COURGES, A SWEET AND SOUR PICKLE

Here’s looking at a bumper harvest of courgettes! Inevitably some of these will metamorph into ‘grown up’ courges...more of a culinary challenge. In that spirit I am offering up my recipe for sweet and sour pickled marrow. If you have a glut of small courgettes, you can use this recipe; you’ll need less in weight of the littler courgettes, and less time salting and pressing them, but they will turn out equally delicious. I’ve been handing out this recipe for about 50 years, but people still get in touch asking for it- and I am not sure whether I ever put it in ‘The Quay’.

Of course, if you have an overgrown courgette, once you have grated it, salted it, combined it with some chopped onion and squeezed some of the moisture out (I use a ‘J-Cloth’), you can add a bit of flour and an egg to it all, for a rissole or vegetable cake.Still, here is that recipe for a truly marvellous pickle.

Ingredients: approximately 1kg of marrow, courge or slightly less in weight (600gs) courgettes;600g onions,thinly sliced; 2-3 red peppers, finely sliced; 1 chilli, de-cored, de-seeded and finely chopped; 2 teaspoons of salt; 300ml cider vinegar, 450g sugar; 1 level teaspoon turmeric; 1 teaspoon of pickling spice, or ½ teaspoons each of celery seed and mustard seeds.

Method: If using marrow or courge, peel it scoop out the seeds and soft pith in the middle. Finely slice it into small chunks. For courgettes,simply slice into small, pickle style chunks. Then combine with the sliced onions, peppers and chilli in a large bowl, sprinkling them with the salt. Mix it all well, then place this in a colander. Place a plate over them and something heavy on top of this plate,and then leave it all to drain, for at least an hour or two. Overnight is fine.

In a large saucepan, dissolve the sugar in the cider vinegar over gentle heat. Add the spices and turmeric, and bring it to the boil. Tip the vegetables into the saucepan and up the heat, bringing it all to a heavy boil. Cook for five minutes or so, until the marrow-courgette pieces look slightly translucent. Spoon this into clean wide-mouthed jars. Seal, Use within three or four months.

-Carla Phillips

ANOTHER LOCAL TREAT

GREAT NEWS- The Frary’s Shellfish Stall on Wells Quay now sells fresh fish as well as their range of delicious, mostly local shellfish. Their standards are high, their stall impeccably clean. We’ve long needed a local supplier of ‘wet fish’, so I’m overjoyed about this bit of news.

To celebrate, here’s another recipe for Crab Cakes. I know that I’ve already given two in my little book of Crab Recipes, and the Louisiana Crab Cakes have appeared in this magazine. But this latest recipe, a New England version, strikes me as a worthy contender for a crab cake contest, if ever there were such a thing, and it’s very simple to concoct, so here goes, with a recipe which will give enough for 3-4 diners.

Ingredients: 2 Crabs (dressed); ½ clove of garlic, minced; ¼ medium onion, minced; a tablespoon of butter; 6-7 ‘Tuck’ style plain crackers, crumbled; 1 egg, lightly beaten; 2 teaspoons of lemon juice; 1 teaspoon of Worcestershire Sauce; a drop or two of Tabasco or other hot sauce; 1 tablespoon of cream (any sort); flour for coating and a little oil for frying.

Method: Cook the onion and garlic in ½ the butter for about two minutes (till they’re softened). Transfer to a bowl, then add the cracker crumbs and everything but the crabs, stirring it all well to blend. Last of all, add the crab, combine it all and leave to stand for 10-15 minutes. Then form into cakes.

Melt the remaining butter into a little oil in a frying pan. Coat the cakes lightly in a little flour then fry them until golden brown. Serve with lemon, and a little tartar sauce.

-Carla Phillips

CRAB OMELET, CHINESE STYLE

This is a delicious and quick meal. A large-ish crab will do for two, and a small crab will yield a sumptuous single serving. The omelet is a very thin wrap around the crab filling, and for two servings you’ll need two eggsl with more water. Accompanied by a few stir fried vegetables: thinly sliced onion, courgettes, mange-tout peas, regular peas, peppers….anything rapid and easy to cook, this makes for a quick and interesting meal.

Ingredients: 1 dressed crab; a walnut-sized piece of peeled ginger, grated; a finely chopped clove of garlic; the white bit of a spring onion, finely chopped; a small segment of chilli, well chopped; a dessertspoon of sherry; a dessertspoon of soy sauce; a teaspoon of toasted sesame oil; a dessertspoon of vegetable oil. For the omelet: one egg lightly beaten with a tablespoon of water and the finely chopped green part of the spring onion; salt and pepper; a tablespoon of vegetable oil. l

Method: First of all, cook the crabmeat filling. Heat up the oil in a smallish frying pan and throw in the ginger, garlic, spring onion white and the chilli. Then add the meat from the crab, all of it. Stir, then add the sherry and soy sauce. When well mixed and hot, turn off the heat and add the sesame oil. Pile this onto a plate, and wipe out the frying pan, then place it back on the fire, and add the next spoonful of oil. Add the egg mix, and rapidly move the pan so that it fills the whole pan. Then turn off the heat, and allow the omelet to finish cooking, which should be very rapid indeed. Pile the crabmeat filling on top of it, roll the omelet around the crab mixture when serving, as though it was a filled crepe. If you are making this for two, you will have to divide the egg mixture into two portions and repeat the frying, but as this takes very little time indeed, it shouldn’t be too onerous.

-Carla Phillips

THE PRIZEWINNER

How did I get started in catering?

Many years more than I care to count, I won a big national cookery contest with a variation of the dish I’m going to show you this month. It was a layered dish of local sea food over a base of barely steamed samphire, destemmed, destalked. I still make it when samphire is around (it will be, soon-) but I have a new variation which you might be interested in trying when samphire is not available. It copnsists of substituting lightly cooked sprouting broccoli, that is, chopping the stems into small segments, immersing them into a fair amount of boiling salted water, then removing them and chilling them rapidly by sunning them under a cold tap or dunking them into some very cold water, before draining well. This refreshes the broccoli and preserves their lovely emerald colour.

Since crabs and our delicious little brown or pink shrimp are once more readily available at Frary’s stall, all is ready for a lovely cold entrée or luncheon dish. It looks appetising in a glass bowl or little glass cups or ramekins.

Ingredients (for 3-4): 1-2 cups of shrimps (the rfeady peeled ones are dearer, but if you peel them yourself, the shells make an excellent base for fish soup or stock); 2-3 handfuls of ready cooked sprouting broccoli; 3 medium to large crabs, the brown meat and the white meat separated into different bowls; 1 teaspoon light soy sauce; 1 teaspoon sherry; 2 teaspoons of brown breadcrumbs; 3 tablespoons of mayonnaise; 1 lemon, halved; 1 heaping teaspoon of mild (Korma) curry paste; paprika, cayenne.

Method: First of all, layer the bottom of your bowl (or cups0 with the broccoli. Then mix the brown meat of the crab with the soy sauce, breadcrumbs and sherry. Spoon this over the greens, gently flattening it out. Next, mix the white meat with the juice of half of the lemon and distribute this over the brown meat.

Now, stir the curry paste and the juice of the remaining half lemon into the mayonnaise and carefully cover the white meat. Last of all, sprinkle the shrimps with some paprika and a little cayenne and scatter them over the mayonnaise layer.

Voila! A new version of my prizewinner!

-Carla Phillips

A LIFE IN THE KITCHEN

It was a grubby old building, half caff, half fish shop, just off Wells Quay. We gazed at it wistfully everytime we drove there from our home six miles away, in order to buy crabs, shrimp or fish directly from the fishing boats on the quay. We could see the elegant Georgian features disguised by too many layers of garish paint. All it needed was care and attention to transform it into our heart’s desire, a proper little restaurant serving the wonderful food immediately available, including the freshly caught seafood from the quay.

At that time, 25 years ago, Wells Quay brimmed with activity. Double parked coasters bearing grain and fertilizer, fishing boats, pleasure craft, dinghies, children diving off the tallest ships, swimming between the boats. Onshore, men unloaded the coasters, the fishing smacks, selling off crab, shrimps,and the byproducts of their trips: dabs, sole, brill, skate and various other fish. Mixing with the bystanders were port officials, tourists. The seabirds were ever present: ducks, swans, nosy gulls. And beyond the harbour the beautiful salt marshes gleamed. A glorious spectacle!

We loved it and longed to open a restaurant near this hive of activity. We knew we could do it. Bernard, my husband, had grown up in the famous family hotel his parents ran in Burnham Overy Staithe. We’d worked there until the hotel was taken over (and ruined) by another, unfriendly branch of the family. We’d done other things since then, including raising a family of four. Now our children were old enough not to require constant attention and I could work full time. And, I could cook. I’d won several national prizes, ran a successful catering business and had worked part time as a chef in a local restaurant, open only during the summer.

Working in that seasonal restaurant, I’d begun to yearn for our own business. During my sessions, we filled the place simply by offering dishes containing only fresh, local ingredients. These proved more popular than the ‘safe’ options of steak, sausage or battered fish.

Nearly a quarter century ago, these notions seemed radical. We were cautioned, when first approaching a bank, not to reveal these menu plans. Indeed. Bank managers saw little advantage to buying and running a restaurant situated by the sea. Folly indeed to surround oneself with 180 degrees of water, we were told. Nevertheless, we did it- and now things have changed. Most eating places pay lip service to local and seasonal ingredients nowadays.

So, this is why I offer here, as a couple of tasters, recipes containing the most local and seasonal of ingredients for this time: crab and asparagus.

CRAB SLICES

When we first started the restaurant, crabs were served in only one way: dressed, that is, the flesh extracted then returned to the shell, then served with a simple salad and possibly a little mayonnaise. Coming from the States, with a dad who had been brought up in Baltimore, I knew of the rich American repertoire of crab dishes. These slices can either serve as sandwiches, or finely cut into dainty slices, make the most appetizing seasonal nibbles.

It must be made the day before it’s required, in order for the ingredients to blend and the bread to become fully infused with the crabby flavours. And, one roll will serve several people, if it’s cut fairly thinly, Set out on a tray, tittivated with parsley, or in season, swags of samphire – or perhaps some Japanese seaweed such as Hijiki or Arame, soaked, drained and then scattered, this is an elegant ‘amuse guele’. The amount of heat from the chilli sauce can be varied to suite your taste, but don’t eliminate it altogether as chilli and crab compliment each other.

Use long soft rolls, the longer the better. A genuine French baguette is a bit too crusty; what English bakers call ‘French sticks’, long, soft and slightly woolly are ideal.

Ingredients: for 1 long French stick: 2 dressed crabs; 1 tablespoon of mayonnaise; 2 teaspoons of soy sauce; 3-4 teaspoons of sweet chilli sauce (Thai or Malaysian type sauce);a handful of chopper parsley.

Method: Cut the bread lengthwise in half just enough to hollow it out. Dig out the inner crumbs, leaving it looking like a thick double dugout. Pulverize the crumbs, then empty the crabmeat, white and brown into a bowl, adding the breadcrumbs. Combine well, then add the mayonnaise, soy and chilli sauces. And finally, the parsley. Fill up one of the ‘dugouts’ and cover with the other half. Slice the loaf in half and place them side by side on a clingfilm lined tray. Cover with more clingfilm and then weigh them down with another tray on top. Find a place in your fridge to chill and store these overnight, When you’re ready to serve them, cut them neatly and thinly, garnish with parsley, samphire or seaweed, and then serve.

ASPARAGUS

The big treat of high spring, asparagus is widely grown in North Norfolk. Places I’ve bought from include Wiveton, Rudham, Binham, Bricham, Sharrington. Personally I prefer it simple. With a potato peeler I usually shave off a little at the bottom of each stalk, then stand it upright in the tallest saucepan I possess. If there isn’t much asparagus, I make a rough collar of tinfoil to put round it in order to prop it up. Then I pour boiling water on, enough to cover the bottom two or three inches, cover the saucepan, and boil for 7-10 minutes until it’s done to your taste. The top tips soften rapidly; some prefer their stalks more ‘done’ than others. Serve with melted butter’ hollandaise, or mayonnaise. It’s wonderful served alongside hard boiled eggs, with either mayonnaise, green sauce or vinaigrette.

A word of warning: if you are prone to attacks of gout, eating too much asparagus too often can bring on the agony. As in all things, moderation is advised.

-Carla Phillips

CRAB- VARIATIONS ON A THEME

Of course, we love dressed crab. And nowadays, crab sandwiches have become popular, and even crab cakes are now available in many pubs and restaurants. But crab is also fine served up as part of a made up dish, such as noodle sheets layered with crabmeat and a cream sauce- a sort of crab lasagne, if you wish to put it that way.

I served this occasionally in our restaurant,years ago. Occasionally, if available, I peeled and thinly sliced puffball mushroom, substituting these sheets of fungi for sheets of pasta (I was secretly convinced that I was probably the only chef in the world serving this dish to the public – but – who knows?…). At any rate, a packet of lasagne sheet noodles and a couple of medium to largish dressed crabs are enough to make this delicious and homely pasta dish for four, so here goes!

Ingredients: One packet of Lasagne pasta; 2 dressed crabs; 1 tablespoon of sherry; 2 teaspoons of sweet chilli sauce; 3 teaspoons of fish sauce (Thai or Vietnamese sort);1 large tablespoon of flour; 50g butter; 550 ml milk; salt; pepper; nutmeg; cayenne; 100g of grated gruyere or emmental cheese.

Method: You need a smallish, deep dish, preferably rectangular or square for this. And, it’s best to make this several hours in advance, leaving it to stand before baking, so that the pasta absorbs some of its liquid.

First of all, combine the crabmeat with the sherry, chilli sauce and fish sauce. Then make a cream sauce with the milk, flour and butter. Season this with salt, pepper and nutmeg to taste. Now, butter your baking pan and ladle a very little sauce onto the bottom. Cover with a single layer of the pasta, then ladle a bit more sauce on top. Cover this with a thin layer of the crab mixture, then with the sauce. This time, sprinkle some of the grated cheese on the sauce. Now, more pasta, some crab, pasta, then the sauce. Finish with the cream sauce on top, together with the rest of the grated cheese. Dust it with a little cayenne, and leave it to stand (preferably in a fridge if the weather is not) for at least a couple of hours. Leave it to stand for 15-20 minutes at room temperature before baking it in a medium oven for 35 minutes. Allow it to stand for 10 minutes before slicing into it.

This recipe can be varied by adding a little cooked white fish or some prawns or peeled shrimp to the crabmeat, along with a teaspoon or two of anchovy essence. And, for a really delicious addition, a savoury custard mixture of 200 ml milk and two or three egg yolks, well seasoned, can be poured over the whole dish (Moussaka-style), which will make the dish go further, besides providing a rich and sumptuous feast.

-Carla Phillips

CRUMBLE MIX

This mixture makes the best crumble, when spread over tart fruits. It’s good with gooseberries, apple mixed with cranberries, currants or other berries…. They may have to be lightly sweetened, and if you wish, they can be just cooked through, if you need to save time (the crumble then, over the fruit, will take a relatively short time to cook in a hottish oven, as the fruit warms through.

Ingredients:100g coconut sugar, 100g granulated sugar; 200g se;f raising flour (or flour with 2 teaspoons of baking powder mixed through; 150g ground almonds, 50g porridge oats; 200g butter.

Method: Mix the dry ingredients all together. Chop in the butter, pastry-style. When it is mixed together, still granular, spread it over the fruit, and then bake it. If the fruit is not cooked, bake it in a moderate oven, for 30-40 minutes. If the fruit is cooked, bake in an oven at a higher temperature for 10-15 minutes.

-Carla Phillips

A SHOW STOPPING SAUCE

The following sauce is fine as a dip for crisps and raw vegetables. But, it’s also a dream accompaniment for fishcakes, plain cooked fish or chicken. And it’s an absolute winner if you’re gathering together a ‘fridge meal’- that is leftover bits and bobs, vegetables, hard-boiled eggs – and want a nice sauce to accompany them.

It’s quick and easy to make; the mayonnaise called for can be of the shop bought variety. All the other ingredients are readily available. Any leftover sauce will store up to a week or so in a jar.

Ingredients: 3 heaping tablespoons of mayonnaise; 1 small clove of garlic, minced or grated; ½ chilli, deveined, deseeded and very finely minced; 1 level teaspoon of ground cumin; a handful of fresh coriander, very finely chopped; the juice of ½-1 fresh lime; 1 tablespoon of olive oil

Method: Combine all these ingredients. If you’ve the means to blitz them together (processor or blender of some sort), you can dispense with any of the mincing and chopping and simply mix them all together.

CUPCAKES AND BROWNIES

I read a mini-rant in a national paper recently about the ‘demise’ of old fashioned British fairy cakes as opposed to the unstoppable rise of American-style cup cakes.

What nonsense!

Both are fine little cakes, made of the same basic sponge mixtures. Fairy cakes are baked in smaller, flatter tartlet tins, cupcakes baked in deeper muffin tins. Cupcakes are slightly bigger. The round, curvy top of fairy cake tops are sliced off finely then split into semi-circular ‘wings’ perched on top of the iced cakes (hence the name),

The slightly larger cupcakes can be iced and then stacked into a pyramid or large ‘mountain’; this is particularly popular as an alternative wedding or celebration cake.

Brownies, another American confection, are dense, squidgy cakes, baked in a large Swiss roll tin then sliced into bars or squares. Chocolate brownies are famous for containing lots of chocolate, butter and sugar, but not much flour. They’re all easy to assemble, but when baking they must be watched as if they are overbaked, they are dry and tough.

Now, for a simple recipe for Butterscotch Brownies, These little treasures are a cook’s gift. Made in a single saucepan, they don’t require much other equipment. This recipe is adaptable. If you wish, substitute cut up chocolate or chocolate drops for the walnuts. Or, if you wish to bake simple drop cookies, add three more tablespoons of Self Raising flour to the basic mixture then drop them in teaspoonsful onto a baking sheet lined with silicone paper.

Ingredients: 120g butter;200g dark muscovado sugar;120g light raw cane sugar; 230g Self Raising Flour mixed with 1tsp salt; 2 eggs; 2 tsp vanilla extract;80g chopped walnuts. A Swiss roll tin (33x23), greased and floured.

Method: Preheat oven to medium. Melt the butter then stir in the sugars until dissolved and starting to bubble. Remove pan from heat and leave for a minute or two. Then beat in the eggs and vanilla. Sift in the flour-salt mixture, stir well and add the nuts. Pour this mixture into the prepared tin then bake for 15-25 minutes- that is, until it’s browned and beginning to crust round the edges. Slice into squares or bars. Then store in an air tight container.

-Carla Phillips
