DOUBLE CHOCOLATE MOUSSE

Every restaurant should have a really good chocolate dessert. When we started out, I tried several different recipes – I’m not a true ‘choco-holic’ and most did not satisfy. I quickly discovered that unless the chocolate itself wasn’t dark, and of a high enough proportion (above 60%- but under75%) the result was disappointing. I finally worked out something which resembled a chocolate sort of pastry which I used to buy from a little patisserie near Maubeuge-Mabillon when I studied in Paris.

It is basically two mousses, one set atop the other. The base is technically an omelette souffle, which rises and then sinks back. This forms the ‘crust’ with a richer topping of a mouse set with either real or ‘veggie’ gelatine – both work! Not very much sugar goes into this pudding. This made it acceptable for many diabetics, and its absence of four made it ‘gluten-free’. But, it is very rich. Small servings are recommended. Make it in a large pizza or quiche dish with enough of an outer lip to contain it. It is made in two parts, the base is baked, and when that is cool the top is poured over it.

Total quantities required: 325g dark chocolate; 8 eggs; 75g sugar; 250ml double cream; 3 tablsp rum; 1 tsp vanilla essence; 1and1/2 teasp gelatine powder (the vegetarian version works well here); a little butter for greasing the dish; a little water.

For the base: Butter for greasing the dish; 125g chocolate; 4 eggs, the whites separated from the yolks; 75g sugar; 1 teasp vanilla.

Method: Chop the chocolate into small pieces and place it in a bowl with a tablespoon of water and melt it, either over simmering water, or in a microwave oven, removing it several times to stir it. When it is melted, stir in the egg yolks and the vanilla. Beat the egg whites until stiff, then gradually add the sugar. When this is all incorporated, fold the chocolate mixture into it and then pour this into the buttered baking dish. Bake it for 15-20 minutes in a medium oven until it isn’t liquid in the middle, but is just starting to colour more on the top. Remove from the oven, leaving it to cool, it will gradually sink while you prepare the topping.

For the topping: 1 and1/2 tsp gelatine powder; 200g dark chocolate; 4 eggs, whites separated from yolks; 3 tablsp rum.

Method: Dissolve the gelatine powder in a little bowl containing 2 tablesp water, and leave this to warm, very gently, either over a little simmering water or for a second or two in a microwave. You want this to just dissolve from powder into liquid. Chop and melt the remaining chocolate with another tablespoon of water and the rum. When the chocolate has just melted, stir in the gelatine, and then the egg yolks. Stir it well. Beat the egg whites until they stand in stiff peaks. Then whip the cream.

Now, first fold the chocolate mixture into the cream. Last of all fold it all into then egg white mixture. Pour this onto the base, and leave it to stand an hour before refrigerating, for several hours before serving.

I know this does seem long, but it doesn’t take too much time if you have everything needed on hand. It can be served with yet more cream, if you dare!

Carla Phillips

EGGS BUTTLANDS

Here’s a recipe, invented when there were a couple of ordinary cooked leftovers in my fridge, plus milk, cheddar and a few eggs. While these ingredients may seem insignificant and ordinary, I want to assure my reader that this combination is nothing short of wonderful – very classy- which is why I’m calling it Eggs Buttlands. I’ve made it several times since for friends and it never fails to please. I’m not being too precise about the quantities of the main ingredients; wouldn’t it be silly to measure out most leftovers?

Ingredients (for 2): approximately 2 good dollops of mashed potato per person; cooked broccoli (if done from fresh, immerse your florets and sliced peeled stalks into rapidly boiling salt water for 4 minutes, then remove and strain under running cold water); 1 or 2 poached eggs per person and cheese-mustard sauce.

Ingredients for the sauce: 3ooml milk; 1 tablespoon of flour; 1 tablespoon of butter; 1 teaspoon of Dijon mustard; 80-100g cheddar, grated.

Method: Make the sauce Delia-fashion, that is, combine the cold milk, mustard, butter and flour in a saucepan and place over high heat. Stir constantly until it is thick and smooth, then remove from the heat. Add in most of the cheese, stirring constantly until smooth. Leave a little cheese aside to top the dish with before baking.

Now, for the final bit. Preheat your oven to very hot. Butter a deepish ovenproof dish. Place your mashed potato on the bottom. Top with the cooked broccoli. Then, on top of this, carefully place your poached eggs. Coat the top of these with the cheese sauce, and scatter over the remaining bits of grated cheddar. Place your dish in your nicely heated oven and in about 10-12 minutes it should be bubbly, heated through, slightly brown on top and utterly delicious!

-Carla Phillips

FAVOURITE THINGS – FOOD IN THE LAST 50 YEARS

In March 1965 my husband Bernard and I came to live in Norfolk, in the coastal village of Burnham Overy Staithe. Bernard’s parents ran a large hotel, overlooking the creek and salt marshes. His dad, George was in poor health; the family needed help. Bernard had been born and brought up there.

The Moorings Hotel, a large building facing on to the creek, was made up of the original Georgian dwelling and its adjoining outbuildings and barns facing the water of the tidal creek, directly across from its small island, alongside a large swimming pool (originally part of a jetty), surrounded seawards by romantically empty sea marshes across the creek, it was a beautifully situated building. It had been converted into a hotel in the early 1920s by Bernard’s grandparents. His grandfather had quarrelled with his brothers and had been bought out of his share of the family distillery in London. He and his wife and large family had come up to Burnham Overy for a holiday, renting a houseboat on Scolt Head Island. While on a day trip to Burnham Market they had spotted notices for an auction sale at the Hoste Arms of the Moorings buildings and outbuildings. It was then called Staithe House and Grandpa bought it sight unseen, compete with a sitting tenant.

The sitting tenant died and his daughter moved away to become an Anglican nun. Grandpa decided to convert it into a hotel. He hired local builders, told them what he wanted and the new hotel opened a few years later, His requirements included a central heating system and wash-hand-basins in each room. It was roughly modelled on the model of a mini country house. No locks on bedroom doors and plenty of old-fashioned service, from polished shoes (left outside bedroom doors each night), early morning teas (in bed) and food for any dogs accompanying their owners. As well as the swimming pool, there were marshes to explore, the boat to Scolt Head Island, and a tennis court. Indoors, there were several lunges, a billiard room (doubling up as a well-stocked library) and, of course, meal after meal in a large dining room directly facing the water.

Meal after meal. From early morning tea to a large cooked breakfast. Then, elevenses (coffee, tea and biscuits). A hearty lunch. Tea in the afternoon then a full meal in the evening. If lunchtime was skipped, sandwiches would be prepared, with cake, etc.

The hotel opened at the beginning of March and closed at the beginning of November. During the winter break, there were a few occasions when the hotel re-opened for the Sailing Club banquet and the like, but winter was given over to family holidays, followed, in the new year, by extensive spring cleaning and the making of the hotel’s own marmalade. This marmalade was made by a long process in which the fruit was sliced and soaked for several days in mater – every receptacle in the establishment would be filled with the mixture of fruit and water and be left to stand….I still make it that way and its making takes up a lot of space.

Even though there was this winter gap of time when it was not open, The Moorings was successful from its beginning. It was mostly full. Indeed, the Board of Trade, which collected statistics from all hotels, informed the family that this was one of the most successful establishments of its sort throughout the UK, in spite of its truncated year. The hotel didn’t serve alcohol, even though guests were welcome to bring it along. This probably had to do with the licensing laws of the time. In the early 1960’s, the laws changed and the hotel acquired a license to serve drinks. Profits climbed. Indeed, it was this increase in profit which inspired the ultimate hostile takeover of the hotel, and its demise.

At first the hotel employed professional cooks. But Bernard’s grandpa loathed the food they produced and Bernard’s grandmother took over in the kitchen, producing the sort of simple and homely food which was warmly welcomed by the guests. Bernard’s father, George, helped her in the kitchen. He had been in the Merchant Navy but he was happy to come out of it when he and his young wife Muriel moved to Norfolk. But, when war was declared the hotel shut. George went in to the navy immediately.

During the war the village was a ‘no go’ area and the large building was requisitioned to house soldiers. Furniture was stored away in a few rooms and the hotel became the headquarters of various troops. Old Grandpa Phillips died in 1943 and Bernard’s granny moved to her daughter’s hotel in Surrey. My mother-in-law Muriel was left inhabiting the half-converted barn directly adjoining the hotel, with her young family while her husband George was in the navy, participating in a very, very active war, on convoys and destroyer in Italy and Africa. He finally ended up as a beach master during the D-Day landings and was just getting kitted up to ship off to the Far East when the war finally ended.

Muriel, originally from London, was more or less marooned in Overy Staithe. Across the road from the hotel was a large field of glebe land which had provided all the vegetables and most of the fruit and soft fruit for the hotel. She had to keep this garden going as best as she could; this included keeping bees, chickens and pigs. Some of the meat had to go to the government, but she was expected to provide her mother-in-law and sister-in-law, living near London, with some of the meat and veggies as well, dispatching them by post (via the railway in Burnham). Throughout the war George sent letters talking about planting seasons, gardening hints, horticultural suggestions….Bernard remembered helping her rub salt into the shoulders of pigs in order to make hams. It hurt.

When the war ended, old Mrs Phillips felt that she was too old to carry on. The building had been completely wrecked by our occupying troops and there was no compensation. \so the hotel was put on the market. Ir failed to meet its £1000 reserve price. My father-in-law had returned from the war a weary and frail man. He decided that he would really like to join the river police. But, he was not tall enough. Someone recommended that he lie in bed for two weeks and with a bit of luck he would st retch that extra inch that he needed to qualify. Needless to say, this did not work. So, wearily he decided to restore the hotel, room by room, which he did, chiefly aided by Nelson Scoles, a local builder.

It reopened with just a few rooms in 1947, and gradually it was restored to its full size. Soon, it attracted the same sorts of clientele as before the war, and the same accolades it had previously qon. And, though there was rationing and many of the privations common to wartime and post war England, there was still that magnificent vegetable garden. There was local game. During the war the coastal waters had largely been out of bounds, so now, there plenty of fish and shellfish. Local beaches were gradually cleared of mines and once more, became accessible to the public. The hotel was able to revive its traditions of comfort and good food.

The hotel, like many of its sort, was a mini ‘Country House’;\an early morning tea in one’s bedroom was followed by a lavish breakfast, local bacon and sausages, mushrooms, bloaters (from Wells) accompanied porridge or dried cereals. Toast from Hewitts Bakery in Wells, Orange juice or grapefruit halves, the latter served ready-carved. Then, tea or coffee.

Elevenses consisted or tea or coffee, with plain biscuits. But, soon enough the big brass gong would sound and lunch would be served to the large dining room directly overlooking the creek. There was always soup – largely an invention of my father-in-law made up, often, of leftovers from the previous day, picturesquely entitled: ‘Norfolk Soup’, ‘Romany Soup’, ‘Game Broth’….whatever came to mind when asked by Muriel ask she typed out the menu to be Roneo’d .There were also first courses...in season, Globe Artichoke, with butter or vinaigrette; Asparagus on Toast with Melted Butter; both grown in the garden. Sometimes, exotic then, Spaghetti with Tomato and Bacon Sauce. Sometimes Dressed Crab was on the menu. These arrived boiled but not dressed and everyone working in the hotel assembled in the kitchen to prepare them. My sister-in-law remembers a few occasions when there were not enough people on hand and she did about 30 crabs on her own. These were simply served, dressed, put back in their shells, along with mayonnaise and a sliced quarter of lemon.

There were cooked meat main dishes, and on Fridays, always a cooked fish dish like slices of halibut with cheese sauce. And of course, there were always cold options – yesterday’s roasts swerved with salad. Meals always had cooked fresh vegetables alongside potatoes. Puddings were often stewed fruit served with ‘Shapes’ of semolina, tapioca, cornflour – or hot teamed puddings. Evening puddings were a bit more elaborate.

Tea was simple but traditional. Thinly sliced bread. Dainty sandwiches of cucumber, tomato or egg. Plain home made cakes: sponges, rock cakes and a few bought biscuits.

And then, in almost no time, the big gong would sound again for the evening meal. The food at that time was slightly fancier. Glorious fish: turbot or sole, sometimes lemon sole or dabs- often treated simply, simply floured and sauteed, swerved with a slice of parsley butter or Maitre d’Hotel butter. There were often partridges, pheasants, duck and guinea fowl as well as chicken, all served with inventive sauces and accompaniments.

Like most cooks, Bernard’s dad had his own likes and dislikes. He loved vegetables but cooked them longer than they do nowadays- but the freshness and quality of them still shone through. He did not like garlic, though he did grow a couple of rows of it for a couple of years after the war when the family housed a strange French lady who insisted on having it for her health. He made friends with some of the American families who were stationed at nearby Sculthorpe air base and was intrigued with some of their American dishes. His inventiveness came out in his soups and sauces. This was noticed in the earliest years of ‘The Good Food Guide’ for it was in the second edition that the Moorings appeared and continued to appear until our family left the hotel.

Most of the main ingredients were fully traceable in origin. Meat came from Barkers, the Burnham Market butcher. On Sundays, there was a huge roast of ribs of beef, roasted on the bone. Dad had been to a ‘carving school’ and was adept at serving out roasts, as was his eldest sister who had sold her hotel in Surrey and joined him in the kitchen during the later years of the hotel. She was a good baker and made meringues last thing at night in a slowly cooling electric oven which had been used during the main supper meal.

When the man who smoked bloaters in Wells retired, Bernard went to join him for a few days in order to learn how they were done. He and his dad converted an outdoors loo up in the garden into a smoke house, which they ysed. Otherwise fish came from Mr Farrow in Burnham, He delivered large turbot, brill, cod and halibut as well as sole and dabs.

Guinea fowl, partridges and pheasants came from Pettits of Reedham who were also hotl customers. Mrs Pettit made decorations from the feathers of their birds. Other produce was delivered by carious wholesalers, milk coming through the local dairy in Burnham, who also made and delivered a delicious cream cheese. Later on, I mixed this with various herbs, producing a sort of Hungarian style Liptauer cheese spread.

Ice cream, made by a prize-winning Cambridge dairy came by train; it was picked up in Hunstanton. My father-in-law also bought whole Stilton cheese, often choosing ones which had won prizes in various county shows (the Royal, the Royal Norfolk and the East of England shows). He read about them in the papers and telephones the makers. They were beautifully served in a splendid large Wedgwood Stilton dish, complete with a special knife. Other British cheese also were served.

Wholesalers, including purveyors of fancy stuff like anchovies or fancy tinned fruits, came to the hotel, as did the equivalent of a modern cash-and-carry wholesale firm. There were no supermarkets then. Indeed, when we returned to England after living in America, that super markets might be a good idea, he replied that they would never go down well in England, particularly in Norfolk!

When we came to the hotel in 1965, the hotel had only recently gained their liquor license. Bernard took over this, reading book after book about wines before they started their wine cellar in a part of the outbuilding in back of one of the garages. We bought most of our wines from Peatling and Cawdrons, storing some of them in their cellars in the shop in Wells, at the Globe. Bernard and his dad also bought consigns of wine from some of the auction sales in London. They constructed asmall bar in one of the lounges that immediately led on o the dining room and I worked there before supper time, trying my best to serve occasional cocktails (hastily looking them up in a little booklet) as well as serving sherry and pre-dinner aperitif style wines.

We found a house to live in on Friars Lane in Burnham Norton in the summer of 1966 and moved there on the day that England won the World Cup. Bernard cycled to work from our home and I stayed at home with out very young children. Occasionally I made a few American-style puddings for the hotel restaurant, but I was very busy indeed with the family and our large (one acre) garden. And it was then that me formation as a cook re-commenced.

What was available in local shops was limited. No garlic, Nor peppers or aubergines. No chillies, yogurt, skimmed milk, soured cream. No undyed smoked haddock. No fresh or frozen orange juice. Privations and the frugality of war had diminished and hardened the tastes of the general population, And, even in a climate which is able to produce fresh vegetables virtually all year round the availability of many of them was narrow. And, there were few native traditions for preserving. For instance, there is no local version of pickling or preserving cabbages in order to make sauerkraut.

Here, I think that I must familiarize you with a bit of my own background. I was born and raised in the USA. My parents were both immigrants from Russia, with families who regarded food simply as fuel. Their diet were heavily plant based and designed to outlast hardship. Porridge and hot cereal in the morning. Plenty of hearty vegetable soup, summer and winter, cold and hot. Bread designed to last for longer than a week. Pickled, cured, smoked and dried meat or fish. Mushrooms, fresh or dried – all of these the mainstays of a Slavic diet.

Luckily, when we moved to Burnham, we had, four times a week, deliveries of old-fashioned good bread from Grooms. I could not abide the widely available fluffy, tasteless commercial bread found in many homes and shops.

I missed many of the mainstays of my New York American diet, particularly various fermented milk products. Why couldn’t I buy yogurt, or soured cream, or buttermilk? Then, during my first year of Living in Burnham Norton, I caught hepatitis. Because I could not digest fat, I wanted skimmed milk. Not available then, except in dried and powdered, imported from France, One early morning, on the radio, we heard farmers complaining that they just could not sell enough milk.We wrote, suggesting that they try selling skimmed milk. There was a quick reply – there was no demand! When we asked about yogurt the answer was the same. We sent away for yogurt culture and began making our own…

The ethos behind the cuisine at the hotel was one of luxury. Standards were high, and well appreciated. The staff at the hotel enjoyed their own good meals, though thy insisted on having chips rather than potatoes cooked in any other way. In our newly acquired house, I got to know our neighbours and grdually made friends with many local people. And I became familiar with their daily food habits. We all used a local travelling butcher (from South Creake) who called once a week. When I asked him what he sold most of, he pointed to the stacks of trays in his little van, each containing ‘pig’s fry’ - a mixture of offal, liver, kidnes. This was often the sole fresh meat meal each week. This was often supplemented by tinned meat – Spam and Fray Bentos pies and some tinned fish, with occasional fish and chips which had its own van. Tinned fruit and some powdered ready-to-mix puddings were also popular. Pastries included sausage rolls and Norfolk Shortcakes, the latter a pastry made with lard, containing dots of more lard, dried fruit and sugar. Meals were accompanied with fruit squashes, Industrian sauces and jam was on hand, as well as that squidgy, fluffy bread.

Many families prepared a packed lunch for their children, although the school cooks prepared decent, tasty and nutritious meals for the children. \the school cook’s sensible and tasty ways with vegetables (‘I just show the cabbage t the hot water’, she explained) were rejected. And, when my children had a birthday party and invited their classmates, I would receive heartfelt pleas to please provide sandwiches made with ‘shoppy’ bread and jam, with plenty of fruit squash as an accompaniment.

Nevertheless, many local families had members who were ardent wild fowler and pigeon, rabbit,and hare appeared on their tables.Of course, dubiously obtained pheasant, partridges and other game also appeared on their tables. Poaching then was a reasonable bread-winner, as local trains which accessed London could quickly whisk away their booty to London. Nowadays, with pheasants available at such low prices, this seems unimaginable. Then, the newspaper printed weekly reports of poachers up before the magistrate.

There were also those who gathered mussels, samphire and cockles. Over the years, there had been may disagreements between authorities administering the marshes and coasts over the gathering of these things. The uneasy balance between these parties still persist even though they all have vested interests in preserving this coastal area.

As the growing of vegetable crops became more industrialized, with picking and packing automated over the years, the farming population diminished. There were still gangs of fruit pickers, harvesting some soft fruit and on some farms, apples, pears, and asparagus. Some of the pickers were recruited from groups of travellers. Others were local housewives, and their gangmaster strutted around like cockerels….

The local diet was supplements with strong seasonings like mustard and horseradish. Mustard was grown locally and sold to Colmans of Norwich who dried and powdered it, selling it in small tins. Horseradish, a common and deep rooted ‘weed’ was grated before being combined with vinefar sugar and cream. There were a few horseradish ‘king’ who would bring their whole families to the coast to dig for horseradish during the winter months, Finely grated, and combined with vinegar, sugar and cream it was often available in small jars on stands along the roads between Lynn and Wisbech, Parsley and mint were the most commonly used garden herbs. Saffron, which historically had been common in these parts, was largely unknown and has only recently been revived though the offices of Dr Sally Francis, a Burnham Norton girl.

It was not until the mid to late 70s that different products became available. Appearing occasionally were exotic vegetables – aubergines, courgettes, peppers, chillies. More fruit: mangoes and lychees. It is hard to imagine that salami and brie cheese were so exotic that it meant a drive to Norwich in order to obtain them. When the first Leftleys, a delicatessen, opened up on top of Wells High Street, it seemed a boon and delight to be able to buy these things locally.

The shallow waters of our coast had been a great source of fishing for locals. Traditionally, dabs (a sort of flounder) were caught in the shallow creeks by walking around in the water, bearing a long rake-like fork with sharp prongs at the ends, which stabbed and speared the fish as they swam in the shallows. Severely trimmed, then floured and fried, these were a popular local meal. Other fishing methods included laying out nets along the beaches, which brought in sea trout, salmon, bass and mullet. Local fishermen also netted mackerel, dogfish, and occasionally, brill and sole. Most of these fish, and their fishermen, have long disappeared, and local trawlers bring in crabs, lobster, shrimp, and if they go out far enough, whelks.

FISH PIE

This is one of the great English dishes. It’s not suitable for a single or pair of diners, unless there is a handy freezer nearby. It has a few procedures which take a bit of time, though with a certain amount of planning it doesn’t really take that long, and can certainly be prepared well in advance. But, for a real crowd pleaser, this certainly takes pride of place.

Ingredients: (for 4)- 1 small amount of salmon fillet;smallish amounts of smoked haddock fillet; a small fillet of haddock, cod or other white fish;l a handful of cooked prawns; optional- more fish, mussels, clams, scallops,etc.; mushrooms, capers, and- optional- hard boiled eggs; peas, carrots. Potatoes- a good sized potato per serving; 3 tablespoons of cream; 600ml milk; 1 egg; butter; flour; 2 bay leaves; paprika; nutmeg; salt and pepper; Thai fish sauce; Marsala wine (or sweet sherry); breadcrumbs; optional – a little grated parmesan cheese.

Method: First of all, place the smoked haddock in a smallish shallow baking dish and cover it with 200 ml of the milk and a bay leaf, Place a sheet of foil on the dish and bake the fish in a moderate oven for 10 minutes, until the skin of the fish lifts easily off the carcass. Pour the milk into a smallish saucepan, discard the bay leaf and the skin of the fish and then cut it into bite sized pieces, placing them in a bowl. Wrap the salmon with the piece of foil, place it in the oven for 5 minutes, then remove whatever skin is on that fillet. Cut it into pieces, and add it to the bowl containing the haddock. Do the same for the white fish (cod or haddock) joining them up with the other pieces of fish. Then add the prawns- and any other bits of fish or shellfish. Slice and fry the mushrooms in a little butter, then add them to the mixture, along with a handful of capers. Cover the peeled, chopped potatoes with cold water, a teaspoon of salt, and the remaining bay leaf, bring to the boil and cook until the potatoes are really tender. While they are cooking, make a thick bechamel sauce with butter (2 tablespoons, flour 2 tablespoons, the milk from the smoked haddock and 400 ml of the remaining milk. This should be thick and unctuous. Season with the fish sauce, the Marsala and salt and pepper. Add the cream to this mixture. Allow this to cool, covering the cooking pot so that no skin is formed,

When the potatoes are coo0ked drain them and discard the bay leaf. Mash them well, then season with salt, pepper and plenty of grated nutmeg. Add the remaining milk (200 ml) and a little melted butter. Beat in the egg. They should be smooth and easy to spread. You may have to add a little milk here, depending upon the very nature of the potatoes themselves.

Now, butter a baking dish. Mix the cooled bechamel with the fish and place this at the bottom of your baking dish. If you wish to add hard boiled egg bits or peas, etc, now is the time. Smooth this quickly, then dollop on the mashed potatoes. Smooth these till they are level, and decorate with stripes formed with the times of a fork. Cover it with breadcrumbs, a few dots of butter, salt, pepper and paprika, and – if you wish- some grated parmesan cheese.

When you are ready, bake this in a moderate oven for at least 30 minutes. Allow it to stand for about 10 minutes before serving.

-Carla Phillips

FLATBREAD, JEWISH STYLE

When I was little, this was widely available all over New York City, but it isn’t so common nowadays, though it can be found in a few corners of Brooklyn and the Lower East Side. A different version of pizza or foccaccio, the dough contains less fat.It’s simple to make, and is really delicious, a perfect picnic dish. I make mine with red onions. You can use either poppy seeds or nigella seeds (also known as Kalonji, available in Indian groceries).

It takes time to rise, but there is no hard work involved.

Ingredients: 460g strong flour; 2 teaspoons sugar; 7g (one packet) yeast; 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil; 2 and ½ teaspoons of salt; 2 medium onions (red or white) finely sliced; 1 small egg, mixed with a dessertspoon of water; 1-2 teaspoons poppy or nigella seeds; a teacup of warm water.

Method: Weigh out the flour. In a small combine a tablespoon of it with the sugar and the yeast, and add the warm water. Stir well and leave it until it starts to foam \(10-15 minutes). Then combine this with the rest of the flour,half the salt and a tablespoon of the oil, Knead these together, adding, if necessary, a little more water. Knead this all together for about 7 minutes, when you should have a smooth dough. Place this in a lightly oiled bowl, turning it round, cover with some film and leave it to rise for a couple of hours. Meanwhile, gently fry the chopped onions with the rest of the salt, in the remaining oil, until they are soft and transparent. Then set them aside.

When the dough has doubled, roll it out as thinly as possible, or stretch it with your fingers, until it covers one or two flat trays. With a fork, prick the dough all over, leaving a little border around the sides. Cover it loosely and leave it to rise for a half hour in a warm place.

Now, mix the egg with the dessertspoon of water and brush this onto the dough, avoiding the unpricked edges. Scatter the onions over this, then the poppy or nigella seeds, and leave it to rise for 10 minutes. Bake it in a hot oven for 30 minutes or so, then remove it and cool on a rack. Eat hot, warm or cold.

-Carla Phillips

FLEMISH YEAST CHEESE TART

Every time I make this it vanishes from its serving plate in no time at all. Even though it is made with a rich dough and the yeast contained within the tart means that it takes a little time to realize, it is so simple in execution that it is well worth it. The recipe originally came from Jane Grigson’s French Regional Cookery, but it has been amended and adopted somewhat through the years.

Ingredients: For the yeast dough: 250g flour; 1 pkt dried instant yeast (approx 6 gms, or you might try a little block of fresh yeast); 125dl lukewarm milk; 1 teaspoon salt; 2 eggs; 100g softened butter. For the topping: 180-250g strong soft (oozer) cheese,i.e. maroilles, reblochon, livarot, or well matured camembert; 30g butter; 1 egg and 1 egg yolk; 125 cream or crème fraiche; salt, pepper and grated nutmeg.

Method: Combine the flour and yeast with the salt, milk and eggs in a food processor or mixer with a dough hook.Beat well till the dough is soft and elastic and then add in the softened butter. Transfer this dough to an oiled bowl and cover with clingfilm. Leave it to rise until doubled (approximately 2 hours in a warmish place).

Then, knead the dough briefly (to knock out the air). Place it into a buttered 23cm (9 inch) pie pan, flattening it so that it lines the entire pan.

Now for the filling. Scrape most of the mould off the cheese. Slice it thinly and place this over the yeast dough. Dot with the butter. Beat the egg and egg yolk with the cream, seasoning it with a very little salt, some pepper and grated nutmeg. Pour this over the cheese and leave it to rise for 15-30 minutes (until it has visibly risen).

Bake it in a hot (200c) oven for 45-55 minutes, until the filling is browned and the pastry seems crisp around the edges.

Slice into fine wedges, serve, and watch it disappear!

EASY FRUIT CRISP

This simple pudding is so adaptable and easy to make that I’m surprised I haven’t come across it more often. It’s fine using blueberries, summer soft fruits or, at this time of the year, apples and blackberries.

It’s best made in the bowls you’re going to eat it in- use a smallish sort of ceareal or small soup bowl which is ovenproof.

For each single portion of fruit you need a teaspoon of sugar, a drop or two of lemon juice and a tiny pinch of cornflour. Mix these with the prepared fruit {chunks of peeled apple with some blackberries, say). Distribute it into the bowl(s). Add a dessertspoon of water per portion.

For each portion of topping you need 20 grams of softened butter and 20 grams of light brown sugar. If you like, you can also add a drop or two of vanilla essence. Cream these together. You can use a mixer, wooden spoon, or if it’s for one or two you can simply use your clean and warm hand. Into this stir 30 grams of self-raising flour. Now, pat this mixture into disks (one for each portion) an d place it in the bowl on top of the sides, sealing it in on the sides.

Bake in a hot oven for 10-15 minutes, until it’s slightly more browned and the fruit is starting to bubble up well. Lovely served hot, with cream, but nice when cool as well.

-Carla Phillips

GAME TERRINE

A combination of various recipes, this one was used, time after time, in my restaurant. If you have the minced venison, you can use any other bits of game in it, to lend contrast and texture as well as taste. As for the pistachios, they are a little bit of additional colour without a very strong taste, and could be omitted – though I think they add to the look.

The recipe is easy to assemble, once you have got it all together, and after cooking and cooling, can be frozen for up to a month—but it will last up to a week or so, just in the fridge.

INGREDIENTS: For the actual terrine: 500g minced venison; 500g minced pork; 250g rindless smoked streaky bacon; 6 rashers of unsmoked streaky bacon; 100g shelled pistachios; 175ml white wine or vermouth or dry strong cider; 25 ml brandy; the seasonings: 2 tasp crushed juniper berries; ½ tsp ground allspice; ½ tsp powdered mace; ½ tsp ground coriander; 1 tsp chopped thyme; 2 tsp ground black pepper; 2 tsp salt. For the gamey ‘bits’: pigeon breasts, chunks of pheasant or partridge meat; rabbit; all cut into bite sized chunks, covered with a bit of ground pepper and a tablespoon or two of brandy and soaked for at least a couple of hours.

METHOD: In a large bowl, combine the minced venison and pork. Slice the smoky streaky bacon into small strips and add them and the pistachios into the mixture. Season with the herbs and spices, salt and pepper and add the wine and brandy. Mix well, using your hands.

Line a large bread tin with three of the slices of unsmoked bacon. Then put half of the minced mixture into the tin. Add the separate gamey bits, then cover with the remaining minced mixture. Cover this with the remaining slices of streaky unsmoked bacon. If you wish, scatter a few bay leaves on top of this, but it isn’t strictly necessary.

Now, wrap the tin well in a double layer of foil. Put the tin into a roasting tin, pour enough boiling water into the tin to come nearly halfway up the side of the bread tin, and bake in a medium hot oven for 1and ¼ to 1 and ½ hours. To test for done-ness, stick a sharp knife into the pate and if it isn’t red, you’re okay.

Leave it to cool, placing another tin on top of it, weighted down with a few tins or bottles. This is just to make the pate that little bit more dense and easy to slice; it isn’t strictly necessary. Chill overnight before emptying it out of the tin. Serve with small gherkins.

-Carla Phillips

GARDEN IN A BOWL

In one of Martin Cruz Smith’s excellent detective stories set in Russia, his melancholy hero Renko describes a vegetable plot near Chernobyl, in Ukraine. Despite the obvious danger from radiation, it is luxuriant, verdant, productive, with potatoes, beetroot, carrots, turnips, onions,etc—Russia on a plate, he concludes.

He refers, I think, to that great soup which almost might be eaten on a plate, Borscht. There are many, many different versions eaten thought the Slavic lands. Substantial ones with meat and bones, light and summery ones with just a few ingredients served mainly chilled, versions made with fermented beet juice starters, and the one that I give you now, a substantial all vegetable soup which was probably a mainstay of Lent or other fasting periods. This particular soup is fine served cold, but it is always comforting if there is a bit of wind and chill about.

The list of ingredients, sounding a bit like a vegetable grower’s catalogue, may seem a bit intimidating. Made with so many different vegetables the resulting taste is surprisingly complex and sophisticated. Its fine flavour, redolent of the productive allotment or plot, makes this one of my favourite recipes. It’s a comfort to the very ill and not ill at all alike.

I know that the quantity produced by making my version may seem awesome. But, the soup will last for longer than a week, will freeze well (use milk containers to store it) and is a really fine present for a friend. You may have to borrow or resurrect a large enough saucepan to contain it all. But it’s worth it!

Warning: there is an awful lot of cleaning, peeling and chopping required at the beginning. Sadly, there are no shortcuts, but apart from the prep, not much is required in terms of time, until the end, when you will need a stick blender, processor, or regular blender in order to amalgamate all the bits and produce the velvety, richly coloured mixture which is wonderful, reheated gently and served with a\ dollop of soured cream, Greek yogurt or crème fraiche.

Ingredients: a bunch of beetroot, complete with the leaves and stems. The roots must be peeled, the leaves and stems cleaned and chopped;a very large onion, chopped; 1 leek, chopped;1 large potato, peeled and chopped; 1 clove of garlic, chopped; a large carrot, peeled and chopped; a turnip, peeled and chopped ;2 blades of celery, chopped; a tin of tomatoes; optional- a few chopped mushrooms; a green or red pepper, chopped; 1 tablespoon of cooking oil; 1-2 tablespoons of butter; a cooking apple, peeled and chopped; 3 tablespoons of sugar; the juice of 1 lemon; 2 tablespoons of cider vinegar; parsley stalks (as many as you have); a small pinch of cumin; either a handful of fresh dill or a teaspoon of freeze-dried dill;1 tablespoon of vegetable stock powder; salt, pepper and cayenne.

Method: In a large saucepan, heat the butter and oil and saute the onion until it softens. Now add the chopped beetroots, together with the garlic and potato. Cover the pan and cook it on a gentle heat for around 10 minutes, stirring at least once. Then add in the garlic, the chopped beetroot greens and stems, the carrot, turnip, celery, apple, tomatoes, and if available, the mushrooms and pepper, together with the pinch of cumin. Cover and cook for another 10 minutes. Then, add the parsley stalks, sugar, lemon juice, cider vinegar, dill and either vegetable stock or vegetable stock powder and enough water to cover the ingredients well. Cover the pot and simmer for about 20 minutes or until the toughest vegetable (the beetroot) is tender. Then remove the pot from the heat and allow it to cool slightly before pulverizing the mixture with either a stick blender or dolloping it into the processor.

Correct the seasoning, adding salt, pepper and cayenne, and if necessary, either sugar or cider vinegar (I particularly recommend the Whin Hill cider vinegar). Reheat and serve with the soured cream, plenty of bread and butter.

GREEK SALAD

This is often perfunctory – a very simple salad, swiftly prepared. But, with very little more attention, it’s a really fine starter or ‘side’.

Ingredients, for 3-4: Several sorts of salad leaves: red, oak leaf, cos, little gem, curly leaf, perhaps a smattering of rocket – counting upon a couple of handfuls per serving, well washed and dried and if large of leaf,torn into serving sized bits; 1 cucumber, peeled and cut into smallish chunks; 12-15 small or cherry tomatoes, sliced into halves; 2 spring onions, finely sliced; 2 red peppers, de-skinned (either grill them or use ones from a jar); 12-15 stoned and halves black olives; 2 teaspoons of drained capers; 100g feta cheese, cut into cubes; a handful of parsley, finely chopped and – if available, a little chopped fresh marjoram and fennel. For the dressing: 1 clove of garlic, grated or minced and immersed into 4-5 tblsp olive oil and 1-2 tblsp of lemon juice.

Method: First of all prepare the lettuce and place it in a large bowl. Add the spring onions and mix well. Combine the cucumber chunks with the sliced tomatoes. Salt them lightly and leave them to drain in a colander for 10-15 minutes. Slice the red peppers and add them to the lettuce, along with the olives and capers. Then add the tomato-cucumber mixture, the feta cheese and the chopped herbs. Last of all, combine the lemon juice with the garlic impregnated olive oil, a little black pepper and a very small amount of salt. When you are ready, toss it and serve it, accompanied with bread.

Carla Phillips

GREEN BEANS

As I write this, the weather is still reasonable, lettuce and salad ingredients still abundant, as well as green beans – runner or French- so that the salad I am suggesting is a suitable lunch, starter or accompaniment dish. I have also added sliced tomatoes or a small sliced avocado to this. It tastes and looks fresh, seasonable.

The dressing, once made, is a laster. It is delicious with hard boiled eggs and cold cooked (NOT overcooked) broccoli.

Ingredients: For the salad, lettuce, cold cooked green beans, with optional extras: sliced ripe tomatoes, avocado, etc; half a shallot chopped with a small handful of dill or fennel or tarragon.

For the dressing: 1 tablespoon of Dijon mustard; 1 clove of garlic; ½ teacup of boiling water; juice of half a lemon; 3-4 tablespoons of olive oil; a little vinegar (wine or cider).

Method: Prepare the salad ingredients, topping them with the green beans, then the chopped shallot and herb. To make the dressing, mix the mustard and garlic in a smallish bowl using a stick blender (Or use a processor or ordinary blender). Gradually trickle in the hot water. Then add the lemon juice. Now trickle in the olive oil, and last of all add vinegar to taste.

-Carla Phillips

GREEN SAUCE

Sometimes a sauce will overwhelm the rest of a dish, swamping the main ingredients it’s supposed to enhance. But, here is a sauce, a vinaigrette, which will transform the most mundane item: a steamed or poached piece of chicken or fish, say. It can be used with tinned fish and store cupboard salad ingredients (gherkins, peeled roasted peppers, capers, olives) to make a version of Salad Nicoise. This sauce will last in a covered jar, refrigerated, for at least 10 days.

Even though it contains anchovies, don’t be put off by the idea of combining this sauce with chicken (or even pheasant); the combination works out in effect as much more than the whole of the contents!

Ingredients: 2 cloves of garlic; 2 small shallots; a drained tablespoon of capers; 3-4 anchovies; 3-4 small (cocktail style) gherkins; 1 chilli, de-seeded and de-veined; a few stoned black olives; a good handful of fresh parsley; 3 tablespoons of red wine vinegar; 6-7 tablespoons of olive oil; freshly ground black pepper.

Method: Chop the garlic, parsley, shallots, anchovies, gherkins, chilli and olives until they’re as fine as you can achieve. Place them in a jug and mix in the vinegar. Gradually whisk in the olive oil, then season with the black pepper.

Use a tablespoon of this on steamed fish or chicken. Or, combine it with cold or tinned fish, some green beans, tomatoes and peppers for a Salad Nicoise. You can also add hard boiled eggs to this.

The Nicoise mixture can be used as a sandwich filling as well, using squashy bread and weighting it down in the fridge overnight.

-Carla Phillips

GROWN UP MAYO!

When he was a little boy, my oldest son, now over 50, was a champion fussy eater. Now married to a Japanese woman who is a very fine cook, he enjoys almost every thing he obstinately rejected when a child. Now, influenced by her excellent cooking, the rest of our family has warmed to the Japanese condiments and seasoning she uses. That is why this column is a hymn to Miso, a common fermented soya product which is used to season soups, sauces, ordinary dishes. There are many sorts – and colours- of Miso. Many are available in delis and supermarkets in pricey little jars, but they can be found in oriental groceries as well as on specialist market stalls. White Miso – not really white, more of a greyish colour- has become my new best friend. Used first as an additional seasoning in leftover stir-fries, and to flavour vegetable water for soup, I’ve now branched out. A little bit, say, a heaping teaspoon full, added to about half a cup of mayonnaise (store-bought), with an additional teaspoon of sweet chilli sauce (the Thai type) makes what I call ‘Grown Up Mayo’. Mixed well together with either a fork or whisked, and serve it with all manner of things: hard-boiled eggs, cold cooked veggies, potatoes, fish and chips….It is ultra delicious.. Try it and report back!

-Carla Phillips

GRUMPY WELLS!

“Too many dogs”! “Long dog leads tangling Staithe Street”!

“Dog poo and discarded masks underfoot!”

“Too many cars. Too fast!”

“Cars parking anywhere and everywhere. Blocking off entrances. On double yellow lines!”

“Where are the traffic wardens?”

“Rude people!” “Pushy people!”

“They’re all looking for second homes. Where will our families live?”

“Supermarket shelves emptied. Small cartons of milk a prized rarity!”

I could go on. Complaints abound. We grizzle amongst ourselves. We know that we need more houses for our local population but do not agree where they will be sited. Must we give up the lovely pastureland which we see when we enter the town from the ‘Dry’ road? These scraps of meadow with their grazing horse are a throwback to a gentler past- the very past of our dinky picturesque beach railway. Will that disappear?

We all know that ‘social’ housing is needed. But where will it go? ‘Affordable’ housing is just too expensive and local builders who obtained permission for reasonably priced housing in the first place have had slippery ways of not building enough of them...And, our genuine abandoned slum, round Maryland is untouched, unchanged.

Yes, we live on troubled times. But in the past we have united often enough to see off some monstrosities and have fought for some great things. Our town council is a model body of citizens battling their corners in civilized ways, often uniting to defeat silly proposals (not that North Norfolk Council always pays attention).

We must try to listen to each other, take a longer view of our future and try to grow our town sensibly. Grumpiness will not get us anywhere.

-Carla Phillips

HADDOCK BASQUAISE

In our restaurant. Outside of the busy months, we used to have occasional ‘special’ evenings, when we would not serve our regular dishes, but would concentrate on the food and wine of a specific area. This recipe found in a French paperback: La Cuisine de A a` Z: Sud-Ouest, Perigord, was an instant hit. Several customers requested that we put this on our regular menu, which we did, from then on.

Smoked haddock is as popular in France as it is here- it is called ‘Haddock’, as if there were no other sort. And, since the delicious smoked haddock from Cley Smokehouse is now regularly available in Wells, and fresh local tomatoes are at their most plentiful and luscious, this recipe seems appropriate.

Ingredients (for 2): 400g smoked haddock; 50ml milk; 50ml water; 1 largish onion, finely sliced; 120g ripe tomatoes; 1 small clove of garlic,minced; 80g olives, stoned and roughly chopped; 10g butter; 2 tablespoons of olive oil; a bay leaf; handful of parsley, chopped; a little fresh chopped marjoram or a good dash of dried oregano; salt, pepper and cayenne

Method: Put the milk and water into a saucepan large enough to contain the fish and bring it to the boil.

Place the fish fillets in it, lower the heat and gently poach the fish for 10-15 minutes, until the fish has changed colour and is easy to skin. This process can also be done in a microwave.

Meanwhile, peel the tomatoes by immersing them briefly in rapidly boiling water, then skinning them. Squeeze them gently to remove the seeds, then chop them very roughly. In the wintertime, you can use a very small tin of chopped tomatoes.

Saute the sliced onion in the little bit of butter gently, until it is a blondish, straw sort of colour. Then add the garlic, chopped tomatoes, parsley, marjoram or oregano, bay leaf, the pepper and cayenne. Cook for about 7-10 minutes; the sauce should have thickened.

Remove the fish from the liquid, skin it, remove any bones if present, then break it into smallish segments. Add the olives and olive oil, and mix it gently to combine.Finally, add the sauce to the fish-olive mixture, then taste for seasoning. This is one recipe where you don’t want to add salt too early on, as there is a fair amount of salt in the smoked fish as well as the olives. Reheat the mixture very gently before serving. It’s great with green beans of any sort as well as mash.

-Carla Phillips

content:
HAIL CAESAR – A GREAT AMERICAN SALAD

I thought that I had already given this recipe, but, combing my files, I was unable to resurrect this one, so am giving it again. Like many Yanks, I am slightly riled when I see what strange combinations are presented in the name of relatively simple but tasty American dishes – and this one is so nice that it seems a shame to see it spoiled so frequently. The recipe given for the dressing is enough to serve it several times .

Ingredients: Romaine or Cos Lettuce (adding other sorts is not necessary). Croutons (made by tossing small chunks of bread in a very little olive oil, then spreading them out on a baking tray – then seasoning them with salt, pepper and a few sprinkles of thyme, then baging them until they are lightly browned and crisp.) The dressing: 200ml mayonnaise; 1 anchovy or a teaspoon of anchovy paste; 1 teaspoon of Worcestershire sauce; 2 tablespoons of lemon juice; 1 crushed clove of garlic; 40g grated parmesan cheese.

Method: Blitz the dressing ingredients together. Serve the salad – the leaves, croutons and dressing all together-- preferably as a light starter.

-Carla Phillips

HAITIAN STYLE CHICKEN

This easy way of preparing chicken in a personal favourite. When I was little and my parents worked full time, a Haitian housekeeper made this for the family. My mother quickly learned the recipe and made it very often- sometimes using a whole cut up chicken and sometimes using just a few parts – the legs, thighs, breasts…So it is extremely flexible and can be scaled down or up. Served hot, it is very fine, but it is also delectable cold, so that I usually prepare extra. But even if it is simple to prepare it does require an overnight marinade.

Ingredients (for two): 2 chicken pieces, or half a chicken; 1 lime; 1 clove of garlic, crushed; a half chilli, deseeded, deveined and very finely chopped; ½ teaspoon of dried oregano; salt and pepper; 1 teaspoon of tomato puree; a tablespoon of frozen peas; chopped parsley; a little cooking oil.

Method: Make the marinade by juicing the lime and mixing it with the garlic, chilli, dried oregano and some salt and pepper. Rub this well into the chicken pieces, and place them in a bowl to marinade overnight, turning them at least once.

Next day (or evening), remove the chicken pieces from the marinade, reserving it. Dry the chicken with a paper towel. Heat up a little cooking oil and fry the chicken pieces in the hot fat until they have coloured slightly. Then place them in an oven-proof casserole. Add the tomato puree and marinade to the hot oil, mix briefly, then pour this over the chicken. Cover and roast for 20-30 minutes, until the chicken is done. Then add the peas. Remove the casserole from the oven in order to allow the chicken to ‘rest’. Finally add the parsley.

This dish is particularly good served with rice cooked in almost any style,

ISRAELI STYLE AUBERGINE PUREE

Rich, unctuous, this is my favourite dip, to be served with toast, bread, veggies, or as a sauce.

Ingredients: 1 large aubergine; a dollop (heaping tablespoon) of mayonnaise; 2 teaspoons of lemon juice; 1 clove of garlic; a small pinch of ground cumin; salt, pepper, a little cayenne; a tablespoon of olive oil.

Method: Remove the stem of the aubergine and stab it a few times (to prevent a messy explosion). Bake it on a tray in a hot oven until it is soft and squishy to touch. You may have to turn it round once. This will take from40-50 minutes. Then, place it on a colander to drain it . You can weigh it down, though this is not strictly necessary. Now, into a bowl, scrape out as much of the inside flesh as you can. To this add the pinch of cumin, the garlic, lemon juice and mayonnaise.

Mix these together well either by blitzing with a stick blender or in a food processor. Season it, then trickle in the olive oil, mayonnaise-style. Leave it to chill for a few hours before serving.

In a fridge this will last for a couple of weeks.

-Carla Phillips

KIM CHEE

This will make a fair amount- 4-6 jars, say, of the famous Korean cabbage pickle. It requires an overnight soak in a large bowl, but very little time or work otherwise. If you can, try to get hold of the wonderful Korean chilli powder. Oriental supermarkets stock it, and it has a superb aroma and taste, which will have you using it in all sorts of other recipes. Otherwise, 4 or 5 red chillies finely chopped will do.

Ingredients: Approximately 2-2and ½ kg Chinese leaves- say 2 Chinese cabbages; ½ teacup salt (non-iodized); 4 spring onions; 3 tablespoons grated fresh ginger; 3 tablespoons finely chopped or grated garlic; 2 tablespoons Korean chilli powder (or 4-5 red chillies, finely chopped; ½ grated mouli (Japanese radish) 1 tablespoon sugar; 1 tablespoon soy sauce (light).

Method: Quarter and then slice the cabbages, not too finely. In a large bowl (stainless steel, enamel, glass, plastic) toss the leaves with the salt and then cover them with water. Weigh it down slightly and then leave overnight, at room temperature.

Next day, drain, but don’t rinse. Toss with the remaining ingredients and then pack it tightly into clean glass jars. Cover them.

Leave these jars at room temperature for 2-4 days. Open the jars once or twice each day, and poke around with a skewer or sharp knife to release gasses. It will mellow in flavour.

Then, store in a fridge or cool place. The Kim Chee will last for months, though it will strengthen in flavours.

- Carla Phillips

KUKU

This is my adaptation of a recipe by Allegra McKevedy’s which appeared in the Guardian some years ago. It'’ the Persian version of '‘tortilla'’- their variation of egg and potato cake. It can be served hot or cold, and though it is often cooked on top of the stove, I usually make it in a small roasting or tray-bake tin in the oven. When there are a lot of people and I’m serving it as a nibble I double the quantities, use a large roasting tin and cut it into bite sized squares.

It’s startling in appearance - bright, violent green! The texture us light, almost spongy. Served in large wedges with yogurt and a side salad, it’s a fine main dish. I usually serve it cut up small as part of a finger buffet.

Ingredients: 1 large potato, peeled, cut up into small segments, boiled in salty water, then mashed; 100g spinach; a small onion; 2-3 cloves of peeled garlic; a large handful each of parsley, coriander and dill, and, if in season, mint; ½ teaspoon of ground cardamom; a level teaspoon of salt, some pepper and cayenne; 6 eggs; a smallish slice of feta cheese.

Method: First of all, line a small roasting or tray-bake tin with same silicon (bakewell) paper. Oil it very lightly. Next, in a food processor, combine the spinach, herbs, mashed potato, seasonings and spices with the eggs. Blitz it very thoroughly to a fine mush. Then pour it into the tin. Grate some feta on it, and bake it in a medium oven for about 20 minutes, or until it is set. As I said before, it is fine hot or cold.

-Carla Phillips

LAYERED CRAB- THE PRIZE WINNER

How did I get started in catering?

Many years more than I care to count, I won a big national cookery contest with a variation of the dish I’m going to show you this month. It was a layered dish of local sea food over a base of barely steamed samphire, destemmed, destalked. I still make it when samphire is around (it will be, soon-) but I have a new variation which you might be interested in trying when samphire is not available. It copnsists of substituting lightly cooked sprouting broccoli, that is, chopping the stems into small segments, immersing them into a fair amount of boiling salted water, then removing them and chilling them rapidly by sunning them under a cold tap or dunking them into some very cold water, before draining well. This refreshes the broccoli and preserves their lovely emerald colour.

Since crabs and our delicious little brown or pink shrimp are once more readily available at Frary’s stall, all is ready for a lovely cold entrée or luncheon dish. It looks appetising in a glass bowl or little glass cups or ramekins.

Ingredients (for 3-4): 1-2 cups of shrimps (the rfeady peeled ones are dearer, but if you peel them yourself, the shells make an excellent base for fish soup or stock); 2-3 handfuls of ready cooked sprouting broccoli; 3 medium to large crabs, the brown meat and the white meat separated into different bowls; 1 teaspoon light soy sauce; 1 teaspoon sherry; 2 teaspoons of brown breadcrumbs; 3 tablespoons of mayonnaise; 1 lemon, halved; 1 heaping teaspoon of mild (Korma) curry paste; paprika, cayenne.

Method: First of all, layer the bottom of your bowl (or cups0 with the broccoli. Then mix the brown meat of the crab with the soy sauce, breadcrumbs and sherry. Spoon this over the greens, gently flattening it out. Next, mix the white meat with the juice of half of the lemon and distribute this over the brown meat.

Now, stir the curry paste and the juice of the remaining half lemon into the mayonnaise and carefully cover the white meat. Last of all, sprinkle the shrimps with some paprika and a little cayenne and scatter them over the mayonnaise layer.

Voila! A new version of my prizewinner!

-Carla Phillips

‘LE WELSH’

During our last twinning visit to France, my hosts took me to Orleans, first to visit the very fine art museum, then later to the ‘Parc Floral’, to a plant fair. For lunch we stopped in the middle of Orleans at a large, popular place which specialized in French fast food: burgers, croque monsieurs, etc. Prominently featured was ‘Le Welsh’.

Curious about it, I ordered this Gallic take on Welsh Rarebit, and found it delightful. My host, a former chef, knew the chef at the restaurant, who obliged him with describing just how it was made. Here we go!

Ingredients: 80-90g cheddar, red or white; 60ml beer (2 tablespoons)- light ale; 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce; a few drops of Tabasco; 1 egg;1 piece of toast; optional- a thin slice of ham.Use a well buttered heavy plate or baking dish.

Method: Grate the cheese as finely as you can. Then place this in a bowl and mix in the liquid ingredients very well. You will need either a lot of effort or possibly a stick blender to really make this into a proper mushy paste.

Place the toast into the bottom of your baking dish. If you are ujsing ham, place this on top. Cover with the sauce. Break the egg on top and season it well with salt and pepper. Now either bake it for 7 minutes or so in a very hot oven, or place it under a grill, cooking it until the egg is set.

Serve with either more toast, or as they did in Orleans, with chips. Voila!

-Carla Phillips

LEMON DRIZZLE CAKE – ROS’ VERSION

A winner, no matter which recipe you use- this is my personal favourite of all the recipes I have tried.

Ingredients: 120g butter (softened); 140g caster sugar; 140g self raising flour; 2 eggs; 60ml milk (5 tblsp); zest of 1 lemon. Topping: 85g icing sugar; juice of 1 lemon.

7inch cake tin greased and lined; 1 meat skewer.

Method: Beat the butter till light and fluffy. Add the sugar and lemon zest and beat well. Then add the eggs, one by one, and finally the flour (with a pinch of salt)and the milk. Spoon the mixture into your lined tin, and bake, in a medium oven for 40-50 minutes, until done. If it starts to brown too much on top, place a flat tin on top of it.

Make the syrup of lemon juice and icing sugar before the cake comes out of the oven. Prod the baked cake all over with the meat skewer, then pour over the syrup. Leave it to cool in the tin.

LEMON TART, NICOISE STYLE

When this was made, by a variety of wonderful cooks, for the Twinning Committee’s biannual feast, up at the high school, it was greeted with delight, by many of the diners. Indeed, I was stopped several times on the street, to ask for the recipe, which is why it’s featured this month. Unlike most lemon puddings, except for the crust, it contains no cream or butter, thus sitting lightly on the tummy after a slap-up dinner.

The recipe comes from Peter Graham’s translation of Jacques Medecin’s ‘Cuisine Nicoise’, ‘The Cooking of Nice’. Medecin was mayor and noted for being fairly shady, but his recipes are wonderful.

I’ve altered the recipe slightly from the original. First of all, I prefer my own pastry to the one in the book. And also, I’ve doubled the quantity of sugar specified, from 20 grams to 40 grams. Not a lot in any case, and the tartness of the taste is in no way compromised.

Ingredients: For the pastry: 150g plain flour; 100g butter; pinch of salt; a little cold water. For the filling: 2 small or 1and ½ large lemons; 40g sugar; 4 eggs; 1 tsp cornflour.

Method: Crumble the butter into the flour and salt. Add enough water to make a dough. Shape this into a disc and wrap it in film. Chill for an hour. Roll it out on a floured surface and place in an 8 or 9 inch pie or tart tin. Prick it all over with a fork, line this with foil and place inside the foil either baking beans (I use the same dried broad beans I’ve had for 20 years) or ceramic ‘beans’. Bake in a hottish oven for 10 minutes. Then remove the foil(and beans), and bake for another 5-7 minutes, until the bottom of the tart looks as though it is dry. This is called ‘Blind Baked’ pastry.

For the filling: Separate the yolks and whites of eggs, placing the yolks in a heavy bottomed saucepan. Beat the yolks with half the sugar. Then grate in the rind of one of the lemons. Next, squeeze in the juice. Finally add the cornflour. Cook, stirring, over a very, very low heat until the mixture has just started to thicken and coat the spoon. Remove from the heat. Now, whisk the egg whites until they are stiff and then fold in the remaining 20 grams of sugar. Whisk a little bit longer, then combine the yolk and white mixtures by first stirring in a little bit of the yolk mixture into the whites, then folding in the rest swiftly afterwards. Place this in the crust and bake it for 15-20 minutes in a hottish (400’) oven. It should be golden brown, and fluffy. Don’t worry when it sinks a little after it has cooled; it is still light and ethereal and a delight to serve – with cream or without.

-Carla Phillips

LINZERTORTE

This Austrian pastry is famously used in latticed tarts with either raspberries (and raspberry jam) or apricots (with apricot jam). Rich and somewhat tricky because of the dough’s high butter and ground almond content, the ingredients are simple but a bit of patience is required in the rolling out.

Contents: For the pastry: 150g ground almonds; 150g plain flour; 150g butter; 110g caster sugar; 1 tsp salt; zest of 1 lemon; juice of ½ lemon; 2 egg yolks. For the filling 200-300g raspberries and a small jar of raspberry jam or fresh stoned apricots (depends on size) and a small jar of apricot jam.

An 8inch or 20cm two-part tart pan.

Method: Mix the almonds, flour, salt, lemon zest and sugar together. Cut the butter into small segments and crumble it into the dry ingredients. Mix the egg yolks with the lemon juice and add a tablespoon of cold water to it .Add this and mix it into the flour- butter mixture, adding a very little water, if necessary. With floury hands form it into a ball, wrap it in either clingfilm or put it in a plastic bag and chill it well.

When you are ready to bake it, place a flat tray or pan into a medium oven to heat up. Roll out 2/3 or so of the dough onto a lightly floured sheet of cling film. It should be thin enough and large enough to form the base of the tart. Refrigerate the remaining dough. Reverse the dough rolled on the clingfilm into the tart tin, Cut off any bits flapping over the sides. If there are any gaps, just dab in a little more dough. Line this crust with a piece of aluminium foil and cover this with baking beans. Place this on the already hot tray in the oven and bake it for 10 minutes. Then, remove the foil and beans and return the crust to the oven and bake for another 10 minutes.

Meanwhile line another tray or baking sheet with clingfilm. Roll out the remaining dough onto it, shaping it into a rectangle. Refrigerate this until you are ready to assemble to tart.

To assemble the tart, spoon enough raspberry jam on the bottom of the tart shell to cover it well. Then tip in your raspberries (the more, the merrier, I think!). In the winter you can use frozen raspberries. Cover this fruit with a generous coating of the raspberry jam.

Remove the tray of rolled out pastry dough and cut out strips of the pastry. Form this into a lattice- the chilled dough strips are easier to manipulate than the pastry at room temperature.

Bake the tart for 15-20 minutes, until the strips of pastry are starting to colour.

For apricots, follow much the same procedure, with the bottom coated with jam, then the fresh fruit, arranged, and then the jam spooned over,

Leftover dough, then rolled out and re-used as jam cookies. Roll it out a little more thickly than if it were intended for a tart. Stamp it into rounds with a cookie cutter, depress the center of each circle and dab it with a bit of jam. Bake fir 10-12 minutes, until light golden brown then cool on a wire rack.

-Carla Phillips

LITTLE SAVOURY BISCUITS

I used to call these the ‘Little Savouries for the Ladies Who Lunch.’ They would be terrific at a drinks party- easy and quick to make and they don’t splat and stain the carpet!

Ingredients: 100g plain four; 100g unsalted butter; 30g drained tinned anchovy fillets; 70g stoned Greek olives; 50g grated Gruyere cheese; 50g grated parmesan cheese; ½ tsp ground black pepper; a little beaten egg or egg white (to glaze the biscuits before baking).

Method: First chop the anchovies and olives together – this shouldn’t take long. Then cut the butter into the flour, or rub it in, pastry style. Add the cheese and black pepper. Then mix in the anchovy-olive mix and form it all into a ball. Roll it on a floured surface, then cut it into little rounds. Transfer these to a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Chill them for at least 20 minutes, until you’re ready to bake them. The brush them with the beaten egg (or egg white)- and bake them in a medium hot oven (190’ or gas 5’) for 15-18 minutes, until they are golden. Cool on a wire rack before storing in an air tight tin.

-Carla Phillips

LITTLE SAVOURY PASTIES

Having a drink, without something to eat, strikes me as unpleasant. And sometimes, it’s necessary to produce something bite-sized which will either serve as an hors d’oeuvre or a light meal.

These little pastries are something I’ve made for years. They are cook-friendly, can be made ahead of time, then rewarmed for ten minutes in a low oven. They can also be pre-prepared , left in the fridge then baked for twenty minutes in a very hot oven.

Originally, I rolled out puff pastry thinly then stamped circles which I filled and fashioned into half moons. Nowadays, I roll out the pastry thinly into a good-sized square and cut it into 3 inch (7cm) squares, then turn into filled triangles. Much less work!

Ingredients: 1 packet of puff pastry. If you can get the sort that is made with butter, it’s nicer, otherwise the ordinary one will do.;3 large or 4 small eggs; 2 tablespoons of cream; a tablespoon of butter; salt and pepper; 2 or 3 slices of smoked salmon.

Method: Break the eggs into a bowl and whisk lightly. With a tablespoon, extract a tablespoon of the beaten egg and place in a small bowl with the same amount of milk or water. This will be enough for sealing and glazing the pastries.

Heat the butter in a saucepan or small frying pan. Add the eggs and cream, stirring gently till it is a thick creamy curd. Immediately pace this in a cold bowl to prevent further cooking and add chopped snippets of the smoked salmon. Stir to blend.

On a lightly floured surface roll out the puff pastry as thin as you dare. Cut into squares. Brush the edges of these squares lightly with egg wash. Place teaspoons of the filling in one corner of each square, then fold over to form triangles. Press with a fork to seal. Place the triangles on a Bakewell- paper lined pastry sheet. Brush the tops with the egg wash.

Now, chill them until 20 minutes before you are ready to bake them in a very hot oven, prior to serving. They should be a warm golden brown. They can rest in a gently warm oven, or, as said before, gently reheated .

MACEDOINE

We’re just entering the time of the year when lots of vegetables are at the beginning of their season – ‘en primeur’, as the French refer to it. Most are wonderful simply cooked ‘as is’, steamed or boiled in a little water, salted or not as you prefer.

Now, if you have some extra cooked vegetables: peas, new potatoes, turnips, carrots, broad or green beans, and later in the season, corn on the cob, let me recommend an authentic ‘Macedoine’ or ‘Russian Salad’.

Not that gloopy stuff out of tins which used to be a feature of public catering when I first hit England in the very early 1960s. No! What I’m suggesting is that you cut up your cooked potatoes, turnips, carrots into smallish pieces, to be mixed with your peas and chopped beans. If your broad beans are humungus

Peel them by crushing the skin lightly between your forefinger and thumb. Mix them all gently together and then dress them with mayonnaise (shop bought is fine) to which you add a good teaspoonful of Dijon mustard and a significant splash of lemon juice.

Unless you’ve got some yellow beetroot available, don’t add the red stuff; the taste dominates and it leaches red into the rest of the salad. And don’t include cooked legumes such as kidney, chickpea, lentils or butter beans. Their granular texture totally obliterates the delicacy of the new spring veggies.

However, a small quantity of cooked mushrooms won’t harm the mixture. Do add chopped parsley and a little finely minced tarragon if you have any.

Dollop this salad onto some nice young lettuce leaves and either serve as is, for a lovely starter, or with a hard boiled egg or two as a more than satisfactory lunch.

Later in the season, you can hollow out a halved tomato, then scoop out its middle and seeds. Salt the interior slightly and leave it to drain for ten minutes. Then pile the Macedoine into the tomato halves and serve with dressed crab, a little leftover cooked fish or some other shellfish. This is quite an elegant cold meal.

MADEIRAN ROLLS

In Madeira, they bulk up their bread dough with sweet potato. This is because, though they are pretty well self sufficient in wheat – there isn’t quite enough, and they have had to supplement their baking doughs with a more plentiful carbohydrate. This dough, slightly sweetened, naturally, by the higher quantities of natural sugars, makes for particularly tasty rolls, which are served everywhere on the island. Heated, split in the middle and buttered with garlic and parsley butter, they appear frequently with poultry or fish.

I have searched out recipes- and have finally settled on a combination of various ones- compiled from a badly translated cookbook, the net, and the words of the proprietor of an open air stall near Funchal Town Market. Easy to make, filled with all sorts of nutritional goodies from the sweet potato content, they have become quite a hit in my household. They freeze beautifully, so I make a large batch which lasts well.

Ingredients: 1 large or 2 medium sweet potatoes; approximately 600g strong flour; 2 packets of yeast; a pinch of sugar; 12 grams of salt (2 teaspoons); 200ml warm water; 1 tablespoon of salad oil.

Method: Bake the sweet potato(es) in a hottish oven for 50 minutes to an hour, until quite soft to the touch. Then, when cooled off enough to handle, peel and mash the flesh. Weigh it up in a large-ish bowl, then add enough flour to total 900grams in weight.

Now, remove 3 large tablespoons of the flour, and combine it with the warm water, a pinch of sugar and the yeast. Mix well and leave, covered, for 30 minutes in a warmish place.

Now, add the salt to the remaining flour-potato mixture, and combine it with the slightly bubbly ‘sponge’, together with the tablespoon of oil. Combine it all – you may need to add some extra water (the proportions and quality of flour and sweet potato determines this), Knead it well for 5 to 8 minutes. Then place the dough in the large bowl , cover it and allow it to rise for 2 hours.

When you remove the risen dough from the bowl,it will deflate. With your hands, stretch and roll the dough into a long ‘sausage’ and cut this into 2 ½ -3 cm chunks. Place them on trays lined with baking paper. You should have between 28 and 20 rolls. Leave theswe to rise in a warmish place, then bake in a hot oven for 15-20 minutes until lightly brown on top.
