MAINCROP POTATOES

Maincrop potatoes are one of the first great treats of late summer, early autumn. They may lack the waxy firmness and sweet taste of late spring wonderspuds, but they more than compensate with their delightfully crumbly, collapsing structure and earthy undertones of taste.

Of course they are splendid when baked. Straight out of the oven, bashed slightly (in order set their collapse in motion), split and served with butter, salt and black pepper. Or, if you like it, served with only a little butter, then some Greek-style yogurt, minced chives or spring onions, then salt and pepper. Bliss.

Or, you can hollow out the baked potato, scooping the ‘meat’ out of the delicate shell. Mash this potato well, season with salt and pepper, then grate a little onion into it. Next, mix in some grated cheddar, a little butter and a small dollop of mustard.

How much, I can hear you asking? As much as you fancy. Taste and try it. Then, pile it back into the skin-shell and grate a tiny amount more cheese on top of it. Return it to the oven—either a hot oven for about 15 minutes, or a low oven for about 25 minutes.

The other maincrop potato treat I thought I’d mention in this piece is a method of using leftover mashed potatoes. This is popular with family and friends and is an ideal easy supper or snack. Again, I’m not going to be precise about weights and measures as, in the case of leftovers, this is always variable.

If you have more than a teacupful of mash, place it in a bowl. Grate a little fresh onion into the spuds. Or, if you have some, substitute some finely chopped spring onions. Stir this into the potatoes. Break an egg into this mixture and stir well. Then stir in enough plain flour to make this mixture malleable, firm, easy to handle. Season this mixture to taste.

Finely slice some hard cheese: gruyere, Jaarlsberg, Mrs Temple’s mountain cheese, cheddar, White Stilton- whatever you like and have on hand. You want a few little slivers, roughly the size and shape of £2 coins (maybe a bit bigger).

Make little potato cakes by surrounding each little cheese sliver with mash. Roll each potato cake in breadcrumbs (dry commercial ones will do). Fry these little cakes in hot oil until golden brown. If you haven’t had these before, you’ll be pleasantly surprised. Variations I’ve tried include covering the little sliver of cheese with chopper anchovy or black olive puree. These are fine, but the added sophistication is not strictly necessary.

HOME MADE ‘MALLOBARS’ (Chocolate tea cakes)

These are best made over twp pr three days. They don’t take any great feats of skill, but the making of them and setting of them has to be spread out over a bit of time. I will give the ingredients with each bit, but if you’re doing a general shop for the whole thing, this has to be taken into consideration.The original recipe specified a 23’ x 33’ (9 x 13 inch) tin, so try to use one which has the approximate amount of room.

The ‘digestive biscuit’ bottom

Ingredients: 230 g butter; 50g dark brown sugar; 50g granulated sugar; 50g runny honey; 210g whole wheat flour; 130g white flour; 1 tsp salt; ½ tsp ground cinnamon

Method: Cream the butter with the sugars and honey. Add the dry ingredients. Then form the dough into a flattish round, wrap it in cling film and chill it for an hour. Line the baking tin with silicon (bakewell) paper. Roll out the dough between two sheets of cling film (this makes it easier to handle). Place the bough in the pan, and prick it all over with the tine of a fork. Bake it in a medium oven for 18-20 mi9nutes, until it has lightly browned. Then allow it to cool completely.

The filling

Ingredients 3 level tblsp. of gelatine powder; a teacup of cold water; 300g sugar; 50g honey; 2 egg whites; a good pinch of salt; 1 tblsp. vanilla (you can substitute rum).

Method: Place the egg whites and salt in a very large bowl. Then put the sugar and honey and ½ teacup of water in saucepan, and begin to heat it until the mixture reaches 240) (soft ball stage). Whip the egg whites until it forms soft peaks. When the sugar-honey mixture has reached the right temperature, pour it onto the egg whites, whisking it all the while. Continue to whisk for a minute, and the add the gelatine water mixture and the vanilla. Continue to whisk it for 6-7 minutes in the large bowl. The mixture should thicken and quadruple in size. Now place this on top of the digestive biscuit base, smoothing over the top. Allow it to set (at least 4 hours, but overnight is best).

The top

Ingredients: 250g dark (good) chocolate; 150ml double cream

Method: Chop the chocolate into small pieces and place in a bowl. Bring the cream to the boil, then pour it over the chocolate pieces. Whisk until the chocolate is melted and the mixture is smooth and shiny. Pour it onto the set marshmallow, and smooth it with a spatula.

Allow the glaze to set for about a half hour before marking and cutting it into little squares.

MINORCAN ROLL

We were queuing for bread in a little village in the middle of Minorca. Each customer in front of me also bought brown and white slices of some sort of rolled pastry, so when it was my turn, I automatically pointed at them and said ‘Dos!’. This is a well-appreciated version of what I call ‘Minorcan Roll.’

Ingredients: For the Caramel Syrup: 200g granulated sugar; 250ml water. For the cake: 4 eggs, separated; 2 teaspoons of melted butter;1 tsp vanilla extract; 180g caster sugar; 120g self raising flour sifted with ½ teaspoon of salt. 450ml double cream.

1 Swiss Roll tin, lined with Bakewell paper. Hottish oven (400’)

Method: First prepare the caramel syrup. In a heavy bottomed saucepan, melt the sugar with a splash of the water, without stirring, until it starts to bubble and brown. Then you can swirl it occasionally, so that any cliffs of sugar on the edge of the saucepan break up into the body of the molten mixture. When it is a good rusty brown, remove from the fire, and pour in the rest of the water, standing well back as it will hiss and spit threateningly. Now return it to the fire and stir until the mixture is dissolved. This won’t take very long. Remove from the heat and leave this to cool. (This can be done well in advance.)

Now, make the cake. Break the eggs into 2 separate bowls – a large one for the whites, and a fairly small one for the yolks. Melt the butter, and set aside.

Whip the egg whites until stiff. Then gradually add the caster sugar, meringue fashion. Don’t bother to wash out the egg beaters, and use them to beat the egg yolks until light. Add the butter and the vanilla.

Fold these into the egg white-sugar mixture rapidly.

Now sift the flour-salt mixture onto the mix, and fold them in. Spoon this mixture into the baking tin, and bake for 10-12 minutes, until dark golden brown on top. Remove this from the oven, and roll it up in its paper, allowing it to cool.

While the cake is baking, whip the cream until stiff and leave in the fridge.

When the cake has cooled, unroll it carefully, and saturate it in the caramel syrup., pouring it on to both sides. Do this as rapidly as possible so that it doesn’t break up. Fill it with 2/3 of the cream and roll it up, then, with a spatula, cover the top and sides with the rest of the cream. Chill it well before slicing it on to plates.

Variation: For a very grown up version, I’ve occasionally added rum or brandy to the caramel syrup. But, this isn’t really necessary.

This is a version of an Israeli variation of this ubiquitous dip, good with thinly sliced toast, sourdough bread, or even some raw vegetables.

Ingredients: (serves 4-6)- 1 aubergine, approx 270-280g; 1 small clove of garlic; 2 tsp lemon juice; a small pinch of cumin; a pinch of cayenne; a pinch of salt; 1 good sized tablespoon of mayonnaise; 1 tblsp olive oil.

Method: Pierce the aubergine with a sharp knife in several places and roast it in a hot oven for 40 minutes, until it’s thoroughly floppy. Leave it to cool in a colander; it will ooze. MOROCCAN VEGETABLE SOUP – MY VERSION

At first I made this soup using the fine recipe from ‘The Soup Bible’ (the best collection of soup recipes I’ve ever found). Through the years I’ve altered and added to the original, and this version is truly formidable. When I cannot obtain pumpkin or winter squash, I substitute butternut squash. I incorporated the original garnish for the soup into the body of the recipe as well as adding some spice.

Ingredients: 1 tblsp olive oil; 1 tblsp butter; 250g onions, chopped; 250g carrots, chopped; 250g parsnips, chopped; 250g pumpkin or squash, chopped; 1 clove of garlic; chopped; 1 tsp ground cumin; 1 tsp ground coriander; 1 tsp ground turmeric; 1 litre of vegetable stock; salt, pepper and a pinch of cayenne; a handful of fresh coriander; a handful of parsley; juice of a lemon; a pinch of paprika.

Method: In a large, hot saucepan, melt the butter and oil together, then tip in the onions. Mix them well, lower the heat and leave them to cook, covered for about 5 minutes. Next, add the carrots and parsnips, stirring them well. Cover the pan and continue to cook for another 5 minutes. Now add the squash and garlic, cooking them for another 5 minutes. Add in the spices, stir for a minutes, then finally add the vegetable stock. Cover and simmer until the vegetables are soft. Now, remove from the heat and add in the herbs, seasoning and lemon juice. Zap the mixture with a stick blender pr puree it in a blender or processor. Correct the seasoning and add the paprika. If it seems too thick, add a little water.

The texture, colour and robust flavour of this soup should cheer you up during these dark December days.

MOUCLADE

I discovered this dish during my restaurant days. A customer who’d enjoyed this on a trip to Southwest France told me about it. Mussels in a rich creamy yellow sauce and ‘ Please could we do this on Saturday night?’

Out came the recipe books and various versions were tried and rejected. The dish originated from one of the French Atlantic ports and used curry in the French manner, that is very mildly. It originally called for white wine but we found that the local dry cider worked perfectly, and can be used relatively lavishly. As our very fine local mussels are now available, and once you’ve had your first or second ‘hits’ of Moules Mariniere, here’s a very fine way of preparing them. Most of the work can be done in advance, so it is a useful dish for entertaining.

Ingredients: (for 2) a litre or 2 pints of mussels; 2-3 celery stalks; 3-4 shallots; ½ litre dry cider; 3 egg yolks; 1and1/2 level teaspoons of mild curry powder; 150mlo (small container) double cream; a walnut sized knob of butter

Method: Scrub and de-beard the mussels. Place them in a saucepan with half the cider, the chopped shallots and celery . Cover, bring to the boil and when the mussels have opened (3-4 minutes), remove them and shell them, saving all the liquid. Return the liquid to the heat, boiling it fiercely to reduce by a half.

In a separate heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the curry powder, egg yolks and the cream mixing it well. Then strain in the hot mussel and cider liquid, stirring it constantly over a fairly low heat until it just starts to coat a spoon. Then remove from the heat and stir in the butter.

When you’re ready to serve it, heat the remaining cider. When it just comes to the boil, add the mussels to the hot liquid to reheat them. This should not take more than a minute or two. Place them in a warmed shallow baking dish or plate, spoon the sauce over them, then place the dish under a grill or in a very hot oven, very briefly, to reheat until the edges just start to bubble. To accompany this, as a main dish, serve plain rice, and lots of brightly coloured , simply prepared vegetables: broccoli, carrots, beans,etc.

MY FAVOURITE THINGS – FIFTY YEARS OF CHANGING MENUS

In March 1965, My husband Bernard and I came to Norfolk, to the coastal village of Burnham Overy Staithe. Bernard’s family ran a large hotel overlooking the creek and salt marshes. His dad, George, was in poor health, the family needed help. Bernard had been born and brought up there.

The Moorings Hotel, a large building fronting the creek, was made up of the original Georgian dwelling and its adjoining outbuildings and barns. Facing the water, directly across from its small island, alongside a large swimming pool which was fed and emptied by a tidal sluice, surrounded, seawards, by dramatically empty sea marshes across the creek, it was a very beautifully situated building.

It had been converted into a hotel in the 1920s by Bernard’s grandparents. His grandfather had quarrelled with his brothers and had been bought out of his share of the family distillery in London. He and his wife and children had come up to Burnham Overy for a holiday, renting a houseboat on Scolt Head Island. While on a day trip to Burnham Market they had spotted the notices for an auction sale at the Hoste Arms of the Moorings buildings and outbuildings. It was then called Staithe House and Grandpa bought it sight unseen, complete with a sitting tenant.

The sitting tenant died and his daughter moved away to become an Anglican nun. Grandpa decided to convert it into a hotel. He hired local builders, told them what he wanted, and the new hotel opened later in the ‘20’s. His requirements included a central heating system and wash-hand-basins in each room, and it was roughly modelled on a model of a mini ‘Country House’. No locks on bedroom doors and plenty of old-fashioned service, from polished shoes, which would be left outside the bedroom doors, early morning teas (in bed), to food for accompanying dogs. As well as the swimming pool and a tennis court, there were marshes to explore, and of course, the boat to Scolt Head. Indoors, there were several lounges, a billiards room (doubling as a well stocked library – and of course, meal after meal.

Meal after meal. From early morning tea to a big breakfast. Then elevenses (coffee, tea and biscuits). A hearty lunch. Tea in the afternoon then a full meal in the evening. If lunchtime was skipped. Sandwiches would be prepared, with cake, etc. How did they manage to eat it all?

The hotel opened at the beginning of March and closed at the beginning of November. During the winter time, there were a few occasions when the hotel re-opened, for the Sailing Club banquet and the like, but winter was given over to family holidays, followed, in the New Year, by extensive spring cleaning and the making of the hotel’s own marmalade. This marmalade was made by a long process in which the fruit was sliced and soaked for several days in water; every receptacle in the establishment would be filled with a mixture of fruit and water and be left to stand...I still make it that way.

Even though there was this winter gap of time when it was not open, The Moorings was successful from its beginnings. It was mostly full, Indeed, the Board of Trade, which collected statistics from all hotels, informed the family that this was one of the most successful establishments of its sort throughout the UK, in spite of its truncated year. The hotel didn’t serve alcohol, even though guests were welcome to bring it along. This probably had to do with the licensing laws of the time. In the early 1960’s when the laws changed, the hotel acquired a license to serve drinks. Profits climbed, Indeed, it was this increase in profit which inspired the ultimate hostile takeover of the hotel and its demise.

At first the hotel employed professional cooks. But, Bernard’s Grandpa loathed the food they produced and Bernard’s Grandma took over in the kitchen, producing the sort of simple and homely food which was warmly welcomed by the guests. Bernard’s father, George, helped her in the kitchen. He had been in the Merchant Navy but he was happy to come out of it, and he and his young wife Muriel moved to Norfolk. But when the war came along, the hotel shut. George went into the navy immediately.

The village was a ‘no go’ area and the large building was requisitioned to house troops. Furniture was packed away into a few rooms and it became the headquarters of various soldiers. Old Mr Phillips died in 1943 and Bernard’s Grandma moved to her eldest daughter’s hotel in Surrey. My mother-in-law Muriel was living in a half-converted barn directly adjoining the hotel, with her young family while her husband, George, was in the navy, participating in a very, very active war – on convoys, destroyers – in Italy and Africa, he finally ended up as a beach master during the D-Day landings, and was just getting kitted up to ship off to the Fqr East, when the war finally ended.

My mother-in-law, originally from London, was more or less marooned in Overy Staithe. Across

the road from the hotel was a large field of glebe land which had been rented by the hotel. It provided all the vegetables and most of the fruit for the hotel. She had to keep this garden as best as she could, and this included keeping a couple of pigs, plus chickens. Some of the meat had to go back to the government, but she was also expected to provide her mother-in-law and sisters-in-law with some of the meat and veggies as well, dispatching them by post (via the railway in Burnham). Throughout the war, George sent her letters talking about planting seasons, gardening hints, horticultural suggestions. Bernard remembered helping her rub salt into shoulders of pig in order to make ham...a painful task.

When the war ended, Old Mrs Phillips didn’t want to return, feeling that she was too old to carry on. The building had been completely wrecked by the occupying troops and there was no compensation. So, it was put on the market but failed to meet its £1000 reserve price. George, my father-in-law, had returned from war a weary and frail man. He decided that he would really like to join the river police. But, he was not tall enough to qualify. Someone recommended that he lie in bed for two weeks, and with a bit of luck he would stretch just that extra inch that he needed to qualify. Needless to say, this did not work. So, wearily, he decided to restore the hotel, room by room, which he did over a few years, chiefly aided by a local builder, Nelson Scoles.

It reopened with just a few rooms, in 1947 and gradually was restored. And, it soon attracted the same sorts of clientele as before the war, and the same accolades it had previously won. Although there was rationing and many of the privations common to war and post war England, there was still that magnificent vegetable garden. There was local game. Because the coastal waters had largely been out of bounds, there were plenty of fish and shellfish. Local beaches were gradually cleared of their mines, becoming once more accessible to the public. Once more, the hotel could revive its tradition of good food.

The hotel, like many of its kind, was a mini ‘Country House’. Early morning tea in one’s bedroom was followed by a lavish breakfast. Local bacon and sausages, mushroom, as well as bloaters from Wells, accompanied porridge or dried cereals. Toast from bread baked at Hewitt’s Bakery in Wells. Coffee and tea. Orange juice or grapefruit, the latter served looking intact, but really carved out of the carcass..

Elevenses consisted of tea or coffee, served with a simple bought biscuit. But, soon enough, the

brass gong would sound and lunch would be served in the large dining room directly overlooking the creek. There would be soup, usually an invention of my father-in-law, made up of leftovers from the previous day, picturesquely entitled - ‘Norfolk Soup’, Romany Soup’, ‘Game Broth’ .. whatever came to his mind while Muriel typed up the daily menu for the Roneograph printer. There were also cold first course. In season, Globe Artichokes, with vinaigrette, Asparagus on Toast, with melted butter, both grown in the garden – or quite exotic, then, Spaghetti with Tomato and Bacon sauce. Sometimes Dressed Crab was on the menu. The crabs arrived boiled, but not dressed and everyone working in the hotel assembled in the kitchen around the enormous table in the middle in order to prepare them. My sister-in-law Mary remembers a few occasions when there were not enough people in hand and she did 30 crabs all on her own.

These were simply served, dressed and back in their shells, with mayonnaise and a quarter of lemon. There were also cooked meat dishes, and on Fridays a cooked fish dish like sliced halibut with cheese sauce. And, of course, there was always a cold option: yesterday’s roast served with salad. There were also cooked vegetables, served alongside the potatoes. Puddings were often cooked ‘shapes’: semolina, tapioca, corn flour, served with stewed fruit or jam, or steamed suet sponges.

Tea was traditional but simple. Thinly sliced bread, cut into dainty sandwiches filled with cucumber, tomato or egg. Plain cakes, simple sponges or rock cakes and a few bought biscuits, and then there was a good break before the gong sounded around seven and supper was served. The food then was slightly fancier. Glorious fish: sometimes turbot, brill or sole, simply floured and then sauteed, served with a bit of flavoured butter (Maitre d’Hotel), followed by roasted partridges or pheasants, served with George’s inventive sauces, or chicken portions, baked or roasted with, again, inventive sauces and accompaniments.

Like most cooks, George had his own likes and dislikes. He loved vegetables but cooked them longer than they do nowadays – but the quality and freshness of them still shone through. He did not like garlic, though he did grow a couple of rows of it for a couple of years after the war, when the family housed a strange French lady who insisted on eating it raw for her health. His inventiveness really came out in his soups and sauces. And, his cooking skills were noticed in the early days of ‘The Good Food Guide’. It was in the second edition of that book that The Moorings appeared, continuing to feature until our family left.

Most of the main ingredients were fully traceable in origin. The meat came from Barkers, the Burnham Market butcher. Sundays, there were huge ribs of beef on the bone. George had been to a ‘carving school’ and was adept at handling the roasts, as was his eldest sister, Mary, who had sold her hotel in Surrey and joined him in the kitchen during the later years of the hotel. Mary was a good baker, and made meringues last thing at night, in a cooling electric oven which had been used during the main supper meal.

When the man smoking bloaters in Wells retired, Bernard went there for a couple of days in order to learn how they were done. He and his dad converted an outdoors loo up the garden, not far from the beehives, into a little smokehouse. Otherwise, fish came from Mr Farrow in Burnham: large turbot, cod and halibut. Large bowls filled with dabs or lemon soles.

Guinea fowl, partridges and pheasants came from Pettits of Reedham, who were also customers. Mrs Pettit made decorations from the feathers of their birds. Other fresh produce was delivered by wholesalers – milk coming from the local dairy in Burnham, who also delivered a rich and delicious cream cheese. Later on I mixed it with various fresh herbs, making a sort of Hungarian type of Liptauer cheese to be served along with the other cheeses, George would buy whole Stilton cheeses, often choosing one which had won prizes in various county shows (the Royal, the Royal Norfolk, and the East of England), He read about them in the EDP, then telephoned their makers. They were duly served in the large Victorian Stilton cheese dish, complete with its special knife, alongside other British cheeses.

Ice cream, made by a prize-winning Cambridge dairy, came by train and was picked up in Hunstanton. Wholesalers, including purveyors of fancy stuff like anchovies or special tinned fruits, came directly to the hotel as did the equivalent of a large cash-and-carry shop. There were no supermarkets then. Indeed when we suggested to Tim Aldiss, who owned a local department store, that a supermarket might be a very good idea, he replied that it would never go down well in England, particularly in Norfolk!

When we arrived in England, the hotel had only recently gained a liquor license. Bernard took over this. He read book after book about wine before starting a wine cellar using part of an outbuilding near the garages. He bought most of the wine from Peatling and Cawdron’s wine shop situated at the Globe in Wells. Some of those wines were stored for us in their vaulted cellar. Bernard and his dad also bid for some cases of special wines at specialist auctions. They constructed a small bar in one of the lounges which adjoined the dining room and I worked there before suppertime, trying my best to serve occasional cocktails (hastily looking them up in a booklet) as well as serving sherry and some aperatif style wines.

We found a house nearby and moved to Friars Lane, Burnham Norton in summer 1966. We moved there on the day that England won the World Cup. Bernard cycled to the hotel from Friars Lane where we lived and I stayed at home with our young children. Occasionally I made a few American-style puddings for the restaurant, but I was very busy indeed with our family, the house and the large (one acre) garden. It was then that my formation as a cook recommenced.

What was available in local shops was limited. No garlic. No peppers or aubergines. No chillies, yogurt, skimmed milk, soured cream. No un-dyed, smoked haddock or pickled herring. No fresh or frozen orange juice, The privations and frugality brought by war had diminished but the tastes of the general population had hardened. Even in a climate which is able to provide fresh vegetables virtually all during the year, the availability of some varieties had narrowed. And, there were few native English traditions of preserving vegetables. For instance, there is no local version of salting cabbage or turnips in order to make sauerkraut…

Here, I think I must familiarize you with a bit of my own background. I was born and raised in the USA. My parents were both immigrants from Russia, from families who regarded food as fuel. Their diets were both mostly plant based, designed to outlast temporary hardships. Porridge and hot cereals in the morning. Plenty of hearty vegetable soup, hot or cold, summer or winter. Bread designed to last a week to ten days, Pickled, cured, smoked and dried meat or fish. Dried mushrooms – all of these the mainstay of a Slavic diet.

Luckily, when we moved to Burnham, four times a week there were deliveries of old-fashioned bread. I could not abide the widely available tasteless fluffy commercial bread, found in many homes and shops. And I missed many mainstays of my New York style American diet, particularly various fermented milk products. Why couldn’t I find buttermilk, soured cream – or yogurt? During my first year living in Burnham Norton, I became ill with hepatitis. Because I could not digest fat, I wanted skimmed milk – not available then, except for a powdered dry skim milk which was imported from France. One early morning, on the farm programme, we listened to some farmers complaining that they could not sell enough milk. So we wrote and suggested that they try selling skimmed milk. Quick reply – there was no demand! When we asked about selling yogurt, the answer was the same. We sent away for some yogurt culture and began making our own…

The ethos behind the cuisine at the hotel had been one of luxury. Standards were high but appreciated. The staff working at the hotel were provided with good meals, however, they always insisted on chips rather than potatoes prepared any other way. These were cooked for them but not for the regular hotel guests, each meal.

Gradually, as I made friends and got to know my new neighbours, I became more familiar with their daily diet. We all used a local travelling butcher, Kenny Edge, from South Creake, who called once a week. When I asked him what he sold most of, he pointed to the stack of trays in his little van containing ‘pig’s fry’, that is, a mixture of offal, liver, kidneys, which was often the sole fresh meat

meal each week. The local diet would be supplemented by tinned meat (Fray Bentos and Spam), some tinned fish and the occasional fish and chips. There were travelling vans for that too. Local meals usually included fresh vegetables. For dessert, tinned fruits and some powdered ready-to-assemble puddings were popular. Pastries included sausage rolls and Norfolk Shortcake, the latter a pastry made with lard and flour, containing dots of more lard, sugar and dried fruit. Meals were accompanied with fruit squashes. Industrial sauces and jams were on hand as well as the ordinary squidgy fluffy bread.

My children by this time were at the local primary school along the road from where we lived. Even though the school dinners there were well conceived and prepared, many families prepared packed lunches for their children. These were often poor in nutrition, but preferred by the families. The school cook’s sensible way with vegetables {‘I just show the cabbage to the hot water’, she explained) were rejected. So, when my children held a birthday party, inviting their classmates, I would receive heartfelt pleas to provide sandwiches made with ‘shoppy’ bread and jam with plenty of fruit squash as an accompaniment.

Nevertheless, many local families had members who were ardent wildfowlers. Pigeon, rabbit, hare and of course, dubiously obtained pheasants and partridges formed part of many local family diets. Poaching, when I first moved to England, was more prevalent as the local trains which accessed \London would quickly ferry stuff down to the city. Nowadays, with pheasants being available so cheaply, this seems unimaginable. Then, there were weekly reports in the local newspaper of poachers appearing before the local magistrates.

There were also those who regularly gathered mussels, samphire and cockles. There had, over the years, been many public disagreements between authorities administering the marshes and coast over these gatherings. The uneasy balance between all these parties persists, though they all have a vested interest in preserving the coastal area.

The growing of vegetable crops became more industrialized, and ready-packed vegetables more common. There were many gangs of vegetable pickers, as well as seasonal fruit and soft fruit picker. On some farms there were travelling gangs for specialized crops, like asparagus. Some pickers were recruited locally, many of them housewives. Some of their gangmasters strutted around like cockerels…

The local diet included seasonings like mustard and horseradish. Mustard, grown locally, was dried by Colmans and sold in small tins in powdered form. It was dissolved, then left to stand for short while before being used. Horseradish, common enough, a weed with a deep, pungent root, was grated before being combined with vinegar, sugar, salt and cream. There were a few horseradish ‘kings’ who would bring their whole families to the coast to dig for horseradish along the coastline during the winter months, Finely grated, combined with vinegar, sugar, salt and cream, it was often available and sold in small jars on stands along the roads between Lynn and Wisbech.

Parsley and mint were commonly used garden herbs. Saffron, which once was common in these parts, was largely unknown, and has only recently been revived through the offices of Dr Sally Francis, a Burnham Norton girl.

It was not until the mid 1970s that different dairy products became available in some local shops. There were even some exotic vegetables: aubergines, peppers, courgettes, chillies. More fruit: mangoes and lychees. It’s hard to imagine that salami or Brie cheese were so exotic that it took a drive to Norwich to obtain them. When the first Leftley’s opened at the top of the High Street it seemed a boon and delight to be able to buy these things locally.

The shallow waters of our coast had been a great source of fishing for locals. Traditionally, dabs, a sort of flounder, were caught in the shallow creeks by walking around in the water with long rake-like forks with sharp prongs at the ends, which speared the fish as they swam in the shallows. \Well trimmed, then floured and fried, these were a popular local meal. Other fishing included laying out

nets along the beaches, which brought in sea trout, flounders, sea bass and grey mullet. There were also mackerel, dogfish, occasionally brill and sole. Most of these fish, and their fishermen, have largely disappeared now, and local yields consist of crabs, lobsters, shrimps and whelks.

Oysters are raised along the coast, in Brancaster and Morston, and mussels continue to thrive, with Frary’s in Wells the most recent mussel fishery to begin around here. Cockles, which once upon a time were gathered in Stiffkey are still there but not gathered at all. Instead they are dredged from the Wash industrially, then boiled and shelled. Alas, they are often gritty prepared this way. But the labour involved of walking a long way to the Stiffkey shoreline, then raking them up and carrying them home in a heavy sack to prepared them, makes this an unpopular job, Along the shores of this coast, there are some razor clams and the large, rather ugly clams, which are called, in America, Quahogs, but these are not commercial. Samphire has only gradually become a more commercial ‘crop’. For many years it was only picked by locals for family ‘feeds’. Nowadays a commercial picker will start in late June or early July, picking it along the Essex coast, gradually moving upwards through Suffolk and Norfolk as the season wear on, before finishing in late August along the Lincolnshire and Yorkshire marshes.

When I arrived, the meals at the hotel mirrored the food found at fancy country houses. Produce which is familiar today was absent. Local ordinary housewives, largely responsible for the diet in their own homes,, concentrated mainly on the familiar foods of their past. They were largely reluctant to try anything new, even though a lot of their food was adulterated. A widespread acceptance of many commercial farming practices did not benefit their diets, nor did some of the widespread overuse of chemicals, used both in feeding livestock and spraying on the land.

The hotel began to make good money in the 60s as a result of the licensing laws and the rise of tourism. However, when old Grandma Phillips died, this had not been the case. The nearly worthless shares in the hotel she had left to her sons. She left her three daughters a house each, so that my father-in-law had to buy the house he’d built and lived in, from his sister. The shares in the hotel, then without much value, were largely ignored by the family, until it began to prosper. Then, those in the family who had possessed the previously worthless shares began to take an interest. So, they received director’s fees. A few of them were not content and decided that they had been cheated. They had a majority of shares, and as a result, were able to take over the hotel. George and Muriel, sick at heart left The Moorings. And, Bernard lost his job.

George was ill, dying and unable to move into the house he had bought next to the friary ruins on Friars Lane, near where we lived. Bernard had to find a new job, so decided to return to Cambridge and do a one year’s teacher training course. By this time, we had four very young children. Left alone with them from Monday morning to Thursday, I had to learn to garden as well as cook while looking after the house and kids. So, I was were grateful for the school dinners which the older children enjoyed. Sadly, years later, when Mrs Thatcher’s government came to power, these dinners were cut back. Cooking equipment was removed, ready-meals offered instead. The school cook, Mrs Franklin left, but continued to prepare her lovely meals for the old folk’s club and Meals on Wheels. ‘Turkey Twizzlers’ were served at school and packed lunches, often not nourishing, became normalized. Farm work diminished. This might have some good effects – when we first moved to our house, there was an adjoining field where I could watch single farm worker, hoeing sugar beet. Starting very early in the morning, he would not have finished by the end of the day. This must have been hard and dispiriting work. By the time we moved to Wells this job was mechanized.

With the mechanization of farming, there were more second homes available. The predominant employment was provided by tourism. Many of the farm cottages, no longer required for agricultural workers, were transformed into holiday accommodation. Television cooking programmes had begun to widen the horizons of many local cooks and cumbersome, slow Baby Belling cookers had been replaced with equipment which was far more adaptable. Microwaves and freezers proliferated. Accessible supermarkets appeared,

By the time my children were teenagers, Bernard and I had started a monthly magazine devoted to

the life and issues of this particular part of Norfolk. Set in newspaper format, we had articles and news about most aspects of this area, except for food. Unable to find a cookery columnist for ‘The Paper’, I temporarily took on writing this column, using the name ‘Cocotte, which in French means a sort of casserole saucepan as well as a flirt. For a couple of years, I wrote columns concentrating on local, easily available ingredients, which were easy to prepare. I drew these from memories of Moorings Hotel meals, my own Slavic heritage, popular American recipes using some of those ingredients, and Bernard’s and my own memories of living and working in France for three years.

About this time, ‘The Sunday Times’ ran an annual cookery contest. Wondering if I could use some of our publication’s recipes for publicity, I submitted one, a cold crab dish made with local additions: samphire and brown shrimp. I got into the quarter finals and then ended up winning the prize itself. ‘The Sunday Times’ seemed slightly lukewarm about my winning. Previous victors lived in leafy Hampstead or high class parts of Cheshire. The paper described our kitchen as ‘family battered’ and mocked our habit lf occasionally eating ‘road kill’. But, with the prize money I was able to buy a car of my own, and publish a small book of my recipes, which sold out. We were given a new gas cooker, but as we couldn’t receive natural gas, it was a Calor gas stove. Our electricity bills were reduced by a third. I was also able to take on a few catering jobs, mostly freelance, then worked at Holkham’s Ancient House for Lord Leicester and Justin de Blank.

By then, momentous changes in education had begun. Bernard was was now head of English at a big high school in Kings Lynn. He felt swamped with the increasing paperwork and the burden of administration. He loved teaching but hated the rest of his job. He longed to return to catering. And so, we started to look for a place to have a restaurant. We had lived in France for three years and holidayed there with our children. We’d particularly loved little northern French seaside towns, with their modest, comfortable restaurants in every port. We went to Wells very often, whether for piano lessons, the library, the wine shop at Peatling and Cawdron, the children’s swing park or just to Leftley’s, which was the nearest delicatessen dealing in a wide choice of food. \We pictured a place near to the Quay, with the right ‘vibe’.

The cafe called ‘The Piscatorial Emporium’ fitted the bill. It was a dinky building, obviously Georgian. But, it was not for sale. Open only six weeks a year, this was satisfactory for the then owner. But, when in the winter of 1985 it became available, we decided to try and acquire it. Needless to say, no one would lend us the money, Bank managers baulked at lending money for a property which was surrounded by 180 degrees of water. Even with Bernard’s hotel experience and my proven cookery skills, the situation seemed discouraging. Then, some local friends who we knew, who had a holiday house in North Creake, offered to provide funding. They bought the building and lent us enough money to refurbish it. With a very tight budget, a very good local builder and enough resourcefulness to equip and decorate the restaurant, using second hand catering and furnishing equipment, making curtains and the table linen – all on a miniscule budget, we opened May 1986. We never looked back.

Of course, we couldn’t think of a name straight away. But when we asked Bernard’s mother, she wa to bes in charge of flowers – a key part, I’d always thought, of the old hotel’s charm, she said, conversationally, ‘Of course, you’ll call it ‘The Moorings’. Of course, indeed! Our culinary culture in the restaurant was a combination of our experiences, first of all the family traditions of using what was local and good. Next, the joint experiences of living and working in Paris, where I had

first learnt to cook, on often very primitive equipment. Student restaurants and domestic cooking, spurred on by Elizabeth David and Julia Child’s books as well as a French paperback primer. ‘Cuisine Pour Tous’ inspired us,.

My own Eastern European origins came in handy. The first time Bernard presented me with a kipper, I turned it into the Russian Salad I’d grown up with. My grandmother’s stuffed cabbage (which bombed when named as such, but became popular when renamed ‘Minced Venison wrapped in Savoy Cabbage leaves in a Sweet and Sour Sauce) was equally successful. \The easy availability of shellfish and my very American ways of preparing them, using cockles in chowder, or making crab cakes in many ways particular to their American locales: Louisiana, Baltimore, New England, meant that I was able to introduce new ways of eating familiar things. Bernard’s knowledge of smoking fish meant that we experimented, then produced, palatable smoked mussels.

We were close enough to the harbour for the local fishermen to find the way to our nack door. We told them to use the front door, especially if customers were there. We were able to get our vegetables directly from the field in Overy Staithe which had been used by the hotel. Local wildfowlers brought us a steady supply of pigeons. We had local venison, eggs from Overy Staithe and even a friend who supplied us, during all the time we were there, with quirky and wonderful ice cream.

Our suppliers became friends, as did many customers and most of our staff. Most of our children had the experience of working hard alongside us, which was of great benefit in their later life. But, the long hours and physical strain of standing in small spaces for hours on end was poor for our health. Bernard became very ill. We had to give up. Happily we were able to find a new home in this town which had truly supported us.

When we had settled into our new home on the High Street, ‘The Quay’, the Wells monthly magazine, was started. Bernard was its first editor. From its beginnings to the present I have continued to share my recipes in it – some from my catering past, others from my childhood, and some recently encountered, all using ingredients which are locally obtainable and which can be made at home using perfectly ordinary equipment. And so, the catering connections of the Phillips family continue on.

-Carla Phillips

OATMEAL COOKIES – THIN AND CRISP

For years I’ve been searching for a plain, large oatmeal biscuit, simply flavoured and with good lasting quality whenstored in a tin. This one is very pleasing, served with ice cream or stewed fruit, and it’s good on its own, served with a cup of coffee or tea, Easy to make, using the ‘all in one’ method, in a single mixing bowl, The batter spreads, so that the biscuits must be set well-apart on large-ish baking sheets, lined with Bakewell or greaseproof paper.

Ingredients: 140g plain flour; ¾ tsp baking powder; ½ tsp baking soda (bicarb); ½ tsp salt; 200g butter, at room temperature; 170g caster sugar; 40g light brown sugar; 1 egg; 1 tsp vanilla extract; 190g rolled oats.

Method: First, cream the butter and the sugars. Then, stir in the flour,baking powder, bicarb and salt. \then add in the egg, vanilla and last of all, the oats. With a tablespoon, form into little balls, and place,well apart on the baking sheets. Press them slightly in the middle, to about a ¾ inch thickness. Bake them in a hottish (290-200) oven for about 13 minutes. Cool then on the baking sheets before transferring them to a wire rack. Store in tins – almost indefinitely.

-Carla Phillips

ONION SOUP WITH APPLES, CIDER OR PERRY

This soup is a very English version of a French favourite, complete with the bread and cheese topping. Very local ingredients enhance it; cider or perry from Whin Hill, cheese from Mrs Temple. Apples are plentiful, the rest of the ingredients easy to find – so have a go!

Ingredients: 30g butter; 700g onions, quartered and sliced very thinly; 3-4 cloves of garlic, chopped; 2 cooking apples, peeled, cored, chopped; 1 heaping tablespoon of dark brown sugar; 1 tablespoon of cider vinegar; 400ml dry cider or perry; 100ml light soy sauce; 800ml vegetable stock; salt and pepper; slivered cheddar or ‘Alpine’ cheese; sliced and toasted bread – any sort.

Method: In a large saucepan, cook the onions together with the butter for a few minutes, and then add the garlic. Lightly dust these ingredients with salt, then add the chopped apples, and cover, reducing the heat. Cook until the onions are very soft, stirring occasionally, for about 20 minutes. Then raise the heat and stir in the brown sugar, cooking until the mixture is a caramel brown colour. Stir in the vinegar.

Now, reduce the heat and stir in the cider or perry, the soy sauce and the stock. Cover the pan, and simmer for abother 20 minutes. Season with pepper (and, if you think it is necessary, salt.

Toast the bread slices, and pile slivers of cheese onto them. Heat aa overhead grill, or turn up your oven to a high temperature, Place the soup in bowls or large mugs, then place a slice of toast with the cheese atop these, Place the bowls on Bking tray, and grill or bake at high temperature until the cheese has melted and just started to bubble. Serve at once.

-Carla Phillips

CRISP ONION ‘PIZZA’ SLICES

You don’t have to do much work making this recipe. But, you do need time, because this dough, containing yeast, needs to rise for a few hours. On the other hand, it is extremely cheap. Once made and cut into little squares or oblongs, it’s ready to be handed round with a drink or three.

Ingredients: 1 tsp dried yeast, 1 tblesp warm water; a pinch of sugar; 150g strong white flour; 50g brown (wholemeal) flour; 2 tblsp olive oil; 60ml water. For the topping: 600g onions, thinly sliced;2 tbls olive oil; a branch of thyme; salt and pepper; a little grated parmesan; dash of cayenne

Method: Add a small pinch of sugar to a tablespoon of warm water then soak the dried yeast in it. Leave five minutes, it should be slightly foamy. Then combine the two flours and salt. At the yeast mixture, the two tablespoons of olive oil and the water to the flour and knead the dough. If it seems dry and unyielding, add more water. All flours have different water content so it is hard to be precise. Now oil the dough lightly and place it in a bowl, cover with either film or a tea towel, then leave to rise for 1and ½ hours in a warmish place. Meanwhile make the topping. For this, heat up a large frying pan. Tip the sliced onions directly onto the hot, dry pan along with the thyme branch. Stir whilst they steam. When they are just starting to colour, add the olive oil, salt and pepper. Stir well, then lower the heat and allow the onions to cook until they are brown, caramelised, stirring occasionally. Then remove from the heat. When cool enough to handle, remove the thyme stem – the leaves will have blended in.

To bake, you need a couple of baking sheets or trays, or large pizza tins. You also need to preheat your oven to a very high temperature.

So, divide your dough. On a floured surface, roll it out very, very thinly. This dough is not at all ‘short’ so that you can be daring! Place each half of dough, thinly rolled out, on each of your baking sheets. Then divide up your onions and spread them lightly over each dough.. Finally, sprinkle with a little grated parmesan and a dash of cayenne and leave to rise for ½ hour.

Place them in a very hot oven for about 10-12 minutes. The edges should be quite brown. Remove from the oven, then allow to cool slightly. To cut, use a pizza wheel, sharp knife or kitchen scissors.

-Carla Phillips

PARSLEY PESTO REVISITED-2

We’re in the ‘Hungry Gap’, a period of time when relatively few local vegetables are readily available- except for the recent, glorious presence of asparagus. This is a time when there is a good presence of various brassica: kales, sprouting broccoli, cauliflowers. But our appetites can flag faced with these if we don’t occasionally titivate them somewhat, so I am reminding you of this Italian sauce which nicely complements these greens. You can cook these in an economical way. By putting the chopped greens into a boiling pot of water and pasta for the last 4-5 minutes of cooking, then draining it all together before immersing it in the ‘pesto’. This particular ‘winter pesto’ with easily obtained ingredients, should delight you, and if you’re only cooking the greens on their own, they will taste marvellous when strewn with this magical mixture.

Ingredients: 25g walnuts; 12g garlic, peeled; 50g grated parmesan;50 g parsley; 50ml olive oil; salt and pepper.

Method: Either in a food processor or stick blender crush the garlic, walnuts, parsley and parmesan together, then add the olive oil gradually. Season to taste. This will store in the fridge for a week or two.

-Carla Phillips

WINTER PESTO

Ordinary pesto is a sauce made with basil, garlic, pine nuts, olive oil and parmesan cheese. Often bought in jars, it’s handy on pasta. Outside the growing season for basil, this sauce, a winter ‘poesto’ comes into its own. In our restaurant, we spooned a little over a mixture of cooked broccoli and cauliflour. Nowadays, I serve it with pasta – it’s really popular with grandchildren – and continue to serve it with broccoli or sprouting broccoli, I slip the prepared broccoli into the boiling pasta for the last four minutes of its cooking time, saving, therefore on energy or additional saucepans.

Winter pasta’s proper name is ‘Salsa di Prezzamolo con Noci’ (this really brought out the red underlines on my computer) . As well as parsley, it calls for walnuts, which are a Fairtrade ingredient (it’s that time of year again). If you leave out the cheese, and store it covered with a fine coat of olive oil it will last quite a while in y our fridge.

Ingredients: 50g walnuts; 25g garlic; 100g parsley; 100g grated parmesan; 100ml olive oil; salt and pepper

Method: Either chop together by hand or process the garlic and parsley with some salt and pepper. Chop or grind the walnuts (or add to the processor) and blend all together. Trickle in the olive oil. Store this in a jar, in your fridge. If you wish, you can titivate it by adding a little cream when you serve it, but I don’t think this is really necessary.

-Carla Phillips

PATATAS BRAVOS

Good news! There’s now a wet fish shop on Staithe Street, and very fine it looks, too.

The shop became vacant when Jules Jackson of ‘Delish’ moved to a purpose built factory unit nearer Norwich, in order to make his bespoke pates and charcuterie for a wider public. (Much of his produce is now available at the terrific delicatessen further up Staithe Street).

Meanwhile, Arthur Howell’s fish shop looks splendid and has a good selection of fish and shellfish, including fish pie mixture and the crabs and lobsters caught and prepared by the Frary family. Later on the shop will be stocking the Frary’s mussels.

Occasionally they have truly locally caught fish, including my favourite grey mullet. Cherished and valued in Southern Italy and Greece, grey mullet are slightly scorned here.

Why? Caught in the same places frequented by bass and sea trout, these fish are not awkwardly boned, or difficult to deal with. Their nail-shell type scales are easily scraped off the fish with the back of a blunt table knife. There is a tad more oil in them than a common flatfish, but that only adds to the general juiciness of their taste.

Filleted, or if a large fish, steaked, they are relatively inexpensive. Dribbled with a little olive oil, well seasoned, with a herb or two added, they can be wrapped in foil, then roasted for approximately ten minutes. The following recipe for ‘Patatas Bravas’ is particularly nice served with simply prepared grey mullet – and cold, are equally harmonious.

Ingredients (for 2): 300g small potatoes – new or newish are best; 2-3 tablespoons of olive oil; 1 large clove of garlic, minced; 1-2 chillies, de-seeded and chopped; a pinch of dried cumin; a teaspoon of paprika; a red pepper, finely sliced; a tablespoon of vinegar; salt.

Method: Scrub the potatoes, place them in salted water and bring them to the boil. Boil for only ten minutes. Then drain them and cut them into chunks. Now heat a large frying pan. Pour in the olive oil and when it is hot, add the potatoes. Fry them turning occasionally, until they turn golden brown.

Meanwhile, crush the garlic, chillies, cumin and paprika together with the vinegar.(A processor or mortar and pestle are best for this). When the potatoes are brown, add this together with the sliced pepper and cook, stirring, for a couple of minutes. Salt the potatoes (Coarse salt is particularly nice for this) and serve. This is good hot, cold, or reheated!

-Carla Phillips

PEARL BARLEY SALAD

Easy to prepare, without the health risks entailed by presenting a rice salad at room temperature during warmish weather, this simple salad is a quick and decorative way to use up leftovers,

To cook pearl barley, boil 100g in about 600ml of lightly salted water. This takes around 30 minutes. Once it has swelled and been drained, it’s ready to handle.

Cut up cooked vegetables: peppers; sweet corn; beans (broad and green); courgettes; peas; carrots. Slice, into fine chunks, some solid little cherry tomatoes and a small portion of cucumber. Mix these well into the barley, then add plenty of greenery: parsley; mint; dill; chives. Mix it well, season, then add a lemony vinaigrette. Mix well again before decorating it with a final sprinkling of parsley.

This is a good accompaniment to cold leftovers, and can also accompany a simple green salad.

-Carla Phillips

PEARL BARLEY SALAD

Easy to cook and without the health risks entailed by presenting a rice salad at room temperature during warmish weather, this salad is a quick and tasty way to use up leftovers. Pearl barley is inexpensive and easily cooked. 100G in 600ml lightly salted water- then boiled around a half hour until the grains have swelled. Once drained, it is ready to handle.

Cut into small pieces bits of already cooked vegetables – beans (broad , green and runner), peas (I used frozen); cooked carrots, courgettes, peppers, sweet corn. Slice some small, firm cherry tomatoes into small bits, likewise, some cucumber. Mix these all into the barley, then add plenty of greenery: parsley; mint; dill; chives…

Now add a lemony vinaigrette, salt and pepper. Mix well, correct the seasoning, and if it seems slightly bland, add a drop more lemon juice, Finally, sprinkle with more parsley.

-Carla Phillips

“PETIT SUISSE “ ENGLISH STYLE

Living in France, many, many years ago, this was a delicious cream which was served with summer fruits: sliced strawberries, raspberries, gently softened and stewed apricots or plums...A dollop accompanied each portion of fruit. It was served at home, and also in restaurants. Even though it was widely sold in tiny packets it was simple to make at home. Once it is prepared, it will keep well covered and refrigerated for 3 or 4 days.

Ingredients: a small carton of ricotta cheese; a pinch of salt; 150ml of double cream; 2 0r 3 teaspoons of icing sugar.

Method: Mix the ricotta with the pinch of salt and the icing sugar. \add the cream and whip it all until stiff, Chill before serving it with the fruit.

-Carla Phillips

PICKLED “LOX”

This dish was my father’s favourite. Unfortunately, my mother disliked cooking oily fish so he had to go out to a local Russian Jewish ‘dairy’ restaurant in order to indulge. I accompanied him, so was introduced to salmon, which I now adore.

I tried to duplicate it for many years. But, on my last visit to New York a few years ago, I sampled the version sold by a very famous delicatessen. It wasn’t quite right, but I realised just what I needed to perfect my own version of this great Russian dish.

The ‘cooking’ is done through pickling – in vinegar, sugar and salt. It isn’t too light a pickle so that, like Gravlax, it will last for about a fortnight. Any sort of salmon: wild; farmed; organic, can be used. But it must be skinned, filleted and have the pin bones removed. If the fish monger or the attendant at the fish counter will not do this, just run your hand down the middle part of the fillet. The few protruding tiny bones, which you feel, are easily removed with tweezers.

This dish is ideal for parties. The given amount of pickling fluid will suffice, whether you are dealing with a half kilo of fish or three times as much. Only the amount of salt will vary. So, in order to make one of the most requested of my recipes, here goes!

Ingredients: ½ -1 ½ kg salmon fillet, cut into generous bite sized chunks; 2 rounded teaspoons (per ½ kg of fish) of salt; 2-3 tablespoons of sugar; 1 red onion, halved and thinly sliced into half-rounds; 1 large carrot, very thinly sliced. Use a potato peeler for this.; 1 teaspoon of pickling spice; 1 teaspoon of whole peppercorns; a handful or chopped fresh dill or a good sprinkling of freeze dried dill; ½ litre of good cider vinegar. Whin Hill from Wells is ideal.

Method: Put the chunks of salmon into a bowl and sprinkle the salt over them. Spread the chunks on a cake rack to air and dry slightly while you prepare the pickle.

Combine the vinegar, sugar, peppercorns and pickling spice with the sliced onion and carrot. Bring this to the boil, then reduce to a very gentle simmer for 15 minutes. Remove from the heat, pour into a cooler jug or bowl and cool this as quickly as you can, by plunging this container into a larger bowl full of cold water. When this liquid is quite tepid, distribute the salmon chunks into a wide, low dish which has a cover (plastic versions are readily obtainable). Pour the pickling fluid over the fish chunks, then add the dill. Cover and leave in your fridge for at least 48 hours. It is then ready, and, I hope you agree, truly delicious!

PINK SAUCE TRANSFORMED

Usually, I plan to make one or two things to tide me over a week: a soup or a vegetable casserole, perhaps a salad with varied ingredients, some cooked. When I am limited for time, or with lack of ambition, I simply supplement these with either a sandwich, baked potatoes or simple pasta, an omelette or something fishy or shell fishy, requiring no cooking. Thus, I am furnished with one decent meal each day.

If I have some prawns, peeled shrimp, crab, cold cooked fish, I know that there’s enough for a decent salad or sandwich. Accompanied by bright, light pink sauce, ‘Marie Rose’, It’s quite a treat.

That sauce can be quickly titivated into something grander. In New York Irish bars, when they serve prawns (or as they call them ‘shrimps’) they add a little bottled horseradish sauce to the mayonnaise-ketchup mixture. Very pleasant indeed!

But, experimenting with the tiny jar of ‘White Miso’ I bought last week at Tesco, I discovered something even better. To the standard sauce of one tablespoon of mayo to which I’ve added a single teaspoon of ketchup, I also added a single teaspoon of that miso. Now, miso is a Japanese condiment and the white variety is made from fermented bean curd. Other, darker misos are made from fermented rice or wheat. These are all particularly rich in ‘Umami’ - which means a savoury taste. Other examples include parmesan cheese, very well aged cheddar, Thai fish sauce, anchovy essence…. You may get an idea of what this adds up to.

Anyway, add a little miso to your pink sauce and it will be elevated to the food for the gods. Try it, and see what you think.

-Carla Phillips

PIZZA DOUGH

This is a mainstay of my cooking. It’s a dough which lasts, when wrapped in a plastic bag, for up to 3 weeks in the fridge. It has multiple uses, beyond pizza- a reasonable dough for quiches, and rolled thinly, a terrific wrapping for sausage rolls. It is not necessary, with this dough, to grease or oil the baking tin or sheet, It’s simple to prepare, and the result is tasty.

Ingredients: 7g dried yeast (1 teaspoon); 280g strong white flour; 70g strong brown flour; 10g salt; 50ml olive oil; water and a tiny pinch of sugar.

First of all, soak the yeast in 100ml of lightly warm, slightly sweetened water. Leave this for at least 10 minutes – it should be foamy. Then mix together the flours and salt, in a large bowl. Add the yeasty water to this and then, the olive oil. Add enough water to this to make a soft and pliable dough. Knead this together until it is smooth and flexible. If you have a dough hook on a mixer or a processor with a very strong motor, you can use this, but in any case, this shouldn’t take too long.

With oiled hands form the dough into a ball, place it in a clean bowl, and leave, covered with a tea towel or sheet of cling film, undisturbed for 2-3 hours, to rise. Then, knock it back. It is ready for use, either now, or stored in a plastic bad in the fridge. When you use it, roll it very, very thinly – if you are worried that it may split, it can be rolled over a large piece of clingfilm, and then placed on a baking sheet.

If you are using this dough for sausage rolls, brush it with a little beaten egg before filling the dough with sausage meat. Seal it and coat it with a little more beaten egg, and the outside will appear nicely glossy.

The thinner the dough is rolled, the crisper and finer the result. Top with your favourite pizza toppings, and bake in a very hot oven, for 10-15 minutes.

When used after being refrigerated, leave it to reach room temperature before topping or filling….

-Carla Phillips

THE DAY AFTER THE FEAST

I love the cold leftovers of the Christmas feast. There’s nothing so cheering as a plate or two of sliced up remains, a jar or two of homemade chutney or some sauce, perhaps a baked potato – and a salad or two to accompany it all. I have recently invented a sort of ‘slaw’, a mixture with oriental overtones which is totally suitable for these occasions.

It uses the Japanese mooli. That is the long white radish which is easily found nowadays. I’ve been buying them regularly from a Fakenham vegetable stall on market day, but wouldn’t be surprised to see them even more widely available. Not expensive, the mooli is long lasting, kept in the fridge. A slice or two will substitute for turnips in any casserole or soup. Sliced thinly and sauteed, they are delicious.

They’re good in stirfries. Grated or julienned they are wonderful in salads. As in this recipe.

The quantity given here is sufficient for 5-6 portions. It lasts for 4-5 days, refrigerated.

Ingredients: 100g mooli, grated or julienned; 100g carrots, roughly grated; 100g onion (preferably red, for appearance) very finely sliced; 70g red peppers, sliced into very fine slivers; a handful of fresh coriander; a handful of parsley, both finely chopped.

Dressing: The juice of 2 fresh limes; 1 tablespoon of sugar; 1 tablespoon of soy sauce; 1 chilli, deveined, deseeded and very finely minced; 100g mayonnaise; salt and pepper to taste.

Method: Combine the chopped vegetables and herbs and mix them sell. Then whisk together the dressing ingredients, and pour over the salad. Leave it to chill and mature in the fridge for a few hours before serving. It’s even better, the second day.

Happy Christmas!

-Carla Phillips

TWO RECIPES FOR THE NEXT COUPLE OF MONTHS

POTATO LATKE

This is what both of my grandmothers made with potatoes in the very early spring. They are not really at their best, but they can be made into nice, filling things. Known as ‘latkes’ or ‘latkas’, there are equivalent recipes all over eastern Europe. I’ve been making these a long, long time. So here’s a recipe which will serve one very, very hungry person or two ordinary souls.

For one very large potato, well scrubbed but unpeeled, you need half of a medium onion, one egg, salt and pepper and at least a heaping tablespoon of plain flour, as well as a little vegetable oil for frying.

First of all, grate the potato, skin and all. You can use either a fine or coarse grater for this; the effect is different, and the fine grater will give you a more ‘cakelike’ effect.

Anyway, grate the potato into a fine sieve, then manually squeeze out any excess fluid. Place it in a bowl, and grate the onion half, fine grater this time, into it. Mix them well together, season well with salt and pepper, then add the egg and stir. Last of all, add in the flour.

Heat the frying pan and coat it with a little oil. When this is very hot, dollop in tablespoons of the mixture. Allow to cook for several minutes, until brown, before turning it over to cook the other side.

These are delicious served with apple puree which has been slightly sweetened, then sharpened with a teaspoon or so of hot horseradish sauce. But you can also serve these simply with a fried egg, for a good and warming supper.

Carla Phillips

BEAN CURD

Bland, dead white, limp and almost jelly like, I never could see what bean curd (tofu) had to offer. However, one evening in a Chinese restaurant, I was served the traditional family favourite: Ma Po Bean Curd, as part of a feast and I had to eat my words. This is a spicy and comforting dish containing a very little minced beef, a few mushrooms and lots of Chinese seasonings and spices (it’s not hot, but very tasty). The bean curd stretches the other ingredients into a supremely successful classic dish. There are recipes for it in most Chinese cookbooks, and it really changed my mind.

After trying Hot and Sour soup, another Chinese dish, then some Thai curries- I’ve now decided that it’s versatile and when used with strong contrasting textures and tastes, is a fine thing to use. It’s widely available, even here in Wells as well as at Oriental groceries and food stalls. Here is a dish which is successful when hot or warm, but makes a tasty cold salad for following meals.

Ingredients: 1 packet of tofu; a tablespoon or so of cornflour, seasoned with salt and pepper; 1 red pepper, finely sliced into thin strips; 2-3 spring onions, sliced; vegetable oil for frying. For the sauce: the juice of 2 fresh limes; 1 or 2 chillies, finely chopped (seeds in or not, depending upon your taste); 2 chopped cloves of garlic; a walnut sized piece of ginger, peeled and finely grated;1 tablespoon of soy sauce; a handful of fresh coriander, chopped.

Method: Spread the seasoned cornflour on a flat dish. Unwrap the bean curd then drain it well on a couple of slices of kitchen towel before slicing it into squares. Heat up the oil (there should be about 2cm, ½ inch of it in the pan), then tip the floured curd into the hot oil. Wait until the curd is starting to colour up and crust slightly before turning in the hot fat. When they are coloured and crispish, remove from the heat, and drain on some more kitchen paper before turning into a bowl. Add the pepper slices to the hot fat, then the spring onions, and fry, brifly. Remove, then add to the bean curd. Now make the sauce by combining with garlic, chilli, and ginger with the lime juice and soy sauce. Toss this over the bean curd mixture, then throw in the coriander. Season well, then serve.

-Carla Phillips
