POTATO SALAD FRENCH STYLE

Newly wed, living and working in Paris in the early 1960’s, this was a treat from our local ‘charcuterie’. It was called ‘Salad Piemontaise’. Recently, looking up the name on the net, most French recipes call for slices or chunks of cooked ham, rather than tuna- so if that suits you, you can substitute one for the other; It is especially good when new potatoes are easily available.

Ingredients: 300g new potatoes; 30g finely chopped onion; 1 tin of tuna steak (preferably one in olive oil, though sunflower oil will do as well); 1 tablespoon of white wine vinegar; a tablespoon each of capers, chopped gherkins, chopped parsley and mayonnaise; salt and pepper.

Method: Scrub the potatoes well and immerse them in a saucepan with water to cover. If you wish, you can either add mint or a bay leaf. Salt the water, Cover the saucepan and bring it to the boil. |Cook until the potatoes are tender, then drain and leave to cool. Now chop the onion and combine it with the cooked potato, a little salt and the wine vinegar. Now add the tuna, its oil, and toss well. Add the capers, gherkins and then the mayonnaise. Taste – you may need a little more vinegar or mayonnaise. Season with salt and pepper and last of all add the chopped parsley.

You can add cooked cold vegetables to this: asparagus, green beans, peeled broad beans, even a little samphire. This is a good starter or lunch dish.

-Carla Phillips

POTATO SALADS

New potatoes are such a treat. Washed, scraped and then cooked till they are tender, they need very little adornment. The standard English manner of adding a few leaves of fresh mint to their cooking water is very successful.

If you are making a potato salad, it’s a good idea to marinate the freshly cooked, hot potatoes in a mixture of grated onion (about a dessertspoonful), along with salt, pepper and a tablespoonful or two of cider vinegar. Don’t drown the potatoes in this mixture. Just too then in enough of it for them to be lightly coated and then leave them to cool.

If you are serving them with many other sauced ingredients, you can simply dress them with a little olive oil and a few fresh herbs.

For a fully dressed potato salad, you can add a mixture of chopped capers and gherkins. Finally add a small amount of mayonnaise and a similar quantity of yoghurt. Finish them off with some chopped parsley, with or without some dill. This last salad is wonderful served with plain cold fish – smoked mackerel, cold salmon, or shellfish – or tinned tuna. A nice summery feast.

-Carla Phillips

TART AUX PRUNEAUX –PRUNE TART

This recipe kept coming up every time I looked up recipes typifying northern French cookery, whether in books or online. So, finally I decided to try it out before simply dismissing it out-of-hand. The pastry, made with yeast, is not especially rich and is surprisingly simple to make, even if, like most yeast pastry, it does take time. But it doesn’t require hard work.

This yeast pastry is widely used in northern France and Belgium, topped with all sorts of fresh fruit in season, then dusted with sugar and butter. But this popular combination struck me as unusual, inexpensive, rewarding.

It makes a large tart, so use either a large springform pan or a pizza tray or tin. It can be made very easily in a mixer or food processor but it’s quick and simple to do without any of these bits of machinery.

Ingredients: For the pastry: 1 packet of fast action yeast; 50ml milk; 240 g ‘strong’ flour; 1 egg, lightly beaten; 50g butter, melted; 50g sugar; pinch of cinnamon; pinch of salt. For the filling: 230g pitted prunes; 150ml water; 80g sugar; small bit of cinnamon stick (2 inches or 5cm); 1 tablespoon of brandy; 1 dessertspoon of extra sugar.

Method: First of all heat themilk gently in a small saucepan until it’s slightly warmer than body temperature. Remove from the heat, then stir in the yeast. Melt the butter and leave to cool slightly while you assemble the dry ingredients. Combine the flour, sugar, pinches of cinnamon and salt. {Place them in the bowl of the mixer or processor}. Combine the ‘wet’ ingredients – that is, the egg, milk and yeast, the butter, and then beat them into the flour. Keep on beating or mixing them until you have ball which sticks together. Knead this very briefly, then place the dough in a lightly oiled bowl, cover this with either a tea towel or cling film and leave for an hour in a warmish place.

Meanwhile, make the filling. Do this by combining the prunes, water, sugar and cinnamon stick in a small saucepan. Bring it to the boil and then simmer slowly until the prunes are very soft and most of the water has been absorbed. Then remove the cinnamon stick, either mash or blitz the prunes, and add the tablespoon of brandy.

After the dough has risen, lightly butter and flour your baking tin. Roll out the dough on a floured surface and then place it on the tin. Prick the dough all over with a fork, and leave it for another 20 minutes. Preheat your oven to a medium hot temperature. Dollop the puree onto the dough, then smooth it out leaving some plain pastry edging. Sprinkle the dessertspoon of sugar over this filling, then bake it for 20 minutes, until the edges are golden.

It’s served lukewarm, dusted with icing sugar, accompanied by crème fraiche.

-Carla Phillips

THAT ALL AMERICAN FAVOURITE

While pumpkins are used in this country for soup or a roasted vegetable medley, any American will proclaim them the Star of the Show at Thanksgiving. A favourite of mine, I think that the simplest Yankee recipe is the best; rich additions of cream, alcohol, boozy fruit doing no favours for this delicious pudding.

In the States, pumpkin usually comes in tins; here we have to start from scratch, with the raw pumpkin. So, split a smallish pumpkin (say, around a kilo) in half, scoop out the seeds and fibrous bits, and roast it in a very lightly oiled tin, flat side down, for 40-60 minutes in a moderate oven until the flesh is soft when prodded. Scoop out the flesh into a bowl.

Blind bake some shortcrust pastry in a 23cm(9 inch) pie dish. (I make a very short pastry using 160g flour, 100g butter and a pinch of salt. Refrigerate for an hour before rolling out.)

Now, for the pie filling: Ingredients: 350-425 g cooked pumpkin;2 eggs; 1 tin of evaporated milk (NOT the supersweet condensed milk); ½ teaspoon salt; 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon; ½ teaspoon ground ginger; ¼ teaspoon ground cloves; 170g caster sugar.

Method: Blitz together all these ingredients until smooth. Use a blender, processor or stick blender for speed. Pour into the baked pastry shell and bake in a moderate oven for 25 minutes, then lower the heat and bake for a further 10-15 minutes, until the pie filling has set. Serve either warm or cold, with thick or whipped cream.

If your pumpkin is large and watery, you may have to drain it in a colander for an hour or two before starting to use it. And if you have too much pumpkin, you can either refrigerate it for up to five days, then make another pie, or freeze it in batches. Or, you can simply stir plain cooked pumpkin into a leek and potato soup.Without altering the taste substantially,it will turn the most appetizing looking pale orange colour!

-Carla Phillips

PUMPKIN PIE

November is the month of that great American festival, Thanksgiving. No matter how many attempts are made to cheapen it with commercial nonsense, it manages to remain a great time of coming together with family and great friends, a happy feast, untainted (unlike Christmas, alas) of massive commercialism.

Like English Christmas, turkey is the dish of the day, though the ‘sides’ are different. Pumpkin Pie is the dessert of choice, My version is the most basic, most popular version of it all. Not containing alcohol, cream or anything exotic, it still seems to me to be the best recipe of all.

Start with a small pumpkin. Dense, less work, with more flavour, they are infinitely more useful than bigger ones which are fine for soup. Halve it, deseed it then bake it, face down in a hottish oven until soft and mushy. Remove it from the liquid (it’s an ooazer), and scoop the cooked flesh out of each half, and drain it, in a fine strainer, or any strainer lined with a clean J-cloth, to get rid of any excess fluid. Then, it’s ready for use – or for freezing, should you wish.

The rest is easy. Plain sailing.

Ingredients: a blind baked pastry crust. Use the deepest pie tin you have.; 400-430 g pumpkin flesh; 2 eggs, lightly beaten; 175 g sugar; ½ tsp salt; 1 tsp ground cinnamon; ½ tsp ground ginger; ¼ tsp ground cloves (a little pinch); 1 tin of evaporated milk. Oven temp- medium (350’).

Method: Mix the pumpkin and all other ingredients together, pour them into the pie shell and bake for 40-50 minutes, until a toothpick inserted into the middle comes up clean. Serve with cream or ice cream.

- Carla Phillips

CONIGLIO ALLA TOSCANA

My daughter-in-law (whose father is Tuscan) taught my son to cook rabbit in this simple and appealing way.

I can already sense the grumbles, disgruntlement of those whose lower lips tremble at the thought of eating Bunny Rabbit, and I’ve lived in the countryside long enough to remember the piteous signs of Myxi infected rabbits…but…

They are garden pests. They breed like- well, rabbits! They are very available, cheap, wild, probably organic, lean, and small enough to do nicely for a couple of meals for two. And this dish, when cold, that is- leftover, is really delectable, accompanied by bread and a simple green salad. Hot, I recommend serving it with mash and one of the slightly bitter brassicas: sprouting broccoli or calabrese.

Ingredients: A rabbit, cut up into joints; 1-2 tablespoons of olive oil; a handful of rosemary; 2 cloves of garlic,peeled then cut in half; 2 glasses of vermouth or other dry white wine; salt and pepper.

Method: Use either a heavy lidded casserole or start with a frying pan, then transfer the contents to a lidded baking casserole. First heat the olive oil. Soften the cut cloves of garlic in the hot oil and when they start to brown, remove them. Add the rabbit pieces, frying them until they are coloured but not brown. Season well with salt and pepper. Then add the rosemary and both glasses of vermouth. Bring it to the boil, then either cover the casserole and simmer it at a low temperature covered for and hour and a half to two hours, or place it in a low oven for the same time. Last of all, remove the rabbit pieces to a serving dish while you furiously boil down to remaining juices to thicken the sauce somewhat (this should not take more than 5 minutes). Check the seasoning before serving.

-Carla Phillips

RED CABBAGE WITH CORIANDER

Before she worked for us, Jane, my helper in our restaurant, spent ten years in Cyprus. This recipe , which she got from her landlady, became a staple which we served throughout a great deal of the year. We substituted cider and cider vinegar for the white wine which her landlady had used, as it was local and cheaper, and to my mind, just as good. The dish takes a bit of time to assemble, but not much physical effort and is even better, reheated on the second day.

Ingredients: ½ of a medium sized red cabbage, shredded; 1 large finely sliced onion; 1 tablsp olive oil; 1 tblsp coriander seeds, crushed ( whacked while contained in a paper bag); a wineglass of dry cider; a wineglass of cider vinegar; 2-3 tablsp brown sugar; 1 cooking apple, finely chopped; 2 tsp sultanas; salt and pepper.

Method: Heat up a heavy-bottomed saucepan, and add the olive oil. Sweat the shredded cabbage and the onions in it, stirring, for about five minutes. Then add the crushed coriander into the mix, stirring it in, and cooking it for a few minutes. Now, add the cider and the cider vinegar. Stir it well, reducing the cooking liquid slightly, and then add the sugar, chopped apple. Sultanas, salt and pepper.. Cook this, stirring occasionally for at least a quarter of an hour, possibly longer if the cabbage seems tough. Correct the seasoning to suit yourself, adding more vinegar, salt, sugar, etc to suit your taste.

This is good as an added vegetable for a main meal, but is also a great accompaniment to sausage, bacon or a pork chop, or simply served on its own with simple boiled potatoes and a little hot mustard.

-Carla Phillips

RUSSIAN BORSCHT (Vegetarian)

Ingredients

2 bunches of beetroot, complete with leaves and stems, all chopped.

2 large onions, chopped.

2 cloves of garlic, crushed

1 large potato, peeled and chopped

1 large cooking apple, peeled and chopped

2 large carrots, diced

3 blades of celery, finely chopped

1 tin of tomatoes

1 turnip, chopped

2-3 tablespoons of butter

1 tablespoon of oil

3 tablespoons of sugar

Juice of 1 lemon

2 tablespoons of cider vinegar

Parsley stalks (as many as you can get)

A small pinch (1/2 teaspoon ) of cumin

A good handful of chopped fresh dill

Optional a few mushrooms, finely sliced.

Vegetable stock or vegetable stock powder and water

Salt and pepper

To serve: Soured cream, chopped fresh dill

Method

Heat the butter and oil and sauté the onions till they soften.

Add the potato, beetroot and garlic and continue to soften.

Add the apple, carrots, celery, tomatoes, turnip and mushrooms.

Cover, lower heat, cook for ten minutes, then add the veg. stock, water to cover, parsley stalks, cumin, sugar, lemon juice, vinegar, dill.

Cover, simmer for 20 minutes or until veg are tender.

Pulverise or magi.

Correct the seasoning. Add salt, pepper and, if needed, either sugar or cider vinegar.

Reheat, serve with soured cream, sprigs of dill.

SALMON OR SEA TROUT, A LOVELY SAUCE

I can’t remember where or when in the wilds of my past I first tried out this fine accompaniment for sea trout or salmon. This is easily made, requiring almost no cooking at all as it is a simple assemblage of readily available ingredients. It can be served with hot fish, or cooled down, with a large cooked salmon or sea trout, which makes it an ideal companion if you’re cooking a big fish for a feast.

However, served simply with cooked steaks or slices of fillet, together with simple steamed new potatoes and some slightly astringent and green broccoli, sprouting broccoli or calabrese – Well! Find me something better! I dare you!

As for cooking salmon or sea trout – it’s always a matter of not overcooking your fish to the point of dryness. If the fish is to be served as steaks or slices, I salt it ten minutes before cooking, sprinkle it with a little parsley, then steam it for a very few minutes, leaving it to ‘rest’ and finish cooking as soon as it has changed colour. But if it’s a big fish, wrapping it in foil may be fine, or cooking it in a fish kettle, or even using the microwave. If it’s fresh and fine, you can’t go wrong. So, here’s the recipe for the sauce.

Method: Combine all these in a saucepan and leave to stand 15 minutes. Then heat this gently, briefly (otherwise it will curdle and separate), Serve, warm or cold with your cooked fish.

SALTEDCARAMEL ICE CREAM – A SIMPLE RECIPE

This is a terribly easy way to quickly make this popular treat for hot weather. A variation made with the caramel condensed milk which is widely available, it has a nice texture and taste but takes little time to prepare/

Ingredients: 1 tin of caramel condensed milk; 300ml double cream; 1 tablsp vanilla essence; ½ tsp salt.

Method: Combine the condensed milk and the cream in a bowl and whip it until there are reasonable peaks. Now add the salt and vanilla, beating well. Pour it into one or two containers and freeze it, for at least 6-7 hours (or overnight).

This may not have the fine texture and refined richness of a classically made ice cream, but it will do pretty well!

-Carla Phillips

Samphire with Green Sauce

July and early August are the best times for samphire, which grows profusely along our coastline, part of a chain of plants which attach the salty earth to the tidal mud. It’s on sale at fish shops, as well as at our beloved seafood stall on the quay, run by the Frary family.

The beautiful samphire you buy from the Frarys has been well washed, but if you do pick some yourself, try not to uproot too much of it because the roots are fulfilling a valuable ecological function. It must be washed very thoroughly to remove any mud, then either placed in the basket of a steamer or stood, roots side down, asparagus fashion, in a few inches of boiling water. Cover and cook briskly for at least seven minutes. Later in the season, it will need more time.

To test if it is done, pull a strand from the pot, run it under cold water then see if the green flesh slips easily away from its stringy stalk.

If done, remove from the heat and immerse briefly in cold water to prevent further cooking.

For easy eating, detach all the green flesh from the stalks. It should look like a brilliant green sort of pasta which drapes dramatically wherever it is laid.

I love to serve it with the following sauce which is also superb with asparagus, globe artichokes, green bans, any left-over veg and hard-boiled eggs.

INGREDIENTS

70-100g of spinach or chard leaves. The “sea spinach” which can be picked locally is very good, but wash it well!

2/3 spring onions.

1 tablespoon of wine vinegar

A handful of green herbs: parsley, fennel (wild if you can find it locally), dill, chervil, tarragon – as many of these as you can find.

Two egg yolks

300-400g sunflower or ground nut oil

Salt and pepper

METHOD

Pour boiling water over the spinach. Drain well, then squeeze it dry. Combine it with the herbs, vinegar, spring onions and egg yolks in a blender. Blend well, gradually adding the oil until you have a rich, brilliantly green sauce. Season to taste – but remember that the samphire is already naturally salty!

GLORIOUS SPRING

New green foliage, blossom everywhere, a little more warmth – and as a bonus, the first of the new season’s vegetables are here. Whether it’s asparagus, carrots, the first new potatoes, early broad beans – simply done, with the addition of eggs, a little poached or steamed fish or chicken – are a great feast. Now, here’s a nicely savoury sauce to serve as an accompaniment.

I’m not at all sure what it is called. I’ve heard it referred to as ‘sauce vierge’ or ‘sauce provencale’ but a little research into Escoffier and other authorities hasn’t enlightened me any further. But it is delicious as a dipping or spooning sauce, and is easily prepared from readily available ingredients. It’s a sort of warm mayonnaise, and a bit like a hollandaise, using olive oil instead of melted butter. Once made, keep it barely warm in a bowl over but not immersed in hot water.

Ingredients: 1 crushed clove of garlic; 1 finely minced shallot; 1 small gherkins, very finely minced; a small handful of chopped parsley; 2 teaspoons of drained capers, chopped if large; 1 chilli, de-seeded, deveined and very finely chopped; 3-4 olives finely mashed; 3 anchovies, mashed; 2 egg yolks; 1 tablespoon of white wine vinegar; a teacup of olive oil; a little ground black pepper.

Method: Combine the egg yolk and vinegar with all the ingredients except the olive oil. Then, in either the top of a double saucepan or in ma heavy small saucepan over a very, very low flame, stir these together and gradually add the olive oil, mayonnaise fashion, stirring well, until the sauce starts to thicken. Remove from the heat, lest it split. Keep it just warm, and serve, in dollops with the fresh new vegetables, simply prepared, and anything else you choose to serve along with it.

-Carla Phillips

AN ITALIAN VARIATION

Some years ago I was part of a large crowd dining at a New York Pizzeria. While we all studied the menu, choosing variations which would please everyone present, we were brought a large plateful of these Italian sausage rolls.

They were delicious. The filling, savoury, herbed, slightly hot. The pastry, leftover

pizza dough, not at all stodgy. When I returned home to Norfolk, I spent some time making my own version. So here it is- fine when hot with drinks or tea and fine, cold, for picnics.

Please don’t be intimidated by pastry made with yeast. Modern powdered yeast, widely available, makes this all an easy and trouble free procedure.

Ingredients: 225g strong flour; 75g wholemeal flour; 1 teaspoon salt; 1 packet instant yeast; 2 tablespoons olive oil; water.

Method: In a food processor, combine the flours, salt and yeast. Add the olive oil, then while whizzing it add enough water to form into a ball of dough. Continue to mix until it’s smooth and malleable. Place this dough in a lightly oiled bowl, turning it round to grease the whole surface. Then cover it with either a damp towel or clingfilm.Leave to rise for at least an hour and a half.

For the sausage filling- Ingredients:1/2kg sausage meat; 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds; 1 clove of garlic; ½ teaspoon of oregano; 1 chilli, deveined and deseeded.

Method: Combine the ingredients in a food processor. Form into long, skinny ‘chipolata’ sized sausage shapes and leave in the fridge till you’re ready to use them.

When the pastry has doubled in size, knock it down. For ease of handling, divide it into quarters or thirds. On a cool, floured surface, roll out one of these dough sections, rolling as thinly as you can. This dough is infinitely more elastic than shortcrust or puff pastry, so be bold!

Place one of the segments of sausage on the pastry and form it into a sausage roll, ‘glueing’ it together by pressing the dough firmly. Pinch the dough at the ends together, cut it, then place with the joined edge downwards on a baking sheet. Repeat until you’ve used up all your sausage meat. If you have any dough left over at the end, you can use it for a bonus pizza- wrapped in clingfilm, the dough will be fine in the fridge for a week.

Prick the pastry all over with a fork, leave to rise for 15-20 minutes, then bake in a very hot oven for 15 minutes, until golden brown. When they’re cooked, slice into serving sized segments.

LITTLE SAVOURY PASTIES

Having a drink, without something to eat, strikes me as unpleasant. And sometimes, it’s necessary to produce something bite-sized which will either serve as an hors d’oeuvre or a light meal.

These little pastries are something I’ve made for years. They are cook-friendly, can be made ahead of time, then rewarmed for ten minutes in a low oven. They can also be pre-prepared , left in the fridge then baked for twenty minutes in a very hot oven.

Originally, I rolled out puff pastry then stamped circles which I filled and fashioned into half moons. Nowadays, I roll out the pastry thinly into a good-sized square and cut it into 3 inch (7cm) squares, then turn into filled triangles. Much less work!

Ingredients: 1 packet of puff pastry. If you can get the sort that is made with butter, it’s nicer, otherwise the ordinary one will do.;3 large or 4 small eggs; 2 tablespoons of cream; a tablespoon of butter; salt and pepper; 2 or 3 slices of smoked salmon.

Method: Break the eggs into a bowl and whisk lightly. With a tablespoon, extract a tablespoon of the beaten egg and place in a small bowl with the same amount of milk or water. This will be enough for sealing and glazing the pastries.

Heat the butter in a saucepan or small frying pan. Add the eggs and cream, stirring gently till it is a thick creamy curd. Immediately pace this in a cold bowl to prevent further cooking and add chopped snippets of the smoked salmon. Stir to blend.

On a lightly floured surface roll out the puff pastry as thin as you dare. Cut into squares. Brush the edges of these squares lightly with egg wash. Place teaspoons of the filling in one corner of each square, then fold over to form triangles. Press with a fork to seal. Place the triangles on a Bakewell- paper lined pastry sheet. Brush the tops with the egg wash.

Now, chill them until 20 minutes before you are ready to bake them in a very hot oven, prior to serving. They should be a warm golden brown. They can rest in a gently warm oven, or, as said before, gently reheated .

SHRIMP SOUP

The little seaside stalls along our coast feature local delicacies: crabs, lobsters, little cupfuls of washed cockles, musses, whelks and winkles, brown and white shrimp.

I particularly like the small shrimp. They’re landed locally, fished off the Wash, boiled at sea in seawater with additional salt. This gives them their salty but satisfying savour.

Of course, it’s nice to eat them as is – breaking off the heads, then rapidly peeling off their shells. If there’s a fine black line of roe lining them, this is easily wiped off. I know it’s a fiddly job.But these little shrimp are the business as far as taste is concerned.

Now, if you’re willing to by a cupful without devouring them on the spot, try using a saucepan as a receptacle for their leavings. Then, you'’e well on your way to preparing a soup fit for the Gods.

Once you have your saucepan of shrimp debris, and have refrigerated the edible fleshy bits, add to your saucepan a chopped up carrot, onion, celery blade, parsley stalk and a few peppercorns, along with a couple of teaspoons of tomato puree and a full glass of white wine. Any sort of white wine, and in a pinch, dry fine cider would do. Last of all, cover well with water (about 3 inches to spare on top of the solids). Bring to the boil, the reduce to a simmer (or leave in a gentle oven) for slightly longer than an hour.

Next, strain the stock through a fine sieve. If you like you can chill and freeze the stock for a super sauce for a fish dish or pie. But for my soup, add a couple of tablespoons of Marsala, Sweet Sherry or Madeira, then bring back to the boil. Last of all add a couple of tablespoons of cream – any sort – and add the peeled shrimp.

Serve with warm buttery rolls and you’ll never want for anything more refined!

-Carla Phillips

pSMOKED HADDOCK ‘SURPRISE’

This is such an excellent dish -easy to assemble with readily available ingredients. Served with mash, a dark green vegetable (broccoli?, calabrese?), it’s an elegant and simple dish to present to friends, as well as the two portions presented in this recipe.

Ingredients: approximately 400ml whole milk (2 teacups); 1 shallot, sliced; 1 bay leaf, a few stalks of parsley; 3 peppercorns; 2 serving portions of smoked haddock (I prefer undyed); 70g strong cheddar, grated; 5 or 6 cherry tomatoes, halved; a handful of breadcrumbs; a little butter; a small amount of cayenne and paprika.

Method: Heat the milk with the peppercorns, shallot; parsley stalks and bay leaf. When it has begun to simmer, remove from the heat and allow it to stand. Butter a baking dish large enough to contain the fish fillets, and place them in it .Cover them with the cheese, then with the sliced tomatoes. Rewarm the milk, then strain it on to the fish-cheese-tomato mixture. Dot the top with the breadcrumbs, a few sprinkles of cayenne and paprika, then bake it in a hot oven for 20 minutes. Leave it to stand for 5 minutes before serving with the potatoes and veggies.

Bon appetit!

-Carla Phillips

SMOKED MACKEREL SALAD

This is an adaptation of a salad, dip or sandwich spread popular in New York delis when I was growing up there. It was usually made with a smoked oily fish from the Great Lakes which was called ‘whitefish’; I’m not sure that this was the proper name. I used to make this out of smoked grey mullet fillets (we smoked this ourselves) but have found that commonly sold smoked mackerel, used in slightly more modest quantities, is a delicious substitute.

If the salad is all hand chopped, it’s very presentable as a salad. Otherwise, blitz it in a food processor. Then it will serve as a great spread or dip as well as a slightly smoother salad.

To give this recipe some ‘oomph’ you must use some chilli sauce to add a bit of warmth. Thai Sweet Chili Sauce won’t do for this. It’s too sweet. Use one of the commonly sold Mexican types (I use the widely available ‘Cholula’); or, in a pinch, Tabasco.

Ingredients: 250g smoked mackerel fillets; 3 blades of celery, finely chopped; 3-4 shallots, finely minced; 1 red or green pepper, very finely chopped; a handful of fresh parsley, chopped; 2-3 tablespoons of mayonnaise; a dash of ground black pepper; 1-2 teaspoons of chilli sauce.

Method: Remove the skin and any stray bones from the fish fillets and shred them. Combine with the other ingredients. For a finer texture, blitz the lot together, adding the seasonings to taste. Leave to stand for at least an hour to allow the flavours to knit together. Serve with toast or brown bread.

This is a perfect post-holiday anecdote for a surfeit of meat.

-Carla Phillips

SMOKED MUSSELS

The last fish smokery in Wells-next-the-Sea closed down in the mid 1960’s and my father-in-law, George Phillips regarded this as a disaster. How would he supply delicious local bloaters for Sunday breakfasts for his customers at The Moorings Hotel in Burnham Overy Staithe?

His local fishmonger promised him a steady supply of herrings. So he appointed his son Bernard (my late husband) , his assistant at the hotel, as the new chief smoker. Bernard, a literary fellow, borrowed a book on the subject from the library and started straightaway, using an old abandoned brick outhouse opposite the hotel entrance, across the road, in the vegetable garden.

First try, the fire was too strong, there was too much sawdust and all the fish fell down. Second time, it took too long and the fish seemed hard and tasted too strong. Meanwhile, Bernard stank of smoked fish and was obliged to bathe frequently in order to rid himself of the smell before serving the evening aperitifs,

But he did master the process in very little time, and years after he had left the hotel, we always had a simple home smokery, albeit reduced in scale. Years later, when we started our restaurant, The Moorings, in Wells, we used an old disused electric cooker. In the bottom of its oven, we set a small metal tray containing sawdust. Above,on a rack, we placed the stuff we wished to smoke.This cooker was located in the back alley of the restaurant until it fell to bits. So then we used a large aluminium oriental steamer. The bottom was seriously holed. Into this, we placed an ancient enamel tray containing the sawdust. We placed a small wire rack containing whatever we wished to smoke on top of the first level of the steamer before using the lid to contain the smoke. This worked like a dream.

I’m telling you this so that so can improvise your own smoker in order to reproduce the wonderful smoked mussels which Bernard continued to provide until he became too ill.

It’s simple indeed if you can sort out a smoker and find mussels of the calibre we get in Wells, or on the Norfolk coast. It’s best to do this out-of-doors, even if it’s a city balcony or an alley, but even a fireplace might be good enough to remove any smoky fumes.

First of all, open your cleaned mussels in a very little water to which you’ve added a heaping tablespoon of salt. When the mussels are just open, remove from the shells and place them upon a wire rack on the tray of your smoker. Sort out the ‘working part’ of the smoker by lighting up a good handful of hard wood sawdust (there are many good sources for these – woodturners, Treen makers, other smokeries…use your ingenuity. Place the tray over the smouldering sawdust, cover the lot, and smoke for 40 minutes. And that is all there is to it.

These mussels are delicious served with a lemony garlic mayonnaise. Or without!

-Carla Phillips

MEAL IN A HURRY AT HOLIDAY TIME

Beside the great set piece meals of Christmas there are numerous meals to prepare when you are in a hurry, the number of diners seem slightly fluid and the will to cook is low.

A small packet of that lovely hot kiln-smoked salmon from the new shop in Staithe Street may hold the solution to your problems in these troublesome times.

You can serve this fish, chopped or crumbled, over scrambled eggs. It’s fine shredded over baked potatoes, served with freshly ground black pepper and a dollop of either crème fraiche or soured cream.

Another dish, very elegant and simple, is to shred a tablespoon of it per person into a tablespoon of cream. Any sort of cream: fraiche, whipping, soured, double- will do. While this is soaking, cook some tagliatelli, 80-100g per person. When the noodles are cooked, drain and dress them with a small knob of butter. Then stir in the smoked salmon-cream mixture and add some freshly ground pepper or a dot or two of cayenne.

Voila! Supper is served.

SOUR DOUGH BREAD – NEW VERSION

This is the sour dough I am currently making, with all the bells and whistles I have added over the past year. I am not giving a recipe for a starter, as they are widely available; jars of them lingering in many people’s fridges-- I am certainly willing to share mine, as starters are easily divided and brought up to a usable amount by simply adding a couple of tablespoons of flour and enough water to bring it up to a creamy consistency, then leaving it at room temperature overnight..Starter will store well in the fridge, if occasionally renewed by being fed.

The process of making this wonderful bread takes time, but very little physical effort. And the result is so delicious, and keeps quite well so that it is very worthwhile.

Ingredients: The sour dough starter (you’ll only need a large tablespoon of it – say 50-60g); strong white bread flour – either 500 g, or 450g strong white and 50g of rye or whole wheat flour; 10g salt; 350ml water; a little ground rice (for dusting the final bowl containing the last proving).

Two medium to large bowls and a heavy-ish casserole with a lid for baking it – a Dutch oven or LeCreuset type casserole should do.

1. The night before starting, remove your jar of starter from the fridge. Add a large tablespoon of flour and enough water so that when you stir, it has the consistency of thick cream. Cover the jar and leave it at room temperature until the next day.

2. Next day, weigh out the flour(s) into a large bowl. Stir in the salt and then all the 350ml of water. Mix briefly and roughly, then cover the bowl with a plastic bag and leave it for an hour.

3. Now, remove the covering, and add the sourdough starter (50-60g}. Mix this in roughly and rapidly, then cover it all with the plastic bag. Leave it for another hour.

4. Now, remove the plastic bag once more. Very gently, pick up a small strand of dough from the side of the bowl. Stretching it gently, pull this over the top of the dough – as though you were wrapping a parcel. Rotate the bowl slightly, then lift another segment of the dough, then stretch it and fold it over. Repeat this stretch and fold movement 23 more times. You should have been round the bowl, - and then some! This is the most demanding physical effort you will be required to do! Now, cover the bowl once more, and leave it for two hours. But, during this time, repeat the dough folding and stretching- only 8-10 times a session. After the last session, cover the bowl well and leave it for a long time (8-10 hours). The dough should be more than double the size when you look at it. Finally, stretch, pull and fold the dough briefly and lightly – you want to keep those bubbles you’ve made!

5. Now, find another bowl which you can use for the final rising. Rinse or spray this bowl with water. Dust the whole of the interior with ground rice .Gently place this last bit of folded dough into the bowl. Make sure that the top of the dough has also been covered by sprinkling it with the ground rice. This prevents the loaf from sticking to the bottom of its baking pot and will make it easy to slide the dough into its final destination when baked. Very gently, slide the dough into this well sprinkled bowl, Cover it with the plastic bag and refrigerate it overnight, really anything between 7 and 22 hours.

6. Preheat your oven to hot (400’ plus). Line your cooking pot or casserole with a piece of parchment or Bakewell paper on the bottom. Remove the dough from the fridge and gently transfer it into the pot. The ground rice makes it easy to tip out when baked. Spray the inside lid with water- and bake 50-60 minutes. Remove from the oven, cool on a rack and don’t break into it until cold!

Carla Phillips

SOURDOUGH BREAD – UPDATE

STARTER – Essentially a mixture of flour and water which has fermented enough to contain wild yeasts, this mixture keeps very well, refrigerated in a jar, for about a month or so. However it separates, into a solid sort of mixture on the bottom, and a greyish clear mixture on top. The grey top is of no use – it’s real name is ‘gunk’; it should be discarded, by pouring off down the drain, and more flour and tap water added. To ‘grow’ more starter in a hurry, simply discard the ‘gunk’, add flour and water, in a consistency which resembles cream, and leave the covered jar out at room temperature.

When you use starter, replace what you have used simply by adding strong flour (white, rye, etc) and water. After several hours, if the liquid smells pleasant, slightly fermented, almost cider like – all is well!

THE LOAF- It take a great deal of time, but not much effort. So, start earlyish, the day before you require the bread, if you want to be sure of getting a nicely risen loaf.

Begin by making your ‘sponge’. For a good sized loaf (you can halve all these ingredients if you want a smaller loaf of bread), weigh 200g starter, 200g warm water and 300g of strong flour and mix these together well. You can also add a pinch of vitamin C (available in beer-brewing sections at the chemist) which is one ‘improver’ which is useful and non toxic, Stir it well, cover the bowl with a tea towel of cling film and leave it to stand for at least 4 or 5 hours.

Next go – and add 200g of warm water to the ‘sponge’. Stir it well, then add 500g of flour – and here you can mix up your flours if you like. I usually add some rye and whole wheat flour to strong white- too much brown makes for a heavy loaf, and too little doesn’t taste as interesting. Time for experimentation. Also add 2 teaspoons of salt to the mixture and knead it into a loaf, very briefly. Place this loaf back in its bowl and leave it, lightly covered, for 10 minutes. Now, lihgtly oil a flat surface, and knead the loaf, very briefly, for 10 seconds. (Count –‘One potato, two potato, etc…’). Replace the loaf in the bowl, and repeat this brief kneading at 10 minute intervals two more times.

Finally mould the loaf into a nice round shape, by first stretching it into a rectangle and then rolling it up, and placing it seam side down on a floured baking sheet.

Leave this overnight.

Next day, criss-cross the top of the loaf by slashing it with a razor blade or Stanley-knife blade. Heat your over to a high temperature. When ready to bake, spray it with water (use one of those little plastic spritzer bottles which you can get almost anywhere). Cover the loaf with a large, round metal or ceramic bowl ….possibly a dog’s water bowl. Place this all: tray, loaf, covering bowl – in the oven and bake for about 30 minutes. Then remove the bowl, and continue to bake the loaf until it is browning nicely, crisp, and has a slightly hollow sound when tapped lightly.

Turn the loaf onto a rack to cool.

-Carla Phillips

SPICE CAKE, AMERICAN STYLE

I’d been searching for a good recipe for American-style spice cake for many, many years. A heavenly cake where the spice is present but not too insistent and a streusel (crumble) topping that gives this cake its own icing, and good texture and taste, this cake was particularly popular in the Mid-West and the South of the US. Various girls in my college dorm were sent versions of this by their mothers; I often looked for recipes of this particular cake which was delicious and had good ‘keeping’ qualities.

As I said, the combination of spices are not too strong. The nuts add texture and the raisins add moisture. It can be made in either an 8inch or 9inch tin; you can choose between a bigger or taller cake. And, an added advantage; no specialized equipment (mixers, etc) are required. The only ingredient which is slightly uncommon is buttermilk, which is sold be many supermarkets and any Eastern European shop will always stock it. Buttermilk will last in a fridge for three to four weeks.

Ingredients: 225g plain flour; 115g butter; 280g caster sugar; 1 tsp ground cinnamon; 1 tsp ground nutmeg; ½ tsp ground allspice; 1’2 ground cloves; ½ tsp salt; 120g chopped walnuts; 120g raisins; 200cl buttermilk; 1 large egg; 1 tsp vanilla; ½ tsp bicarb of soda.

Method: Preheat oven to 370’ (medium hot).Butter and line your cake tin. Pour 200cl of very hot water over the raisins while you get together the rest of the cake.Mix together the flour, sugar, salt and spices. Add the butter and blend it in with the fingers until it resembles breadcrumbs. Then remove and set aside a cupful of this mixture. This will be the cake’s topping. Now, drain the raisins and add this to the rest of the mixture, followed by the walnuts. Mix it together well. Beat the egg lightly with the vanilla and buttermilk. Add the bicarb, mix it all together then add the wet mixture to the rest of the cake. Pour the batter into the prepared cake tin, then sprinkle the reserved dry crumb mixture over the wet mixture in the cake tin. Bake it in for 40 minutes or so – until a sharp knife inserted into the cake comes out dry. When you take it out of the oven, leave it for 10 minutes or so before turning it out of its tin, then cooling..

These are the quick and easy solution to a holiday ‘problem’- of what to offer someone who has casually dropped in for a cup of tea or coffee. Cake? – No, too filling for grownups! Scones- No, a fiddle to prepare!

The Yankees have it right this time. A homemade biscuit- ‘cookies’, as we call them, is the perfect answer. And this following recipe is quick and simple to prepare. Once made, it also stores well in a tin or tightly lidded plastic box. The taste, redolent of spice and butter, is somehow appropriate for this season.

Ingredients: 110g plain flour; ½ tsp ground cinnamon; ½ tsp ground cardoman; dash of ground black pepper; dash of salt (if you use unsalted butter); ½ tsp bicarb (baking soda); 1and1/2 tsp warm water; 1and1/2 tsp dark treacle (or molasses);90g butter (softened, or at room temperature); 90g caster sugar.

Cool on a rack before storing.

STEAMED TREACLE PUDDING

My husband’s aunty owned and ran an upmarket hotel in Sutton Surrey from the 1930s until the mid ‘60s. She knew an awful lot about cookery. But, this was ‘Cook’s’ recipe, which had been used since Edwardian times. Her treacle sponge was incredibly popular; the grated apple and lemon flavourings cut through the extreme sweetness of the syrup. When I made it in our restaurant, using vegetarian suet (which I found to be lighter than the regular version), it was in constant demand. It can be made in a single pudding bowl or decanted into smaller bowls suitable for turning out as individual servings. This recipe will serve 4 or 5, and can always be re-steamed or heated in a microwave.

Ingredients: 120g self raising flour; 1 teaspoon baking powder; pinch of salt; 120g soft breadcrumbs; 1 level tablespoon brown sugar; 120g suet; 1 medium cooking apple, peeled and grated; zest of ½ lemon; 2 eggs; 2 eggs; juice of ½ lemon; 60ml milk; 1 teaspoon vanilla extract; 100ml golden syrup.

Method: Sift the flour, baking powder and pinch of salt together into a largish bowl. Add the breadcrumbs, the brown sugar, lemon zest and apple, then mix it again. Now, in a separate bowl, beat the eggs. Add the juice of the half lemon, the milk, vanilla and the golden syrup. Mix this into the dryer ingredients and spoon it into your pudding basin or individual little bowls. Cover with greaseproof or foil sheets of paper, which have a central pleated fold, so that the can expand as the puddings are cooked. You can anchor these papers with an elastic band.

Steam for 40 minutes. Turn out while still hot and serve with some golden syrup, warmed and diluted with juice from the remaining half lemon.

-Carla Phillips

Stuffed Mushrooms

Shirley Conran once stated that life was much too short to stuff a mushroom. Well, possibly her life! I think she was dead wrong. The following recipe is popular with family and friends as well as past customers.

First, however, a simple tomato sauce is required. I suppose that at a pinch you could buy one of those available in jars, but it’s simple enough to make.

Ingredients: 1 dessertspoon of olive oil; a small onion, finely chopped; 1 small clove of garlic, minced; 1 teaspoon of sugar; a small tin of tomatoes (any sort); ½ teaspoon of dried oregano; salt and pepper.

Method: Gently fry the onion in the olive oil, then add the garlic. Next, tip in the tin of tomatoes and also a tinful of water as well as the sugar and the oregano. Simmer this sauce for about 15 minutes, then season to taste. If you like your sauces smoooth, you can always blitz it with a blender, stick blender or processor.

Now, for the mushrooms.

Ingredients: For each large mushroom- 1 sausage (I particularly like Arthur Howell’s venison sausages for this recipe}, ½ slice of bread. Soaked briefly in water, then squeezed; the stem of the mushroom you’re stuffing; a small shallot and half a clove of garlic; ½ teaspoon of fennel seeds or a small chunk of fresh fennel; a little salt and pepper.

Method: Blitz these ingredients together. Pile them into the mushroom cap. Spoon a little tomato sauce in to a deep enough baking dish to contain the mushroom{s}. Cover with more of the tomato sauce/ Cover this dish lightly with aluminium foil, then bake it in a medium oven for 30-40 minutes. This is great served with either mash or pasta, and looks fine accompanied with very green greens, such as spring cabbage, calabrese or even sprouts.

STUFFED CELERY

A quick recipe, easily assembled. Nicely presented on a pretty plate, hand it out with the drinks, bite-sized snacks, mince pies; perfect for holiday occasions.

Ingredients: celery, with sticks separated and well scrubbed if you use the tasty ‘dirty’celery; 200g cream cheese; a teaspoon or so of lemon juice; 1 teaspoon of curry powder; a very small amount (about 2 teaspoons) of cream; 4 good sized tablespoons of chutney. Ingredients: 10 small cooked beetroot, cooked in their skin; 1 tablespoon of horseradish cream or sauce; 300ml cider vinegar; 100g sugar; 1 bay leaf; 1 teaspoon salt; a few peppercorns; 1 tablespoon of chopped dill; 1 or 2 onions, thinly sliced.

Method: Peel and slice the beetroot. Put the rest of the ingredients into a saucepan and bring them to the boil. Then add the sliced beetroot and when it is once more boiling, leave it to bubble away for 2-3 minutes. Then pour it into clean, warmed jars. Leave it to cool before refrigerating.

TECHNICOLOUR! -BUTTERNUT SQUASH SOUP

Bright orange, its high colour emboldened by the turmeric in the curry seasoning, the blazing appearance of this soup conceals its simplicity. Easy to make – not as rich as it looks- it is very cheering at a dark and dank winter mealtime.

Ingredients:1 smallish butternut squash, peeled, de-cored, chopped into bits; medium onion, sliced; tblsp vegetable oil; 1-2 cloves of garlic, finely chopped; 1 red chilli, de-seeded, ribs removed, then chopped; 1 walnut-sized peeled segment of ginger, either chopped or coarsely grated; 1 level tsp of ground coriander, ground cumin, turmeric and mild curry powder; juice of 1 ½ limes; salt and pepper. Now, add the onion and the spices, and cook for five minutes or so, stirring occasionally. THE MALTINGS AND THE COMMUNITY

June 6th, 2021

Yesterday, I wondered whether there were any spare tickets for the piano recitals scheduled at the Maltings. It was late morning on the Saturday – and I would have been happy with either tickets for that afternoon or return tickets for the day following, which had been advertised as sold out. So, I rang the Maltings. The answerphone told me that the box office was open during the weekdays and Saturday. Since it was Saturday, I rang once more in the hope that the phone might be answered. No chance. Examining the ‘What’s On’ leaflet there was the suggestion that I book through ‘nnmf’ – the North Norfolk Music Festival. No phone number was given. Useless!

Why am I telling you this? It’s because this sort of thing happens all too often/ The Maltings continues to lurch from glitch to mishap without hesitation.

So why ask for suggestions about community relations. Particularly with an emphasis on the local parents and the schools. It seems silly since the person originally hired to do this job, who actually did it splendidly, was dismissed. The disregard to all of the community projects which were welcomed by the parents and schools, which were valued highly by Ofstead school inspectors and acclaimed by the BBC, were ignored by the management at the Maltings. Indeed, except for one small event at the Maltings itself, the events held in the schools, well attended by parents of this community, were not ever visited by a single trustee, as far as I can tell.

This rankled with the community at large.

Ordinary Wells people have long complained of not being listened to when suggesting things. Workshops, Craft Fairs, Mini Craft Courses, a piano in the foyer (like St Pancras), Art classes..even a book exchange...all suggestions are met with cold politeness which masks arrogant hostility.There is a feeling that the Maltings is the Keeper of a Culture which is to be doled out to the deserving.

The publicity is a joke. No posters or flyers in the surrounding villages. No efforts to link up with the neighbouring communities.No notices for children to bring home.

I note that the return address is in Barnstaple. Why there? If this is about Wells, why has it come from afar? Is this the work of a distant commercial firm? Only asking….

Carla Phillips

TOMATO SOUP WITH DILL

ON ITS OWN OR AS AN ACCOMPANIMENT

Here is a little dish which is wonderful served as a vegetable on its own. But is delightful accompanying several other, very plainly cooked, ingredients: steamed veg, roasted chicken or steamed fish…

It’s not elegant or smooth enough to classify as a sauce, but serves the same purpose: put together with simple ingredients, it will ‘lift’ even the simplest meal. And its made of that widely available summer ingredient: fresh tomatoes. The little sorts of tomatoes, commonly grown by many of us, are simply perfect.

The weight called for does not have to be exact, This is not an exact formula to inscribe on stone. It’s the method of cooking (very rapid) which counts here.

Ingredients: approximately 250g (1/2 lb) of small tomatoes, sliced in half; 1 spring onion or shallot, finely chopped; 1 teaspoon (a walnut sized lump) of butter; salt and pepper; 2 tablespoons of white wine (I use Vermouth- it’s cheap and doesn’t go off rapidly); 1 tablespoon of either chopped fresh tarragon or dill or fennel; 1 tablespoon of cream.

Method: Heat up a smallish frying pan. Then put the shallots or spring onion in with the butter, followed by the tomatoes. Season with salt and pepper, then add the wine. When this is on the boil, add the cream, and as soon as it amalgamates and starts to reduce (very quickly, you’ll find), add the herbs.

TURKEY TETRAZZINI

This delicious combination of pasta and turkey was a big deal in the 1950s. Named after famous opera singer Luisa Tetrazzini by a Californian chef anxious to please her, the recipe originally called for poached chicken. Like so many great dishes of that time, imitations and ‘instant’ versions of the dish gradually debased this wonderful recipe, well worthy of revival. Nowadays it’s a post Christmas star, its quality rising and falling upon the nature of the stock made from the leftover bird.

So, to make a good turkey stock use the bones, any broth or gravy you already have, together with a chopped large carrot, onion, stick or two of celery and a couple of cloves of garlic. Place these all in a large saucepan, together with a couple of bay leaves, a few peppercorns and a couple of cloves.Bring it all to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer it all together for a good hour.

Then, remove from the heat and sieve the stock into a bowl, discarding the solids. Return the liquid to the stove, and cook once more, boiling until it’s reduced to about 300-250ml.

To complete the dish you will need 350g sliced mushrooms;60g butter; 3 tablespoons of sherry (any sort); 150cl cream; 2 tablespoons of plain flour; 250g spaghetti; salt and pepper; leftover turkey meat cut into smallish pieces; 30-40g grated parmesan

Method: Make the sauce by melting half the butter, then adding the flour then adding the hot, reduced stock. Bring this to a boil, stirring the while. Reduce the heat, and allow to simmer very gently for 5 minutes. Then add the cream and sherry and season to taste.

Cook the spaghetti until it’s ‘al dente’, Drain and rinse quickly to prevent the strands from sticking together. Saute the sliced mushrooms in the rest of the butter. Then toss the spaghetti and mushrooms together with half of the sauce. Place this in a fairly large casserole or roasting tin. Stir the turkey into the remaining sauce, make a depression in the spag-mushroom mixture and spoon the turkey into it. Cover it with the grated parmesan and bake in a moderate to hottish oven for 30 minutes. Serve immediately.

The original recipe called for chopped truffles over it all- which isn’t particularly practical for present day cooks- but if you were given a bottle of truffle oil as a present, now is the time for a dribble of it over the dish as it comes out of the oven.

This recipe makes enough to serve 8-10 people—and if it seems too great an amount, it does freeze nicely

Ingredients: 100g poppy seeds; 200ml milk; 225g butter (at room temperature); 130g light brown sugar; 3 eggs; 300g flour, sifted with 1 tblsp baking powder and a tsp of baking soda [bicarb] and ½ tsp salt; 1 tsp vanilla extract; 3 tblsp lemon juice [juice of a lemon]; 1 tsp grated lemon zest – and a 20cm (8 inch) deep baking tin, greased and lined with Bakewell or greasproof paper.

Method: place the poppy seeds and milk in a small saucepan. Heat, just until the milk is starting to boil [scalding], then remove it from the heat and allow it to cool for at least a quarter of an hour. Cream the butter and sugar well, then add the eggs, one by one, Then alternatively add the sifted dried ingredients with the poppy seed-milk mixture, finishing with the dried ingredients. Stir just enough to blend well, then add the vanilla, lemon juice and zest. Spread this batter into the baking tin and bake in a moderately hot oven(350’) for 40 minutes. - UPSIDE-DOWN CAKE

This is a great use for some of the fine stone fruit available during the summer time. In winter, tinned or bottled fruit, including tinned pineapple, also works well.

Use apricots, peaches, plums, cut in half with the stones removed. As it is reversed onto its serving dish, remember this when placing your fruit in the cooking pan. Traditionally cooked in a heavy-bottomed skillet or frying pan with an ovenproof handle, I possess nothing suitable, so use an ordinary 9 inch (23cm) cake tin, lightly oiled and lined on the bottom with Bakewell (silicon) paper. When I turn the cake onto its platter, the results look good, even if my fingers may get a bit sticky during the reversal, peeling off the paper.

Preheat your oven to low to moderate (approx 325-350F – 170-180C)

Ingredients: 130g butter; 200g brown sugar; a punnet of apricots, peaches or plums – more if you like your fruit crowded together, as I do; 4 eggs, separated; 180g caster sugar; 120g self-raising flour; 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract; a pinch of salt

Method: In a heavy-ish saucepan, melt the butter. Before continuing further, set aside 3 teaspoons of this melted butter in a little container. Now, add the brown sugar into your saucepan. Stir until the sugar is well dissolved and only just beginning to bubble slightly. Remove this from the heat and our it into the cake tin. Now, distribute your halved and stoned fruit on top of this.

And now for the batter itself. Beat the egg whites with a pinch of salt until they are stiff. Gradually add the caster sugar, meringue fashion.

Now, beat the egg yolks well. Add the 3 teaspoons of melted butter, then the vanilla. Fold this into the meringue mixture. Last of all sift and fold the self-raising flour into the meringue and yolk mixture. Pour this batter over the fruit mixture in the baking tin and bake it for 30-40 minutes, until it’s a lovely golden brown and the middle doesn’t wobble when lightly poked.

Reverse it onto a serving dish. It’s great when hot but also fine served cold or even gently reheated. Serve with cream, ice cream or a fruit fool.

WILD MUSHROOM SOUP

Some former customers of mine reminisced about driving up for a Wells weekend, starting with a meal at our restaurant, anticipating a bowl of this particular soup. It was very popular, with a substantial taste and rich texture which far exceeded its relatively simple ingredients. I still make this frequently, especially when the weather is grim.

Ingredients: 500g onions, halved and very thinly sliced; 1-2 cloves of garlic, peeled and finely minced; 1 tablespoon of dried wild mushrooms (porcini); 250g mushrooms (very large ones or brown ‘chestnut’ ones taste best) finely sliced; 20g butter; 1 tablespoon of olive oil; 1 tablespoon of soy sauce; 1 tablespoon of sweet sherry or Marsala; 1 tablespoon of tomato puree; 300ml milk; 2 tablespoons of cream; salt and pepper; a little chopped parsley for a garnish.

Method: First of all, soak the dried mushrooms in about a teacup of boiling water, leaving them to stand while you prepare the rest of the ingredients. Then, heat an empty heavy bottomed saucepan. Throw in the sliced onions, stirring wells as they start to steam and colour. Then add the butter and olive oil, and reduce the heat under them. Stir briefly, then cover and leave it all to gently cook until the onions are a rich golden brown. Now, pump up the heat and add the sliced fresh mushrooms. Stir well, then add the garlic. Strain the soaking (previously dried) mushrooms, reserving the soaking liquid. Add these mushrooms to the other ingredients, mixing well. Next, add the soy sauce, sherry or Marsala, tomato puree and the soaking liquid and enough water to cover all these ingredients by about 2 inches. WARMING SOUPS

.In an icy winter my usual strategy is to make thick vegetable soups which ‘do’ for several meals. Buying myself a stick blender (an inexpensive stout zapper which pulverizes easily and quickly) has made this an easy task. Schlepping hot mixtures from the saucepan into the blender or food processor tends to be fraught and messy. Plungeing this little machine directly into the cooking pot- with its detachable, quickly washed out business end, has made life considerably easier.

And so to the soups themselves/ Basically, most soups start with the sauteing (or gentle frying) of onions – or several of their relatives such as leeks, shallots, spring onions, together with a potato or two. The potato adds the thickish, slightly velvety texture. From then on, you can add as much or as little as you please. You can add a little curry powder, or garlic,chilli and ginger. You can add herbs. You can throw in most vegetables: beetroot, carrots, root vegetables, squashes, celery, etc. You can certainly add any cooked leftover vegetables to hand.

Next comes stock. I use a combination of vegetable water and commercial vegetable stock powder (‘Marigold’is my preference). But you can add chicken, ham, game or beef stock, if that’s what you have and like.

But, that absolutely basic mixture of onion and potato is perfectly fine on its own. A good friend who spent a winter studying in Lisbon told me of the regular, delicious starter served up by his Portugese landlady each night.

She started bu heating up a largish saucepan, to which she added a couple of tablespoons of olive oil. She cut up either one large or two medium onions which she added to the oil. Then she peeled a large potato, chopped it up and added that. She then turned down the fire under the pot, covered it, and only occasionally stirred it until the potatoes had started to soften.

To this, she added vegetable stock (about 500ml). This was brought to the boil and simmered until the potato was entirely soft. Then she removed the saucepan from the heat and shredded, very finely, some dark green cabbage or kale.

The soup was then liquidized and returned to the stove, to reheat. The shredded cabbage was chucked in to cook for barely two or three minutes, and then the soup was served. Sometimes a slice or two of chorizo or sausage went on top as a garnish, but this wasn’t an everyday occurrence.

Try this. It’s simple, cheap and tasty and helps combat those chilly winter blues.

-Carla Phillips

AMERICAN YOGURT CAKE-EASY PEASY!

I’d heard about this cake, made without using machinery in less than 15 minutes. It’s baked in a loaf tin, easy to slice, easy to store. With plenty of add-on variations. And, no machinery or muscle power is required. The loaf tin needs to be greased and dusted with flour or use one of those cheap widely available frilly paper moulds, expressly designed for this job. All you really need is two bowls, which don’t even have to be the same size.

Ingredients: 220g self raising flour;1 tsp baking powder; 7g salt; 150g caster sugar; the grated zest of a lemon; 100ml vegetable oil; 170g whole milk Greek yogurt; 2 eggs; ½ tsp vanilla extract.

Method: Preheat oven to 180’c. Grease and flour the tin. Weigh the flour, baking powder and salt into a bowl. Mix them lightly. In the other bowl, rub the lemon zest into the sugar till it is slightly moist. Then add the yogurt, oil, eggs, vanilla. Whisk them all briefly, before folding in the dry ingredients. Pour it into the baking tin, smoothing the top and bake until the top of the cake is golden and a toothpick or skewer inserted into the cake comes out dry (45-55 minutes). Let the cake cool in the tin for 15 minutes before inverting it onto a rack.

You can omit the lemon zest and add more vanilla. Or, at the last moment, fold in chopped nuts, raisins or other dried fruit, chocolate chips….I iced the lemon cake with icing sugar stirred into warm lemon juice...possibilities are endless.

-Carla Phillips
